0440237688|5.0|\\"THE GIVER\\" is the story of 12-year-old Jonas (no last name) a boy who lives in a world where everything is controlled. There are thousands of strict rules to follow, and everything is chosen by a select Council of Elders. This includes jobs, marital partners, children, etc. There is no color, no emotion, no diversity.  <br />  The story is good from the beginning, but really picks up at the Ceremony of Twelve, where children who turn twelve that year get jobs chosen for them by the Council and go into training. Other kids get jobs like Engineer and Laborer, Jonas gets specially selected to be the Reciever of Memory. <br />  On his first day of training, Jonas meets the Giver, a kind old man that transmits memories of past generations into Jonas, so he can gain wisdom. There are happy memories, such as sailing on a lake, and going downhill on a sled, but there are sad and horrible memories, like poverty, war, and physical pain.  <br />  I won't go into much detail from there, because I've told you too much already, but I will say this gets thumbs up from me. Highly recommended.

B0001YRVN4|5.0|I love Star Wars, and I always have.  It's the original sci-fi saga.  You can't even compare it with Star Trek because it's so much better.  I'm sorry, maybe I'm a little biased.  But Star Wars has, is, and always will be my favorite science fiction series. <br /> <br />It's not just the fact that the acting is superb, the plot is riveting, and the settings are realistic (despite that the movies were produced in the 70s [i think? - i wasn't around back then]).  Somehow, the trilogy is understandable and easy to relate to (unlike Lord of the Rings, for instance).  You fall in love with the characters in Episode IV, and that's what holds your attention more than anything else for the rest of the trilogy. <br /> <br />Some might suggest that you watch Episodes I-III first, before you get to these.  I suppose you could do that, but I maintain that you don't need to.  These movies were made to stand alone, and they have.  You don't need to watch episodes I-III before you get to these.  In fact, I am of the opinion that you should watch the older movies first, because I think that the first three episodes are far more confusing.  It would be easier to understand if you've already seen the originals. <br /> <br />Regarding plot, it is a bit confusing, but not too badly.  First, the emperor aand Darth Vader have pretty much taken over the Universe and destroyed all thats left of the Jedi (except for Obi-Wan and Yoda).  To go into that, the Jedi use the Force for good and the Dark Side use it for bad.  Thus, the classic theme of good v. evil emerges.  Anyway, two droids land on a planet and meet up with Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill).  There's a message from a damsel in distress on one of the droids, and Luke takes the droid to Obi-Wan, who lives nearby.  Returning home, Luke finds his aunt and uncle dead, killed by imperial troops.  He then decides to join Obi-Wan in his mission to help the Princess Lea, who has been captured by Darth Vader.  From there, the plot is obvious.Luke joins up with Han Solo (Harrison Ford) to help the rebels (another facet of the good side fighting against the Empire).  And the story goes on from there, until predictably, the Empire is defeated. <br /> <br />Of course, there's a lot of drama and action and revealed information in between.  That's what makes it good. <br /> <br />I love all the characters in Star Wars.  My favorite, I must admit, is Han Solo.  He's just that cool.  Luke's character is also well done, as is basically everyone else's.  The director even takes the time to develop the droid's and Chewbacca's personas.  The character development is what makes this movie great. <br /> <br />Action scenes are superb for the time these movie were made.  Special effects are amazing and seem real despite the fact that most aliens are people in costumes.  Whereas the new Star Wars movies rely almost totally on digital animation (the biggest problem i have with the new movies), the old ones rely on acting and just plain, good old-fashioned costumes. <br /> <br />I won't even get into the new movies here.  The old ones are SO MUCH BETTER!!  I LOVE THE OLD STAR WARS MOVIES!  The new ones were decent, I suppose, but they could have been so much better.  The acting was mediocre, and although special effects were good, i think that they should have modelled the new ones after these three originals.  After all, you can never top the original, but you can at least try to imitate it!
B0009A1AS2|4.0|I have been a DT fan for quite some time now, so my review may be slightly biased.  Octavarium is an excellent CD for a veteran DT fan, as well as the 16 year old who is just discovering them.  As with all DT efforts, the musicianship is unrivaled.  Lets face it, Dream Theater is a musician's band.  Moving on......This album places a heavy emphasis on the melody.  After listening to the songs a few times, you will more than likely be humming the tune.  Track 4, \\"I Walk Beside You\\" is very U2, as far as the guitar work and soaring melody.  Track 3, \\"These Walls,\\" flat out rocks, regardless on the clean guitar/distorion contrast.  The title track, \\"Octavarium\\" is great if you have a spare 24 mins to listen to it.  I think it would have been more practical to break it up into different tracks as with 6 Degrees of Inner Turbulence.....Next..... <br />Fans who love Train of Thought will find that this album is very different.  Just as good or better depending on your taste, but just not as heavy.  Train of thought is a metal monster.  This is a more well rounded group of songs, or should I say Octad :-) .... To sum it up, if you're into great melodies, buy this record.  If you're into difficult instrumental thrashing, buy this CD.  If you like neither of the above, buy it anyway.  Also, you could always listen to the song clips online and form your own damn opinions rather then reading what other people think!!!!

The \\"fine wine\\" I was referring to before has turned into a massive market selling label.The appeal it first had when you didn't know of its full potential has become worldwide. B000006045|5.0|I picked this up in 1998, in Ottawa, on a blind whim. I didn't know what \\"trip-hop\\" was, who Massive Attack was, or what the album was going to sound like (I just thought the cover was cool). I popped in into my rental-car stereo -- and was totally blown away. I drove around aimlessly for two hours so I could keep listening. <br />  Seven years later, Mezzanine's still near the top of my 500-album stack, in heavy rotation. <br />  This album crosses dozens of genre lines but doesn't bow to any of them. Somehow, M.A. managed to synthesize something completely new out of borrowed pieces of hip-hop, classical, anthem rock, metal, industrial and its own pre-Mezzanine sound. I'm waiting for another group of artists to achieve something even remotely as imaginative and ahead of its time as Mezzanine. <br />   Even if the Bristol sound isn't your thing, you have to appreciate Mezzanine as a creative stroke of genius. If you like music at all, you'll be well rewarded for giving it a listen.
0792839730|4.0|Very good adaption of the Ryan book, which stays about as true to the epic narrative as is probably possible. I've seen others remark that the score to the movie sometimes is out of place, and I would agree, but it's still one of my favorite movie scores, and is quite rousing.    I'm generally not a fan of the 'big name star stew' casting, but it works, for the most part, in this movie. Bogarde and Hackman are especially good. One of my pet peeves in war movies is obvious anachronism. It appears here in the use of modern vehicles in place of period German tanks. I can excuse this, since this movie didn't have the boundless budget of, say, Saving Private Ryan. They did at least use Shermans for the Allies. Overall, the movie is entertaining, and reasonably true to the book/historical events.    The dvd itself, however, is nothing special. The picture isn't horrible, but it's a little grainy, and you get pretty frequent flashes of scarred film. The movie would probably need a serious revamping, a la 'Vertigo' or 'Rear Window' to substantially improve this, though, so this is likely the best we'll get.

B0009AM5JA|4.0|The above quote taken from a Pitchfork review, which for the first time in a long long time hit the nail right on the head for me.<br /><br />I have to say that compared to the disaster that was A Rush Of Blood To The Head, this is a huge step forward in their sound as a band (although Chris is very often drowned out by everyone else). They captured a little bit of that live sound that is the only reason I became interested in Coldplay. That's all that keeps me from giving this album 3 stars.<br /><br />The album starts off strong, with Will showing off some not-so-basic drumming skillz. Finally a little variety in his style. Standout tracks on this album are 'Square One', 'White Shadows', 'Low', and 'Twisted Logic'. The latter, I feel, is Coldplay's best and most promising song ever. It is one of the few songs on X&Y that goes in a different direction (albeit, slightly Radiohead-esque) without sounding like they're ripping anyone off too hard.<br /><br />The complaints I have about this album are that the songs too often come off as uninspired. The biggest \\"WTF??\\" that was drawn from me came from the first single, 'Speed of Sound'. In a way it's what 'Clocks' should have been, but since it wasn't, there really is no reason for such a blatant recycling of music. Not a bad song, but the simple fact that 'Clocks' came first really takes all the credibility away for me.<br /><br />Coldplay are showing off their influences more than ever on this album. 'Talk', which samples Kraftwerk's 'Computer Love', came off to me as annoying on first listen, just because I was all \\"Hey, it's Kraftwerk.\\" 'Fix You' is not sampling anything, though I found it is very heavy on the Sigur Ros-itude. Comparing it to Sigur Ros leaves a lot to be desired; on its own, 'Fix You' is a good song.<br /><br />The good points of this album seem to reside heavily on the \\"X\\" side of the album, while \\"Y\\" is very stagnant sounding. It's like the pressure of EMI finally caught up to them and they just quickly wrote some generic Coldplay stuff. So this record gets props for being a step forward for Coldplay, even if it is a very small and hesitant step.<br /><br />X&Y also gets props for the most niftiest of trendy silicone wristbands it came with.f. So this record gets props for being a step forward for Coldplay, even if it is a very small and hesitant step.    X&Y also gets props for the most niftiest of trendy silicone wristbands it came with.

B00006L3LD|4.0|As many have said, the DVD content is pretty limited. Tour videos, a music video, and an abundantly useless discography. It speaks of online offers for a &quot;night time&quot; version of the 'Are You In?' video, but if you're like me and just got the album, the video is no longer available.<br />As for the music, this is probably what Make Yourself should've been. The sound has improved a bit, and Brandon no longer sounds drowned out by the band.<br />The best songs are '11 am', 'Just A Phase', 'Mexico', 'Under My Umbrella', and 'Aqueous Transmission'. 'Under My Umbrella' is a  nice fast pace sound, with an awesome bridge reminiscent of Porcupine Tree. 'Aqueous Transmission' mixes West with the East and is very effective. The only song I really have a problem with is 'Blood On The Ground'; it just isn't the greatest song ever, and the lyrics are pretty bad.<br />The best thing about this album is how Incubus tries to display as wide a range as can be managed in the nu-metal-esque genre (yes I know they are not nu-metal). There's dynamic changes, occasional variety in instrumentation, dissonance, and genre fusion (see Aqueous Transmission).<br />If you're into Incubus, this album gets my highest recommendation (second to A Crow Left Of The Murder).
B0007Y4TVU|5.0|The answer would be yes. This is System's best album to date, and the only possible flaw with it is that it is too short. But seeing as how that shall be remedied this fall with the second part, Hypnotize, that's not something to complain about too much. Many people complain about Daron getting too much vocal time. I have to admit, at first, I was put off by him. But after a few listens, I have come to see that there is no problem in that at all. Of course, we all know that it would have been better with more Serj, but it is still great the way it is, as Daron is a great singer in his own way. <br /> <br />1. Soldier Side (Intro) - By itself, no, this is not a great song. But seeing as it's meant as an intro, it is great. It is deceptive as well, as the next song is completely different from the calmness and softness of this one. As an intro, this is a good song. 8/10 <br /> <br />2. B.Y.O.B. - Starts off very fast, and then it suddenly slows down to R&B style for the chorus. A very strange thing to do, but good anyways. Both the verses and the chorus sound very good. It sounds really awesome when they say \\"Where the f*** are you?\\" and then they start saying \\"Why don't presidents fight the war? Why do they always send the poor?\\" The song during and after that part is amazing, and great to listen to. A very good song. 9/10 <br /> <br />3. Revenga - Starts off seeming like it will be slow, but the the guitars kick in. The verses are so fast it's almost impossible to tell what they're saying the first few times around. The verses are fast as hell and the chorus is slower, but amazing too, with incredible guitar riffs within it. The part where the music almost completely drops out, and it's Daron singing with Serj in harmony fits perfectly. A great song as well. 9/10 <br /> <br />4. Cigaro - The lyrics will definately take you off guard the first time around; this is a rather amusing song. The chorus is spectacular in this, with Serj and the guitar melding perfectly together. Daron's \\"Can't you see that I love my c***?\\" line and the two following it sound really great. A very funny, and very good, song. 9/10 <br /> <br />5. Radio/Video - This song would have been truly extraordinary if it weren't for the chorus. The chorus in here just bugs me to no end. The verses, on the other hand, are awesome. The only other annoying thing in here is later on, when Serj sings the chorus really softly, but then screams 'radio' and 'video'. That just really didn't need to be in there either. Don't get me wrong, though; I like this song, for the rest of it is really great. It just could have been better if those two things were taken out and replaced. Overall, a good song. 8/10 <br /> <br />6. This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song - The title alone should tell you that this will be an interesting song. This song makes practically no sense whatsoever, and has some of the most bizarre vocals from Serj to be heard yet, but it's still awesome. The \\"Gonorrhea, gorgonzola\\" part is really fun and amusing. If there is some type of message to be had in this song, I sure have no idea what it is, but it's a keeper regardless. 8/10 <br /> <br />7. Violent Pornography - This is one of my favorite songs on the album. Starts off slow, and then Serj and Daron come in. I love the \\"It's a non-stop disco, bet you it's Nabisco, bet you didn't know, whoo-hoo!\\" part. The chorus is amazing, even though there's really nothing all that special about it. I just love listening to it; it's probably the guitar and harmony. The second repeat of the chorus, around 2:20, is amazing. I really like the very end, where Serj stutters \\"brainwashing\\", and then Daron says \\"It's a non-stop disco\\" one last time. 10/10 <br /> <br />8. Question! - It's hard to describe this song... it's just extraordinary. The verses and chorus are both sung melodically, and the chorus sounds truly epic. The third repeat of the chorus just blows me away, with the guitar playing away incrediblyfast underneath it. You have to listen to this song to really understand why it is so great. 10/10 <br /> <br />9. Sad Statue - The verses are great and fast paced, especially the ones where Daron and Serj harmonize. The chorus is very unexpected, as it suddenly slows to about half as fast as it was. It sound good, though. The final repeat of the chorus is noticable. A good song. 8/10 <br /> <br />10. Old School Hollywood - This is a very different song, for System. It has a very techno-type feel for most of it, but that is by no means a bad thing. The guitar in this song is incredible beyond belief. The chorus is nice, but it's the guitar that is the true star in this song; it's amazing. Really the only downfall is that Daron sounds a little obnoxious during the verses, but the rest is too great to dislike it just for that reason. 10/10 <br /> <br />11. Lost In Hollywood - Completely different from the rest of the album, this song is disliked by many because Daron is the main singer. Well, that doesn't matter at all, as this is still a great song. It never gets hard or rough at all, it is sweet, melodic singing throughout. Serj sounds really nice in the background, and Daron sounds just fine at the front. The song is sad and tragic, but very heartfelt. The moaning throughout sounds wonderful. This is probably the best ending to an album System has had so far, and an amazing song in its own right. 10/10
B0006L16N8|5.0|I have to admit that I have not been a huge fan of Coldplay over the years.  I do like some of their past songs on an individual basis but not the full album.  There are not many bands that can put together a FULL album of songs that can be played over and over.  Most just have maybe 5 to 6 songs that acomplish that.  Having said that, I have crossed over to the world that is Coldplay with thier latest release X&Y.  I bought the album on a whim after sampling some songs and I have not taken it out of my cd player since.  In fact, I have not stopped talking about it to other fans.  Every song on this album is great and I find myself struggling to find a favorite.  You can really tell who inspires this album. B00003CXBH|5.0|The way in which The Mission, which is set c. 1750, integrates the life of Rodrigo Mendoza, a former capturer of indigenous people for the slave trade, to the lives of Jesuit missionaries and the lives of the indigenous people of Argentina, Paraguay, and Brazil is absolutely amazing. <br /> I would like to focus on the issue of the indigenous culture of South America that is portrayed in the film-the Guarani Indians.  I feel that the lenses through which the indigenous people are viewed in the film are realistic, as you can say.  There are, basically, two perspectives on the indigenous people in the film.  The first perspective views the indigenous people as \\"animals.\\"  This perspective is held by Don Cabeza and by other representatives that back up Spain's and Portugal's intentions to take over the land of the indigenous, as well as to enslave them.  The second perspective is shared by Father Gabriel, Rodrigo (who, ironically, has become a Jesuit and, therefore, serves the interests of the indigenous people), and the other Jesuit missionaries; this perspective views the indigenous people as valuable human beings with rights. <br /> The relationship among the indigenous community and the Europeans begins by being hostile, for the first Christian priest to arrive to the area is murdered.  However, Father Gabriel accomplishes to win the love and trust of the indigenous people.  <br />The role that religion plays in the film is extremely important.  The indigenous people come to believe the word of the Jesuits-that is, that it is God's will for them to abandon the jungle and build a mission.  Their convictions grow to be so strong that later, when the Cardinal, who professes to speak for Portugal's king and for the Catholic Church, insists that it is crucial for them to abandon the mission, the Guarani leader opposes to do so and, instead, fights back.  Other aspects, regarding the relationship among the Europeans and the indigenous people, that stand out in the videoare the indigenous people's adoption of European religious rituals, beliefs and daily life practices, the role that language plays, and lastly, the issue of power among the oppressing entities of politics and religion. <br />In conclusion, I definitely recommend The Mission.  It is one of the most compelling videos that I have ever watched, and what is most compelling about it is that its historical aspect is actually based on facts.  It brings up the following ideas: What does it mean to be a human being?  Who has the right to determine what a human being's rights are?  How can men be capable of being so selfish, inhumane and cruel to other human beings, yet they are also capable of being so loving and altruistic in such a way that they are willing to give up their lives for others? <br />

B0009A1AS2|4.0|While not their best album, it's far from their worst and I find that I really enjoy \\"Octavarium,\\" Dream Theater's latest CD.  I've always liked how they can experiment with different sounds and not make one album sound like any of the others, yet still retain their signature style and identity.  For the last 4 albums they've been doing what they do best, and this is no exception. <br /> <br />If you don't like bands that change from album to album, then you may not enjoy much of DT's work.  There is a good variety on this album that showcases the different styles they can play (much like \\"Falling Into Infinity\\" or \\"Six Degress...\\"), so it might throw off newer fans who joined the fray because of the dark and heavy \\"Train of Thought.\\"  Mike Portnoy is a self-professed big fan of Muse, and last summer they toured with Yes, and those influences can clearly be heard on this album. <br /> <br />The slower tracks (\\"The Answer Lies Within\\" and \\"I Walk Beside You\\") are as close to mainstream and radio singles as DT has been in a while, but the songs are palatable and grow on you.  The opening track, \\"The Root of All Evil\\" is a continuation of songs from the last two albums (\\"The Glass Prison\\" from 6DOIT and \\"This Dying Soul\\" from TOT) and rehashes some of the same riffs...so it's not spectacular, but I find it interesting to listen to variations on the same themes, much the way King Crimson has done many times over multiple albums. <br /> <br />The final 24-minute track, \\"Octavarium,\\" is pretty good, though not great...the majority of it sounds just like an old Yes epic in the vein of \\"Close to the Edge,\\" but it has those DT influences and in the end it's not bad.  It's definitely different and again, it grows on you. <br /> <br />\\"Never Enough\\" is the only weak track, in my opinion.  The only other thing I don't like about the CD is the sleeve artwork by Hugh Syme.  Makes me feel like I'm holding a Rush CD (Syme has done basically every Rush cover in existence).  It has the same font, etc...bad design, but then, I didn't buy it for the sleeve, so it really doesn't matter in the long run. <br /> <br />Now when comparing this album to other DT albums, one must put everything in perspective.  A lot of people will say \\"oh, they've never put out anything good since Images and Words, blah blah blah...\\"  On the contrary, they've put out a lot of material that's better than \\"Images and Words\\" since then.  People's expectations are too high.  If you like at least 3 of DT's previous albums, you'll like \\"Octavarium.\\"  If you have \\"been a fan\\" since 1992, yet have been disappointed with all their efforts since then, and are still mad that Kevin Moore left the band, then this album is definitely not for you.  You're just old and stuck in a nostalgic time warp.  Times change, music changes, people change.  Things progress.  I'm glad DT takes chances and experiments with every album.  I enjoy their shredding as much as the next guy, but they don't have to do it every single song on every album. <br /> <br />\\"Octavarium\\" is quite a change from their previous album, \\"Train of Thought,\\" and I expected no less.

B00005JMJ4|4.0|Tokyo sparkles as the third main character in this sweet, platonic, slice-of-life love story.<br /><br />Set in the dazzling confusion of a far and exotic city, the story is full of courteous characters who communicate beyond words. Understatement and deep feelings abound in the superficial conversations of people just getting acquainted, such as Charlotte and Bob, or already too acquainted and too loosely attached, as in their respective marriages.<br /><br />The music is atmospheric and dreamy, and the soundtrack includes Bill Murray's pleasant karaoke performance of \\"More Than This.\\"<br /><br />Having just returned from Tokyo and loving it, I've watched \\"Lost in Translation\\" at least three times, enjoying the opening scene of the Ginza district at night, its tall neon lights all in bewildering and utterly incomprehensible symbols, and the charming manners and gestures of the people.<br /><br />We pointed to menus, just as Bob and Charlotte did, even in McDonald's, yes, McDonald's for pancake breakfast. It was too early in the morning for another tasty, raw octopus tentacle. And chopsticks were totally daunting. My husband observes that chopsticks, noodles and I were not a pretty sight.<br /><br />I visited an art museum to see a Van Gogh exhibit--a contrast in cultures. I stood in front of Van Gogh's painting of the asylum where he stayed in his bi-polar bouts. A Japanese gentleman in a suit also stood there. We looked at the painting. We looked at each other. We looked at the painting, shook our heads, sighed over Van Gogh's pain. A million words passed between us in those looks.<br /><br />So it was in LIT.<br /><br />The laid-back pace of the character-driven story illustrated their jet-lagged boredom a little too well for my husband, a daughter, and a son-in-law, hence, the four stars. But another daughter and I loved it.<br /><br />The understated, sometimes hilarious performances of the entire cast, including an over-the-top lounge singer and a Britney Spears wannabe are all excellent.<br /><br />And I know I'll never approach an ellyptical machine again without smiling.<br /><br />They could eliminate one tasteless scene, however, without losing the story line, ***when Charlotte says they're going to meet Charlie at a place called Orange. That's a good time to hit a button called Skip*** because it turns out to be a raunchy night club they soon leave, with a vulgar song in the background. The whole scene was out of place, alas, and could have been only suggested or totally left out instead of so in-your-face. Yuck. And the movie would be amusing family fare without it.<br /><br />The song is mercifully left off the wonderful, ethereal sound track.<br /><br />The story could be a good springboard for discussion: Would you mind your spouse, in lonely desperation, sharing a bed, only in platonic innocence, with another?<br /><br />More to the point, how would you keep your spouse--and yourself--from reaching that point of lonely desperation? Maybe you could work out together on the ellyptical.... :)w I'll never approach an ellyptical machine again without smiling. B000001FG5|5.0|This is mostly just awful, the nadir of the Bee Gees' remarkable catalogue. They knew what they were doing in the wake of the astonishing Saturday Night Fever, all right. The packaging gives it away: blow-dried, cynical and slick. As they stand, in wind-blown silhouette against the raging sky, are those really their SHORTS (no pun intended, ever) peeking from between their presumably hairy legs?? Talk about bathos. As for the actual music, only the wonderful 'Tragedy' which leads the suspicious pack is really worthy of the Bee Gees' incredible canon; the rest is mostly filler. Two other tracks stand out as well, but hey- -we're speaking relatively here. The title track and the funky 'Search, Find' provide a mild one-two punch midway through the dreck. Elsewhere, the overweening vapidity of the hits 'Too Much Heaven' and 'Love You Inside And Out' belies whatever creativity informs the arch production; that they were hits at all says a lot about marketing and the state of commercial radio in the beleaguered 70s- -and whose fault was that? I love these guys, and I know they had to get this stuff out of their system, but thank the Helium God they began losing the balloons over the next few releases. Probably started wearing long pants again, too.

0671015206|3.0|I found this book in a thrift shop, a strategy the authors surely would applaud (even if it doesn't augment their attempts to accrue prodigious wealth).  While many of their observations and data hold true, there are two constraints they should have mentioned. One is possible cohort effects. Most of the millionaires they interviewed appeared to have grown up in the Depression, when attitudes toward money and resources were shaped by a particular time in history. Will the \\"Millionaires Next Door\\" in 2010 look the same? The second is: where does the fun of life enter in?  Yes, one can save money by buying old cars, eating in diners, living in a trailer, and buying clothes at Sears, but what about enjoyment? There's something to be said for appreciating the finer things in life when one is around to do so, and not everyone lives forever, no matter how good their financial planning may be.  The moralistic tone invoked for any discussion of luxury goods was offputting.

B0006L16N8|5.0|let's face it. Coldplay avoided the \\"sophomore jinx\\" quite eloquently with the majestic \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\". i think perhaps that the THIRD album of a \\"new-ish\\" band might be an even BIGGER hurdle to cross (than the SECOND). Coldplay leans on a more \\"expansive\\" sounding record than the previous two. you might expect that success has \\"Rushed\\" to the heads of Martin, Buckland, Berryman and Champion but there are plenty of hints of disillusionment and melancholy on X&Y. rather than getting grounded and bogged down in dispair OR complaceny Coldplay chooses to SOAR with songs regret AND love,...perhaps looking down (but never back). this album really seems to exist somewhere \\"above the ground\\" or \\"in the clouds\\". maybe it's the cloud-like synth breaths that blow behind many of the tracks. maybe it's the fact that vocal harmonies saturate this record TO GREAT EFFECT. it's not a complete departure but it IS artistic growth. these are solid musicians. none stands out. there is no show-boating. it is a cohesive whole. the only weak spot on the record is the nails-on-the-chalkboard vocals and cliched guitar choruses of FIX YOU. The lead single SPEED OF SOUND has a beautifully catchy chorus, THE HARDEST PART jangles delightfully and if SQUARE ONE, WHITE SHADOWS, and especially TALK don't get into your skin,..well....i feel sorry for you. this is (for the most part) a pretty impressive pallette of melodic adventure. DO NOT miss it.

1400082773|5.0|Dreams from my Father transcends the confines of literary genres. It is an influential book, well worth reading and impossible to characterize. It was first published in 1995, after Obama became the first black president of the Harvard Law Review. Known for his brilliant speech at the Democratic National Convention, Obama's memoir typically goes unnoticed. The arc of Obama's story sweeps countries, from Indonesia to Africa, from Hawaii to Kisumu. This unique autobiography however, is much more. His dedication to community organizing in Chicago compliments his dedication to self-evaluation. Obama constantly seeks to expand his identity and perspective, pulling from his multi-cultural heritage. He is an acute observer, a resourceful analyst, and an outstandingly eloquent author. Obama argues with himself on almost every page. He gets you to agree with him then presents a counter-narrative that seems just as convincing. He powerfully dismisses stereotypes only to show how much we are all caught between messy contradictions. Indeed, the US is a nation of displaced immigrants and migrants and their children, who seek authenticity. Dreams from my Father is full of truths, which at times like these may feel refreshing. I strongly encourage the questioning reader to give this book a shot.  <br /> <br />

B000005RS0|5.0|The folks at Capitol/EMI did absolutely EVERYTHING right (even the fade-outs on the bonus tracks), with this stunning re-issue of Tina's classic 1984 comeback album, \\"Private Dancer.\\"  Clocking in at 77:57, with original and new pictures, lyrics, and above all, newly remastered sound, it's as if you're hearing these great songs for the first time all over again.  Not only a superb album, this sets a standard of excellence for re-issued and remastered classics that all others should learn from, follow and be judged by.  First-class all the way!<br /><br />Not only that, if you are a true Tina fan, the bonus tracks are worth the price of the CD alone.  Previously unavailable on CD, 4 of these bonus tracks were 45 rpm single B-sides, and they are 4 of the very best.  \\"I Wrote A Letter,\\" and \\"Don't Rush The Good Things\\" rock, while \\"Rock and Roll Widow\\" is silky soul that could easily have been on \\"Private Dancer.\\"  The best of the four, though, \\"When I Was Young,\\" is one of Tina's finest performances on ANY disc, especially her primal wailing of the title at the end.  Raw, pure and fine.  The CD ends with three more generous extended mixes of \\"What's Love Got To Do With It,\\" \\"Better Be Good To Me\\" and \\"I Can't Stand The Rain,\\" all of which play it safe by sticking fairly close to the original versions, but are nonetheless terrific. DON'T miss out on this CD - it remains one of Tina's best (and that's hard to improve on), but in this case - is even BETTER!
0446605409|5.0|I've read all of DeMille's novels and they are all very enjoyable but this one stands out among the rest.  John Corey is always humorous in his various novels but he is laugh-out-loud funny in this one.  I've often chuckled to myself at his one liners in other books but I've never seen the people around me roll their eyes at me because I was laughing so hard.  They always ask me what is so funny and I'm forced to tell them, \\"you've gotta read the book.\\" <br /> <br />This book is the best blend of crisis, a layered plot, interesting characters and a strong pace.  Corey can sometimes come off as brash and often rude but ultimately, he is a very likeable protagonist.  DeMille does an excellent job of hiding his intelligence behind a wise-cracking front.  We are also introduced to Beth Penrose who plays the perfect straight man to Corey.  I think she's a better fit for Corey than Kate Mayfield, who DeMille has Corey marry in his later books.  There are just enough elements to this story to keep the reader on their toes but not so much as to lull them into an apathetic boredom.  Very highly recommended.

B0006L16N8|5.0|In an ideal world, all music would have this much style and substance. But it's not an ideal world, it's Coldplay. Coldplay to the rescue. We should all thank them for being students of great music. In an era when most Rock bands are annoying clones of each other, Coldplay has masterfully found a way to stand high above the crowd. It's hard to make music that's truly captivating and that seizes the senses, but \\"X&Y\\" succeeds on so many levels. This album is truly a diamond amongst ordinary jewels.

B0006L16N8|5.0|With much anticipation, I picked up my copy of X & Y almost cowering in it's presence, hoping that it would be as thrilling as all of the other material put out by Coldplay in the past years. I was not disappointed!!<br /><br />There is something about X & Y that makes it very familiar and connectable to fans, yet is not totally typical. The unmistakable trademark presence of Chris Martin's voice and the personal quality to this record are what make it awesome.<br /><br />Songs:<br /><br />Square One - awesome guitar work, and the lyrics are fantabulous. Just about being a person, no matter who status and wanting to have someone validate you, listen to you and understand you.<br /><br />What If - Beautiful piano and vocals. A song about no matter who you are, something bad can always happen in one single second.<br /><br />White Shadows - Different rhythm feel for the band. Song is about feelings and uncertainty.<br /><br />Fix You - Typical Chris Martin, very light and spiritual almost. Song about relationships and trying to fix them.<br /><br />Talk - The Quintessential Coldplay sound. Another song about uncertainty, possibly relationship based.<br /><br />X & Y - Also, very typical Coldplay style so it is the title song. This song is about putting yourself into a relationship, and then it not working out but the longing for it to work.<br /><br />Speed of Sound - First single and most likely the most familiar style to mainstream fans who are not used to Coldplay's various sounds. A juiced up version of \\"Clocks\\" with an emphasis on discovery.<br /><br />A Message - Quiet and somewhat obscure at first. Has a very redemptive quality to it. Possibly based on a hymn called, \\"MY SONG IS LOVE UNKNOWN\\"?<br /><br />Low - A turning point in the album. A song about lonely, closeminded people.<br /><br />The Hardest Part - Much more up-tempo and \\"happy\\". Defintely about breaking up, or leaving a certain relationship or position.<br /><br />Swallowed by the Sea - An outwardly uplifting and positive song almost about getting someone back from losing them.<br /><br />Twisted Logic - A song with a haunting melody about standing up for your own beliefs and feelings, and dreams and hopes and not letting the general populous tell you what you should think.<br /><br />Til Kingdom Come - Chris sounds very different on this song, originally written for Johnny Cash. This is a typical, yet wonderful song about life and love.<br /><br />Truly this is an album about the ordinary person and the feelings, doubts, triumphs, trial and the experiences that they go through.Sea - An outwardly uplifting and positive song almost about getting someone back from losing them. <br /> <br />Twisted Logic - A song with a haunting melody about standing up for your own beliefs and feelings, and dreams and hopes and not letting the general populous tell you what you should think. <br /> <br />Til Kingdom Come - Chris sounds very different on this song, originally written for Johnny Cash. This is a typical, yet wonderful song about life and love. <br /> <br />Truly this is an album about the ordinary person and the feelings, doubts, triumphs, trial and the experiences that they go through. <br />
B0000D96NW|5.0|In 1994, Machine Head made 'Burn My Eyes,' a great (and very original)<br />heavy metal album. But from about that year until now, things went downhill<br />for the band. They still made albums, but almost no one was interested in<br />them. Starting with 'Burning Red,' an album that essentially put a dividing<br />line between fans, the group became nu-metal (or if not nu-metal, than<br />something very close to it) and also came close to copping other bands,<br />like Tool. M.H. risked being one of those bands that put out a strong debut<br />album, then didn't release anything else worthwhile for the rest of their<br />career.<br /><br />2004, however, is a new year, and a new album ('Through the Ashes of the<br />Empires') that might be the best album of their career. If it's not, then<br />it is at least, hands down, the most inspired, brutal, and all around<br />strongest Machine Head album in ten years. Some accuse them of jumping off the sinking nu-metal ship and onto the popular New Wave of American Heavy Metal. That is probably true, but, since the new sound is so awesome, I<br />hardly care. Plus, maybe it wasn't a desperate attempt to stay relevant--maybe Machine Head just got a kick in the butt and decided to go<br />back to their roots.<br /><br />'Through the Ashes of the Empires' is sort of like a cross between new<br />Fear Factory and old school Sepultura, but the new album doesn't sound like every other<br />metal C.D. that is popular right now. There are no typical NWoAHM riffs<br />here, and no acoustic interludes. To add diversity, many of these songs<br />start differently, and some of them are a completely different speed than<br />others. Plus, singer Robert Flynn sometimes lowers his voice and even<br />croons.<br /><br />Highlights include:<br /><br />'Imperium' starts out lightly, with one guitarist playing slow, simple<br />strings in each headphone. After hearing the opening, the listener wonders<br />what kind of album they're in for...but all that changes around the<br />40-second mark, when the power chords make a booming entrance. On top of<br />that, the drummer (Dave McClain) sounds like he's trying to crack his snare<br />drum. The guitars speed up (with the drums hitting at the same time) and<br />the vocals begin around a minute and forty seconds into the song. Part of<br />this song is cleanly sung, part of it is yelled, and there's a really cool<br />part during a pause when you can hear Rob breathing in. Machine gun bass<br />drums end this song.<br />'Bite the Bullet' has a small smattering of drums at the beginning, then<br />Rob snarls like a demon and the guitars turn to heavy, rhythmic riffing.<br />'Left Unfinished' begins with noise from what sounds like a baby's toy or<br />crib. This abruptly ends, however, when Rob belts out like he's been<br />punched in the stomach ('Ew!') Then he launches into a tirade against his<br />mother and father (he was put up for adoption by his real parents). These<br />lyrics are very personal, heartfelt, and show that he's both pissed off and<br />hurt. At one point, he yells 'I'll never forget...parents that brought me<br />this pain.'<br />'Elegy' has a screeching intro (which sounds like pick slides), then the<br />guitars turn to heavy chugging. Rob almost croons again at the beginning<br />(and during the middle, which is soft). After the mid-section, the next<br />verse builds and erupts with a wall of metal.<br />'In the Presence of my Enemies' opens with slow, pounding drums. The<br />guitars on this song lurch so smoothly that they almost groove, and the<br />vocals are almost whispered, at first. A good, ten second guitar solo is<br />included, and near the song's end, the vocals become a capella (even though<br />Rob is barking as furiously as ever).<br />'Vim' has another drum intro, but this one is fast, a bit longer, and it<br />almost sounds like a drum machine. But it's when the guitars begin that I<br />know this might be the best song on the album. This whole song is very<br />fast, with a running beat, deft drumming and blinding guitars. After the<br />middle (which features guitar work that's even faster than usual), there's<br />a speedy, two part solo that keeps up with the pace of the song. Near the<br />end, the listener can really tell how crazy the drum work was during this<br />song.<br />'Descend the Shades of Night' is partially acoustic (both the intro and<br />outro is), with more proper singing.<br /><br />Megadeth are another band that experimented with and commercialized their<br />sound. And, just as Megadeth did in 2004, Machine Head made a triumphant<br />return with a killer C.D. But where do they go from here? Have they come<br />full circle, and reached the pinnacle of their career?<br /><br />I believe both bands are at the top of their game, and have brought their<br />careers full circle, but I also believe that they still have plenty of good<br />material left in them. Granted, this album raises the bar high, but I think<br />if Machine Head keep the sound they have now, and aim their sights high,<br />they will succeed in making another great album.<br /><br />But, even if they don't ever make another C.D. of this quality, that<br />doesn't mean that you can't enjoy 'Through the Ashes of the Empires.' The<br />bottom line is this is great metal and I highly recommend it.er than usual), there's   a speedy, two part solo that keeps up with the pace of the song. Near the   end, the listener can really tell how crazy the drum work was during this   song.   'Descend the Shades of Night' is partially acoustic (both the intro and   outro is), with more proper singing.     Megadeth are another band that experimented with and commercialized their   sound. And, just as Megadeth did in 2004, Machine Head made a triumphant   return with a killer C.D. But where do they go from here? Have they come   full circle, and reached the pinnacle of their career?     I believe both bands are at the top of their game, and have brought their   careers full circle, but I also believe that they still have plenty of good   material left in them. Granted, this album raises the bar high, but I think   if Machine Head keep the sound they have now, and aim their sights high,   they will succeed in making another great album.     But, even if they don't ever make another C.D. of this quality, that   doesn't mean that you can't enjoy 'Through the Ashes of the Empires.' The   bottom line is this is great metal and I highly recommend it.
B00005JKC3|4.0|The Hulk is one of those comic book characters that is so utterly fantastic that any film adaption of him was probably doomed from the start.  To begin with, he's a giant green man.  And when audiences see a giant green man smashing a tank with his bare hands, they generally aren't sure what to make of it.  It's absurd, sure, but let's be honest, all superheroes are absurd. <br /> <br />The Hulk's biggest weakness is, oddly enough, the TV show that made him so popular.  Because it was TV and there weren't great special effects, people tend to think of him as a largish, bodybuilder with marginal superstrength.  Sorry.  The Hulk is a big dog in the world of megamuscles.  And by being truer to the comic than the show, most the audience was confused. <br /> <br />Onto the film.  It's good, but slow.  I've watched it a couple of times, and I can't for the life of me figure out what I would've cut out, but it still does kind of creep along at points.  The performances are all strong, particularly Eric Bana as Bruce Banner.  It could've been a throwaway part, but he does solid work portraying a quiet man with deep psychological scars. <br /> <br />The Hulk himself is an outstanding creation.  If you forget that giant green man part, you'll see just how incredibly realistic he is, and how soulful his virtual performance is.  The action scenes are terrific, especially the gamma dogs:  a fight that is every bit as brutal as it should be.  Unfortunately, the final confrontation and it's resolution could've been clearer.  But if you pay attention, it'll make sense. <br /> <br />Just go in with an open mind or don't go in at all.
B00005JNEW|4.0|Five years after \\"Varsity Blues,\\" another film about West Texas high school football comes with Billy Bob Thornton as Coach Gary Gaines who must lead his team to the championship, no matter what it takes.  Based on the real games and the real people, who participated in the 1988 season, 'Friday Night Lights' is more authentic and often alarmingly realistic than 'Varsity Blues' (which I like), in describing the glory of being the star players, and revealing the reality surrounding them. <br /> <br />Director Peter Berg (The Rock's successful 'The Rundown'), perhaps inevitably, spends most of the films on the life on and out of the field of the high school players -- THE star of the team 'Booobie' (Derek Luke), team leader Mike (Lucas Black), and Charles (Tim McGraw) whose abusive father keeps on telling how he is disappointed with his son.  So far, things are not new.  If you think one of them is too confident, you already know what will happen to him.    <br /> <br />To see the life of Coach Gaines, with good acting from Billy Bob Thornton, is more intersting to me, for his life in the city of Odessa, Texas, could be very intense, nearly life-or-death matter.  The townspeople come to the Coach, and then, quietly tell him that their team must win -- if not directly, with uninvited suggestions.  And as far as the football goes, when they wish something, that something must be realized.  Like winning the State. <br /> <br />[CONVENTIONAL BUT SOLID] Despite the semi-documentray touch of the slightly shaky and grainy photography, the film is made with an orthodox approach.  At first the film has some moments showing the players' doubts about their way of life, or even the way of the football itself (and the community that suppport with enthusiasm), but gradually the heroism takes them over, with the exciting scenes of the bone-crunching games and dedicated football players.  The story is very conventional, but the presentation is solid and well-paced. <br /> <br />Like his previous 'The Rundown,' Peter Berg conducts everything with confidence, and the results are very satisfactory even though you don't particularly like the world of American high school football.  Even if you don't come to like the sports itself, you come to understand the people in this small town where the Friday Night Lights mean everything to them, the glory, the life and all.
B0006A9FKA|4.0|Let's get something straight.  This movie is not a parody, satire, or homage to zombie movies.  Any of those labels undercuts this entertaining film.  Just because a story has a healthy dose of humor that doesn't mean it should be dismissed as merely a comedy send up.  Shaun of the Dead is much more sophisticated that that.  Mostly. <br /> <br />The cleverness of this film is that it understands that zombie movies have been done to death, and that makes them predictable.  But the question is, if we suddenly found ourselves in the middle of one, how long would it take us to notice?  It takes Shaun quite a while, and when he does, he's like any of us.  Scared, confused, and more than a little incompetent, which leads to a lot of comic situations. <br /> <br />But this is not just a comedy.  People die.  Gruesomely.  Shaun experiences real loss.  And the best and worst of people is explored in a way that is often seen in zombie movies but still somehow seems fresh and interesting in this one. <br /> <br />The only weak spot is the end, which is a bit jokey and in my opinion, just a step out of tune with the rest of the film.  But it's still kind of funny, and a small sin.  So enjoy this film.  But please don't dismiss it if it causes you to chuckle now and then.

B000002PB2|3.0|I dusted this effort off recently while transferring a wealth of vinyl to digital. Musically the album, like you would expect from such a talented band, is very good. With a couple guitarslingers like Jeff Watson and the underrated Brad Gillis you expect a lot. The songs are hit and miss though. At times the band shows uncanny pop sensibility with songs such as \\"Don't Tell You Love Me\\" and \\"Young Girl in Love\\" and at other times can't seem to find a good melody such as \\"Play Rough\\" \\"Eddie's comin' out Tonight\\". Knowing the two heavyweights playing guitar makes one expect more from the band, but alas, they could never deliver a solid front to back album. I find it interesting to look back at videos from this era a see that \\"Fitz\\" Gerald and the keyboardist from Prince's \\"1999\\" era band  band both mined the surgeon-in-scrubs look. LOL. The album is worth picking up though, just to get the epic \\"Don't Tell Me...\\" a rocker for the ages. This alone gets it an extra star.
B0006L16N8|5.0|simply stated -  coldplay does it again.  these peices grab my attention and soul.   I had goosebumps within the first 8 seconds of listening to the cd.....  <br /> <br />
B000002B35|3.0|Pulse is a hearty slice of the Water-less Pink Floyd caught live. David Gilmour, released from the so-called shackles of Roger Waters, sets the controls for the heart of the money bag and carries on with the band plus a host of sidemen. The Pink Floyd sound is here albeit minus the desperate Roger Waters vocals, but it's all here. The songs presented here all are played with precision and to great effect, but of course, something's missing. That something is the heart and soul of Pink Floyd, Roger Waters. Gilmour is second to none in emotional melodic guitar wizardry and the rest of the Floyd originals do their parts very well, but the band just doesn't have the exasperated paranoia that Waters gives. I love Floyd, but I only like this Pink Floyd. A better representation of the sound of Pink Floyd is in the hands of Roger Waters' Bleeding Hearts Band. Waters' live DVD is indeed somthing to behold and most assuradly outclasses the Gilmour Floyd. Why? Because Waters holds the key to the Pink Floyd Sound. It's in his bones. Waters can replace Gilmour's position with the likes of Jeff Beck, Snowy White, or Doyle Bramhall, but Gilmour's Floyd has yet to replace the Waters' point of view, lyrics, or vocal stylings. It's too bad for fans that these two (Waters and Gilmour) can't bury the proverbial hatchet and find a common ground. Till then proceed with caution when it comes to Pink FLoyd, but feel safe in testing the Waters.
0440238609|5.0|Here's my take on the four issues that seem to be raised most often with regard to these books - their supposed anti-religious message, the failings of the book #3 and suitability for children. <br /> <br />I seriously do not understand why people say that these books are 'against religion'. The way I see it, they are against a religious establishment that is given extraordinary powers - the same powers as the Catholic establishment actually did have in medieval Europe. The power to burn people for saying the earth goes around the sun, the power to declare a scientific idea a 'heresy', the power to torture to 'cleanse one of evil', and to make you an outlaw if you dare to disagree with any part of the dogma, ... the condemnation of any sensual pleasure as sinful,... the practice of selling 'indulgences' where you could pay money and be forgiven a sin, ... The author condemns ideological totalitarianism - lots of people are very comfortable with ridiculing fundamentalist islamic regimes - how about swallowing a Christian version of Saudi Arabia? <br />    <br />I found the 'message' of the book hopeful - the call to try to make a paradise where we are, and to live our lives so that we'd have some stories to tell when they are over. And the idea that when we die we become part of all sorts of living things again, and there is a joy in it.    <br /> <br />Reading the reviews,I was really surprized to see how many people liked the 1st book best, and the 3rd least. I myself have been telling people to just get through the first one, the 2nd one is much better, and the 3rd one is the greatest - fewer magic tricks, more food for thought. But then, I am not the type to regret not having lengthy descriptions of 'epic battles'... As for not having everying 'spelled out' for you - I view it as the author's leave to give me, the reader, room for interpretation. Go and look at Tolkien's preface to the Lord of the Rings and his distinction between metaphor and allegory...  <br /><br />As for suitability for children, I think kids aren't given enough credit for their ability to judge for themselves and to choose. I myself read Anna Karenina at the age of 8 for the first time and was deeply annoyed when people kept telling me that I 'won't understand anything' . I understood the bits that were relevant and interesting to me at this age, and I enjoyed it - now, at 30, I appreciate other parts of it more, and I am sure that the book will read completely differently when I am 60, - which is not a reason to wait till then to read it. I think that 'His Dark Materials' is, too, a book, that has the potential to grow as you do, and if a child can read, (s)he is old enough to give it a try.
B0006L16N8|2.0|X&Y finds Coldplay reworking their sound, adding sonic filler akin to their idols, Kraftwerk, Brian Eno, Depeche Mode, etc. I hesitate to include Depeche Mode in that list since, save for lead single Speed of Sound, the new album is just a collection of epic songs with no concrete message or purpose, odes to either the majesty or mediocrity of the universe, I can't tell; think Daylight, A Whisper, or Politik without any argument, times ten; there's just no charisma to the album, nothing that would make me play it aside of rainy days or huddling miserably in some odd corner, and certainly nothing even remotely radio-friendly like Depeche Mode. I'm convinced that those fans who listen to this album, who don't worship Radiohead and odd odes to quiet as artistic genius, will yearn badly for the simple, plaintive Coldplay of their past albums. Nothing on this album nearly matches the yearning or contrition of Trouble, Shiver, Sparks, The Scientist, Clocks, Green Eyes, Warning Sign, A Rush of Blood to the Head, Amsterdam, I Ran Away, Crests of Waves, or Moses. <br /> <br />Played live on the MTV live leak show, song A Message showed some promise, but on the album, it and What If, Fix You, and Low ring hollow. Excepting the Johnny Cash folk song 'Til Kingdom Come, which struggles on its own continuing Parachutes' waiting, the other songs all come across as modern day Pink Floyd covers. Read the lyrics to album closer tracks 10, 11 and 12; there's no punch to the gut, or to the face. <br /> <br />Word is that Coldplay dropped everything and started anew while making this album, ala Oasis on Definitely Maybe. Whether or not this contributed to the lyrics being so empty, I don't know, but without the want or misery of their better work, Coldplay is not the same. Contentment suits them badly.

B0000CDLA7|4.0|It seems a lot of people have forgotten what \\"Progressive\\" really means.  Here I go referencing Webster's: \\"1. moving forward in space; advancing. 2. increasing by successive stages. 3. a progress toward something better...\\"  Progressive music is driven by the notion that music isn't stagnant.  It's made up of passionate people who really want to explore and create new music, not just print lyrics up with some variations on the same old same old.<br /><br />From interviews I've read of Dream Theater, they say that Train of Thought was just something they wanted to do.  They all have a fascination with metal music, and they used this album to explore that side of their music.  And they did a damn good job!  Take the heavier moments in their music and expand them to a full-length album, just as advanced, just as impressive, and you've got a good idea of what TOT is like.<br /><br />If you're offended by the idea that Dream Theater likes metal or really any genre of music besides Awake, Images&Words, et al, then why are you listening to progressive metal in the first place?<br /><br />\\"Stream of Consciousness,\\" an 11-minute instrumental, is my favorite track on the album.  It is flawlessly executed, and I can't get enough of it.  Also noteworthy are the drums on \\"Honor Thy Father.\\"  Mike Portnoy will blow you away on this album.  The general idea of the whole album is that these guys are incredible musicians, who are more than capable of making fantastic albums, in virtually any musical realm they would like to.<br /><br />Perhaps try comparing this album to some of the other \\"straight-up metal\\" choices out there.  This album over St. Anger?  Maybe we'd be giving out 31-star ratings, as opposed to 2-star ratings.

B0006L16N8|5.0|I've been a Coldplay fan since 2000, and it amazes me how popular they've become in the past 5 years.  Their older work is very broken-down, mostly acoustic.  I was honestly a little disappointed with A Rush of Blood to the Head because it seemed too polished, too overworked.  This album, in some regards, travels in the same direction, but the result with this one is much more hit than miss.<br /><br />The tracks are no longer depressing vocals layered over an acoustic guitar and light drums (although I loved that sound).  X&Y features lush keyboards, more up-front basslines, and even a few drumloops running in the background.  I'm honestly surprised that this approach works so well for Coldplay.<br /><br />The music is beautiful.  You feel like you're staring across an open sky and some sort of musical spectrum.  These songs feel like they have depth to them, but it's not overdone.  There's a feeling of intelligence and profundity, but it isn't snobbish or conceited or arrogant.  You could even call this music humble.  But that's a very abstract way to review a CD.<br /><br />The thing that impresses me about this CD, which is true of all of Coldplay's CDs, is that none of the songs particularly stand out, but the CD doesn't get boring or laborious to listen to.  Coldplay fans should like this CD if they try not to let the new musical elements bother them.  Anyone else who perhaps has heard \\"Speed of Sound\\" on the radio will definitely want to give the rest of this CD a chance.<br /><br />This is still Coldplay, but I'm glad they've taken some steps to keep from regurgitating the same material year after year.  X&Y receives 5 stars from me and my highest regards.

B0007XT87G|5.0|I love Porcupine Tree, and was incredibly excited for this next release.  And honestly, it is even better than I had anticipated.<br /><br />It is as if somewhere along the lines they decided to take all of my favorite elements in their music, then pile them together and follow it to its most musically advanced point.  Then, as if things weren't good enough, they centered it around a plotline (yes, this is a concept album, but luckily, the concept isn't in-your-face as in an Ayreon CD or something).  And just to make this album a gift straight to me, they've borrowed Opeth's frontman!  I have driven my friends insane by pointing out all of Mikael Akerfeldt's vocals and guitar solos.<br /><br />But enough about me, this album is something you'll want to listen to over and over again.  You'll hear something new each time you listen to it.  I've heard Steven Wilson talk about the contrast between horizontal and vertical complexity in his albums, and this album embodies both to the nth degree.<br /><br />In a quick rundown of the songs: the title track is this album's \\"Blackest Eyes\\"... \\"Deadwing\\" sets the mood of the album perfectly, and is very straightforward, and features a phenomenal Adrian Belew (King Crimson) guitar solo.<br /><br />\\"Shallow\\" was a great single.  It is very metal-y and obviously influenced by Wilson's work with Opeth.  Fans of PT's mellower side won't be too impressed, but it's a great song nonetheless.<br /><br />\\"Lazarus\\", the single for Germany, is my least favorite song.  It is very mellow, reminding me of \\"Trains\\" and PT's other nonedescript songs.<br /><br />\\"Halo\\" is a heavier song, a less PT-esque song, but that is in a sense MORE PT-esque, because it embodies Steven Wilson's obsession with exploring new genres of music.  The guitars in this song are fabulous.<br /><br />\\"Arriving Somewhere but not here\\" is my favorite song, hands down.  Akerfeldt is on back-up vocals, and the two voices blend beautifully.  This 12-minute opus is mostly mellow, but builds into one of the heaviest moments on the album, which melts into one of the most beautiful guitar solos I've ever hear (Akerfeldt once again).<br /><br />\\"Mellotron Scratch\\" is beautiful.  You can feel your soul drop out of your chest.  The most notable moment is towards the end when the 3/4 instrumental is overtaken by 4/4 complex vocals, and then the instruments fade to this gorgeous a capella ending.  I've replayed this ending dozens of times and it is so musically advanced even I can hardly understand it.<br /><br />\\"Open Car\\" is a good song, but nothing spectacular.  Classic PT.<br /><br />\\"Start of Something Beautiful\\" is my 2nd favorite song.  It has pounding guitars, but it isn't metal at all, really.  The melody will stay with you, but it isn't really catchy.  You thought this was the start of something beautiful, well think again...<br /><br />\\"Glass Arm Shattering\\" perfectly completes the album.  It's a mellower song, but it isn't boring at all.  The second the song ends you want to start the album over again.<br /><br />This really is a fabulous album.  I'm starting to sound like I need a thesaurus, so I'll wrap this up.  Really, I almost cried when they kept pushing back the release date on this, but it was worth every second of the wait.us is mostly mellow, but builds into one of the heaviest moments on the album, which melts into one of the most beautiful guitar solos I've ever hear (Akerfeldt once again). <br /> <br />\\"Mellotron Scratch\\" is beautiful. This is a mess of dub, reggae, rock and roll, jazz, and rap, and it's your job to sift through it.  Find it on vinyl, throw on one side, grab a cold Koka Kola and just listen to the damn thing.  Don't skip anything, just listen to 6 songs at a time, you will soon understand why this is great.  You won't love everything, but I guarantee there's something here you will love.

B0006L16N8|5.0|While a band's later albums are rarely appreciated as much as their earlier work by the public at large, true fans will tell you that the maturity that comes with age adds depth and nuance to an album (think Pearl Jam and \\"No Code\\" or U2 and \\"Beautiful Day\\").  These albums are overlooked by most people because they aren't interested in an evolving sound; they want more of \\"Alive\\" or \\"Where the Streets Have No name\\".  Hopefully that won't be the case with \\"X & Y\\" as Coldplay has brought a tremendous amount of confidence and power to this album.  While remaining true to their past, they have developed an album which is more varied musically and more sophisticated lyrically. <br /> <br />Fitting for an album whose title plays on X and Y chromosomes, the songs can be (with a few exceptions) divided up into two general themes, although they aren't arranged in any particular order.  Roughly half deal with personal growth, finding one's way and place in the world, while the others deal with finding one's place in a relationship.  In many ways they form different sides of the same coin, the internal and external and they work quite well in forming a cohesive album. <br /> <br />The album starts of with a song that will sound familiar to most fans; \\"Square One\\" is a simple, quiet song about coming to grips with success and determining what's really important in life.  Next is \\"What If\\", another relatively slow number that addresses the core question of committing to a relationship, namely what if things don't work out, what if the affection isn't reciprocated. <br /> <br />The pace changes with the amazing \\"White Shadows\\", a departure of sorts with a strongly electric guitar melody that is simply haunting.  On top of this the lyrics show a more sophisticated, enigmatic approach than previous albums.  While open to interpretation the core message is about finding one's place in the grand scheme of things as summed up in the lines \\"You're part of the human race/All of the stars and outer space/Part of the system again\\".  \\"Fix You\\" is a U2-esque number, particularly the concluding chorus, that on the surface seems to be about friendship, but I think it is informed at least in part by vocalist Chris Martin recently becoming a father.  Next is \\"Talk\\" which features a great tag line, and seems to tie together the two themes as it deals with improving relationships by improving oneself. <br /> <br />The title track, \\"X & Y\\" is a prequel of sorts to \\"What If\\" that talks about making yourself available in a relationship, of taking the chance it might not work out, that you might get hurt.  \\"Speed of Sound\\" is the first single and is along with \\"White Shadows\\" my favorite track on the album.  The lyrics are particularly beautiful and deal with looking past our modern world to find real meaning.  Following is \\"A Message\\" which is a solid track but doesn't really jump out; another relationship song that deals with staking a place for yourself while still making room for someone else.  \\"Low\\" is a fun, almost satirical song that features some nifty use of bells by the drummer and pokes fun at those who expect life to come easy.  Not a typical Coldplay song, but one that really shows how their considerations are expanding.  <br /> <br />\\"The Hardest Part\\" and \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\" are two of the more enigmatic tracks.  The former deals generally with growing up, letting go, but I sense there's more to it than that.  The latter feels more like poetry and is equally open to interpretation.  Again, the open-endedness shows real development in Martin's song writing and while it may frustrate some, it is something that should be really be embraced. <br /> <br />Rounding out \\"X & Y\\" are two great songs; first is \\"Twisted Logic\\" which, while not overtly political nonetheless encourages questioning, probing, understanding and fighting for what you believe.  A great song not least because it makes its point without ramming it down the listener's throat.  Last is the \\"hidden track\\" \\"Til Kingdom Come\\"; originally written for a Johnny Cash project, it sounds every bit like something he would have done.  While a departure from anything else you've heard Coldplay do, and not really in keeping with the album, it's still an amazing song about holding out hope in a situation that may be hopeless. <br /> <br />Featuring a larger variety of guitar and drum sounds, more developed song writing and longer tracks, \\"X & Y\\" may not appeal to those who are looking for more of the same from Coldplay.  However, if you are looking for an album that represents a band in the full flush of their abilities, definitely check this one out, I guarantee it won't disappoint. <br /> <br />Jake Mohlman <br />

This one blew them all away.<br /><br />Dream Theater isn't my favorite band, but I'd consider them the best band musically in my collection, which is almost entirely prog anyway.  Octavarium sounds a lot like Train of Thought, which may be bad news for people.  It definitely isn't straight-up metal, like some people considered TOT to be, but it has much more of a TOT sound than, say, Images & Words.  The opening track, Root of all Evil, even has a section of \\"I can feel your body breaking...\\" to almost identically the same lyrics and chord structure as in \\"This Dying Soul\\"<br /><br />...of course who hasn't known a prog band to reference their own material?<br /><br />The CD's ultimate triumph is its title track.  It is a whopping 24 minute-long opus.  And this isn't a 10-minute song followed by a long period of silence and then a bonus track.  This is 24 unbroken minutes of truly fantastic music.<br /><br />Hardcore DT fans will think this is a good \\"next link in the chain.\\"<br /><br />Casual DT fans, and any prog fans will think this is incredibly good.<br /><br />And any musician should be blown away.<br /><br />It's nothing earth-shattering, but it's as good as it possibly could be.  3 cheers and five stars for LaBrie, Petrucci, Portnoy, Myung, and Ruddess!

It is really impossible to describe.  and anyone giving this album bad reviews because Shadows isn't screaming is just ignorant, he had surgery on his vocal chords and he can't!!  Besides i think that lack of screaming seperates the band from all the \\"new metal\\" garbage out right now.

B00005NTNM|3.0|In the first movie in this series, \\"Dirty Harry,\\" Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) hunted a serial killer.  In the second movie Detective Callahan went after a group of vigilante cops.  To expand the scope of those deserving of Harry's attentions, this movie adds domestic terrorists, who really are little more than glorified kidnappers and thieves.<br /><br />Clint Eastwood had fully established Harry Callahan's role by this third movie, so most viewers knew what they were getting.  However, near the beginning of the movie several vignettes are offered to show Harry Callahan in all his stylistic glory.  We see Harry kick a man who appears to be having a heart attack, admonishing him to \\"get up,\\" to the chagrin of bystanders.  We see Harry deal directly and violently with an armed group of robbers by giving them a car when they requested it.  We also see Harry try to make new detective candidates understand the real world while being typically politically incorrect.<br /><br />While Clint Eastwood is reminding fans of Dirty Harry what kind of person he is, there is a group of people who initially appear to be after some sort of \\"power to the people,\\" but are in reality being led by Bobby Maxwell to do a bit of old-fashioned murder and mayhem, with the goal being large quantities of money.<br /><br />Eventually the supposed terrorists and Dirty Harry must intersect, and that intersection is provided by an encounter between the criminals and Inspector Frank DiGiorgio (John Mitchum), Harry's most recent partner.  DiGiorgio and his new partner encounter the robbers at a warehouse containing arms, where they have already killed one man.  When the robbers critically injure DiGiorgio we know that Harry will track them down and bring them to his own unique style of justice.<br /><br />The movie drags a little while Harry is trying to locate the crooks.  During this time we are treated to Harry's own cold opinion of bumbling politicians and what might be Harry's opinion of women.  One scene to watch for is when his new partner, Inspector Kate Moore (Tyne Daly), stands behinds a LAWS rocket as it is being prepared for test firing.<br /><br />The movie speeds up again when the crooks kidnap the Mayor (John Crawford) and Harry finally determines they are on Alcatraz Island.  Callahan and Moore head out to bring the bad guys to justice and to rescue the Mayor, with the action remaining constant to the end.<br /><br />The interactions between Harry and Kate are quite interesting.  Harry has no respect for Kate initially, not because she is a woman, but because she has no experience in the field.  The movie goes out of its way to explain that Harry would treat anyone with Kate's level of experience the same way, male or female.  However, Harry begrudgingly begins to accept Kate as a partner, and by the end of the movie Harry has developed a greater respect for Kate than for the Mayor and all the other politicians in this movie.  The end scene firmly establishing that respect and is one of the rare emotionally moving scenes in the Dirty Harry series.<br /><br />I have always considered the Dirty Harry movies to be a comparison of how we sometimes perceive criminals are treated versus the way we would like to see them treated, especially considering the violence criminals perpetrate on others.  Of course, such behavior falls into the category of fanciful thought, because Harry's actions often border on being illegal, and in real life it is hard to constrain such violence to the criminals.  Still, these movies can be enjoyable to watch.<br /><br />This particular movie is dated and the pacing is slow in places.  This movie is well below the level of the original, and is a bit weaker than the second movie.  However, it remains a Dirty Harry movie, and they can be addictive.<br /><br />Several scenes in this movie are humorous or unbelievable.  When Harry leaves a government building through a metal detector he does not set it off.  When DiGiorgioand his partner approach the warehouse being robbed by the terrorists, why did DiGiorgio continue to proceed once he knew how many people were involved?  Then his partner stands in front of the crooks speeding vehicle as it bears down on him during their escape.  The Mayor's driver should have turned the limousine the opposite direction from the way he turned, and simultaneously called for help, instead of turning the way he did.  However, these implausibilities help set up the confrontation between Harry and the crooks.  Could the plotting have been more believable?  Probably, but that would have required more care in development of the plot, and apparently speed was more important than quality in this movie.hy did DiGiorgio continue to proceed once he knew how many people were involved?  Then his partner stands in front of the crooks speeding vehicle as it bears down on him during their escape.  The Mayor's driver should have turned the limousine the opposite direction from the way he turned, and simultaneously called for help, instead of turning the way he did.  However, these implausibilities help set up the confrontation between Harry and the crooks.  Could the plotting have been more believable?  Probably, but that would have required more care in development of the plot, and apparently speed was more important than quality in this movie.
