B0006L16N8|3.0|X&Y is Coldplay's long awaited followup to their modern masterpiece A Rush of Blood to the Head. The moodiness of that album is on full display here as the mood of X&Y bounces between uplifting and somber throughout, sometimes during the same song. However, while their previous albums contained great tracks with memorable hooks, most notably \\"Trouble\\", \\"Clocks\\", and \\"In My Place\\", this album is inconsistent. When it's good, it's very good. When it's not, it borders on boring.<br /><br />Upon listening to this album, there appears to be more emphasis on Jon Buckland's riffs than their previous efforts. \\"Square One\\", \\"Talk\\", \\"White Shadows\\" are all great tracks driven by his guitar work and Chris Martin's vocals. Also worth noting is that Martin's piano lines aren't as memorable as in the past with only the hit single \\"Speed Of Sound\\" containing a good hook. Strings and organ are very prevalent here and work very well on \\"What If\\" and the gorgeous track \\"Fix You.\\" Other great tracks here include the catchy \\"Hardest Part\\", which sounds like the logical choice for their next single, and the majestic \\"A Message.\\" The rest of the songs are noticeably weaker as \\"Low\\" and the hidden track \\"Til Kingdom Come\\" are decent at best while \\"Swallowed in the Sea\\", \\"Twisted Logic\\", and the title track are mediocre, something you couldn't say about any of the songs on their first two albums. All told, fans of their first two albums will like X&Y but also may be hitting the skip button on some tracks, particularly those on the second half.
1573223026|4.0|In A Long Way Down, Nick Hornby writes a life-affirming novel without being life-affirming.  On New Year's Eve, four people decide independently to jump off the same building at the same time.  They soon discover that this isn't as great a coincidence as it seems because the building (Toppers' House) is notorious for attracting suicides and New Year's Eve (along with Valentine's Day) is one of the most popular nights on which to do it. <br /> <br />They all have different reasons for wanting to do themselves in.  Maureen is burdened with a teenage son who has always been in a vegetative state.  Martin - the \\"British Regis\\" - was publicly disgraced and imprisoned.  JJ is an American musician who has just lost his band and his girlfriend.  Jess is...well, too troubled to explain. <br /> <br />Once they all find themselves together, they find suicide is something that is hard to do with other people watching.  Instead, they go on a quest to find Jess's ex-boyfriend.  It gives them something to do other than kill themselves.  That's what they end up doing for each other - creating things to do other than kill themselves. <br /> <br />In the hands of a lesser writer, this could have been sappy and predictable, but Hornby writes a funny book about suicide.  Part of the problem is that, after they decide not to commit suicide, that can't think of why.  They have had no revelations.  They don't feel better about life.  They don't even LIKE each other. <br /> <br />What gives the book real forward momentum is that it is narrated in the first person by each of the four characters.  Hornby creates a distinct voice for each and alternates chapters, giving them all their say.  Things start out weird in this book and get progressively weirder, but Hornby manages to create a convincing case for toughing things out without resorting to contrived happy endings.   <br />
B000002KXV|5.0|\\"Well by '76 we'll be a.o.k\\" sings Donald Fagen on The Nightfly's opening track  I.G.Y. (International Geophysical Year). Adopting the persona of a wide eyed, optomistic adolescent in 1950's America, Fagen's beautiful lyric takes on an almost unbearable poignancy given that it was written around 1982 when Fagen (and the rest of us) knew that by '76 things definitely were not a.o.k. Still, to an upbeat yet achingly sad melody, the song's protagonist fills his heart with hope for the future where new technologies help alleviate the sufferings of mankind. \\"A Just Machine to make big decisions/Programmed by fellas with compassion and vision\\" Fagen sings, before promising \\"What a beautiful world this will be/What a glorious time to be free\\". There really is, in my opinion, no other musician around either then or now who has the depth and lightness of touch to match Fagen. The Nightfly is probably the zenith of Donald Fagen's recording career, and although a third solo studio album is planned for 2005, I doubt whether he can get close to the beauty of The Nightfly. And if he can't, no-one else stands a chance.

B0009A1AS2|4.0|A complete lack of an official review that does this album true justice has led me to take matters into my own hands. I agree with many of the other independent reviewers on this page, but there are a few other things that bear mentioning. <br /> <br />First off, the review on Allmusic is completely wrong. I don't exactly see how arena-rock-styled balladry can be mistaken for a 'post-hardcore edge', but hey. Secondly, this record is definitely not a good place to start if you're just getting into Dream Theater. I'd recommend the first album of theirs I ever heard, 'Awake', if you're looking for that. Thirdly, though the band's technical abilities are still undeniably incredible, 'Octavarium' doesn't really astound you with its craft and musicianship like DT's earlier stuff, mainly because (as it's already been said in at least one review) John Petrucci never allows himself much of a solo. <br /> <br />HOWEVER, there are plenty of awesome things to be found here. James LaBrie's voice sounds outstanding, for one thing; he has added quite a bit more depth and dimensions to his vocal style, which is a welcome surprise. Production quality is also high, and a whole range of new sounds have been incorporated into the mix, allowing for atmosphere and intrigue. The songs themselves are uniformly strong. Opener 'The Root of All Evil' seizes the listener for eight unrelenting minutes, twisting and turning with untamed rhythmic and melodic changes. 'Panic Attack' has a similar, slightly harder effect. 'Sacrificed Sons' is one of the first 'anti-Iraq' songs that has managed to affect me; it is a cunning track indeed, what with the eerie soundclips talking of 'terrorism' resounding in its first few moments. Perhaps most significant is the 24-minute title track, smartly placed at the end of the record. It is broken up into five 'movements', and each one hyperactively flickers through the styles of basically every band that's ever influenced Dream Theater. The song never loses itsfocus, which in itself is quite an achievement, considering it is nearly four times the length of the shortest song on 'Octavarium'. <br /> <br />So, my main complaints are: <br />1) that there are some dreadfully choppy moments here - specifically, the nonexistent transition between the snarling first song and the delicate balladry of the next, \\"The Answer Lies Within\\", <br /> <br />2) there are some truly icky lyrics in some of these songs - \\"The Answer Lies Within\\" would be about four times better if it didn't insist upon lapsing into clich, <br /> <br />and <br /> <br />3) Kevin Moore isn't back yet, and Jordan Rudess has a tendency to 'steal the show' from his bandmates here. <br /> <br />But still, DT have been together for 16 years, and they've really maintained their consistency throughout most of that time. To hear good progressive music in 2005 is always a delight for yours truly, and 'Octavarium' definitely delivers in that respect.

Trace them back to their 3 song EP \\"Brothers & Sisters,\\" and you can hear the greatness waiting to emerge.  However, on their new album \\"X&Y,\\" they truly come up short. <br /> <br />I'm not sure what their intentions were, but this album just doesn't seem to have the heart of the first two; it just has this forced and manufactured feel.  All apologies to the Coldplay fanatics out there, but you cannot honestly say this is the same band that we heard on \\"Parachutes\\" and \\"A Rush.\\"  You can't say they've evolved either, because with evolution there is progress - there is none made here. <br /> <br />Musically, I'm baffled.  Lyrically, disappointed.  Overall it just seems canned, redundant, and empty.  No heart-pounding piano or guitar, no words that drive to the soul.  The lyrics seem so stale, in fact, that I began to get bored with the entire thing halfway through.  I heard a lot of the same words and phrases being used multiple times, which is fine if they're woven together in a clever way, but that's not the case.  Ultimately, Coldplay turned in their most unimpressive work, yet will likely garner their most impressive sales.  Maybe that was the plan all along... <br /> <br />There is, however, one bright spot to this grim story:  the unnumbered track, \\"Kingdom Come,\\" is brilliant.  Sadly, this is the only glimpse we get of an honest song.

0385659806|4.0|When I first picked up the book The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time I was expecting a novel involving some suburban wife and her affair. I was pleasantly surprised when there was hardly a mention of a middle aged housewife and her troubles and tribulations. Instead I got a wonderfully written novel about the world of an autistic boy named Christopher Boone. Though this book has the basis of a coming-of-age story, it is told in a refreshing new set of eyes where the boy is not miserable and locked away but simply different. I personally am tired of the underdog story laden down with a heavy coat of depression so this was a cheery alternative with the same idea all the while though making me think about my own logic. I highly recommend this novel if your in the mood for a nice, uplifting paperback with a bit of a twist.
B000000OAA|5.0|A big turning point came for Queen with the release of Sheer Heart Attack, eventually leading them to superstardom with the follow up to this effort with A Night At The Opera. A more sophisticated approach compared to the 2 previous albums(both great by the way), Sheer Heart Attack works so well in so many aspects. The musicality to begin with reaches a new level on this album, with the band finding numerous diverse songs ranging from tongue and cheek pop joy, to short metal powerhouses, to 2 part lyrical choir-like melodies.<br /><br />An achievement that deserves enormous acclaim but will never get the full on respect it deserves, Sheer Heart Attack balances the songwriting differentials of the 4 members of Queen so well. As always, Queen finds a way to begin the album with a most intriguing tune, in this case coming from the energetic fiesta of Brighton Rock. Brian May seems to simply be the king of writing the perfect album opener, as he has done so on several other albums with the likes of songs such as Keep Yourself Alive, Father To Son, We Will Rock You and Tie Your Mother Down respectively. The insatiable, glorious melody of Killer Queen makes for some outstanding listening, with Freddie shining on lyrical deliveries, almost sounding as if he's obsessed with the song itself. Roger Taylor shows that he continues to improve his songwriting skills, this time unleashing onto us Tenement Funster, a great rocker indeed. Very similar to I'm In Love With My Car, Taylor offers exceptional drums to go along with the raspy lyrical delivery. Flick Of The Wrist has an incredible piano introduction, breaking into another rocker, with dark lyrical passion to begin the song. The chorus has a sing-a-long feel to it, accompanied by classic guitar riffs from Brian May. Lily Of The Valley has a deep emotional aspect to it, with Freddie Mercury singing in his most melodic tone of voice in this superb ballad. Now I'm Here is quite simply an ultimate rock classic, featuring a smashing introduction into a fiery rock track. In The Lap Of The Gods is a beautiful song, with background harmonies worked so effectively with tremendous production. It is mind boggling to think that Queen were able to produce the kind of work they did in the 70s without the use of synthesizer machinery. Stone Cold Crazy follows this up nicely, forcing down speedy guitar riffs into your ears with Mercury at top speed on the lyrics. A fast action metal song with an awesome chorus and a very smooth guitar solo coming in about 40 seconds through the song. Dear Friends, a rather simple song, short and well executed. Misfire sees John Deacon take his shots as a songwriter, contributing a rather effective pop song, however falling short when looked upon against the track listing. Bring Back That Leroy Brown was most likely an experimental song, working very well, and branching out on A Night At The Opera, maybe influencing Mercury to write songs like Seaside Rendezvous and Lazing On A Sunday Afternoon. The chorus is catchy and repetitive. She Makes Me, has a very smooth electric guitar strum, but falls short lyrically. Nevertheless, finds its place amongst the group of songs. In The Lap Of The Gods...Revisted has a more balladic feel to it at the beginning than the original, and is a completely different song. However, offers rock phases throughout the second half, backed up very nicely by the ensemble singing. The remix of Stone Cold Crazy doesn't offer the listener enough of a variation.<br /><br />Overall, although I'm writing this review after listening to the album only three times, I would be truthful to say this is my favourite Queen album. A great deal of diversity, complexity and balance in the album makes it an instant success, offering Queen fans with a piece of all the styles(all original) that made this group sensational. On top of this album, I highly recommend Queen's other 70s works, specifically Queen I and II, A Night At The Opera and A Day At The Races. I've heard good things about News Of The World and Jazz but don't own them myself. I can't understand why their classic albums don't receive classic treatment. Well, I guess it's understandable. They're Queen.hings about News Of The World and Jazz but don't own them myself. I can't understand why their classic albums don't receive classic treatment. Well, I guess it's understandable. They're Queen.

B0006L16N8|3.0|I'd hate to think that, if the news reports are right, this is the album that Capitol Records -- the home of The Beatles, the classic Beach Boys, Sinatra in his Nelson Riddle days, Dean Martin, Louis Prima, Esquerita, the early Pink Floyd, Nancy Wilson, Duran Duran and the comeback-era Tina Turner -- is relying on to stay financially afloat. What does that say about the current state of pop music?  Look -- this is not a slam of Coldplay. The guys are good for what they are: a young group of musicians who play inoffensive, dreamy, cleanly produced pop music clearly geared for a mass market in a conservative time in our history. But what's the main difference between this act and the ones mentioned above? All the artists mentioned above were originals. Originals.  What I hear here is a group oft compared to the tamest elements of U2 (and Brian Eno contributes to the ninth track, \\"Low\\"), but with a singer who sounds like Sting more often than he does Bono. I hear a couple of faster-tempo tracks that would probably have been in medium rotation on a mid-'80s \\"alternative\\" radio station. I also hear elements of later, more ethereal Beatles, and even a touch of Floyd. But I don't hear a single thing that says \\"original.\\" It's a well-crafted disc, but I hear much more craft than passion. Pretty much it's what I heard from them in the past as well. And I don't hear much that qualifies them as rock.  I don't hear any saviors here. All I hear is a pleasant quartet that made a pleasant album and will make a pretty penny for its record label for maybe another album or two, then be discarded when the sheep turn to other pastures. Maybe the folks at Capitol should start trying to find an act that's (here's that word again) original.

B00005ASHM|5.0|Of course you don't understand Pet Sounds, Turtleman. You identified more with the buzz of the circular saw you attempted to review. Pet Sounds is not the buzz of a circular saw.<br /><br />If you were blown away the first time you heard the tapestry of harmonies on \\"Wouldn't It Be Nice\\", \\"God Only Knows\\", and \\"Sloop John B\\" - you are gonna love Pet Sounds.<br /><br />It holds up very well for a 1966 rock & roll album. The songs are extremely well written, the arrangements are spotless, the Beach Boys have never sung better, and the production isn't hampered by the cliche fuzztone, sitar, and feedback excesses that would mire so many of their contemporaries deep in the psychedelic '60s.<br /><br />As for The Beatles vs The Beach Boys battle . . . None of The Beach Boys had the razor edge of John Lennon's vocals . . . but, even at their best (\\"Because\\" or \\"Sun King\\") the Beatles could never quite match the harmony arrangements of Brian Wilson.<br /><br />What is interesting is that it took Lennon, McCartney, and George Martin's combined efforts to accomplish in the studio what Brian Wilson was creating as writer, arranger, and producer.<br /><br />No, forty years doesn't seem to have diminished the incredible accomplishments of either band. The Beatles will always be the standard by which every band who follows is measured - and Beach Boys' music will always be to summer what Christmas carols are to winter.
0553213105|5.0|It is not for nothing that this book is labelled as a classic.  Austen is the greatest writer of this type of fiction and this is her crowning glory.<br /><br />Coming from the world of high society in England of the late 18th Century, Austen lived the life she wrote about.  Having refused a compromise proposal of marriage herself, and lived out her life as a spinster, she was only too aware of the realities of the marriage game.<br /><br />Women in this society were marketable product, and both men and women were stratified by their annual income.  A titled person or someone from a noble family might improve flagging fortunes by marrying untitled money, but in general money married money and titles married titles.<br /><br />Into this delicate balance Austen throws her heroine - Eliza Bennett.  In any \\"proper\\" romance novel it should be the passionless and tame courtship of her older sister Jane to the wealthy Bingley and his bitchy sisters that should form the core of the story.<br /><br />Eliza opens the novel by turning down a proposal from an embarrasing, boring, unhandsome relative who has a modest income as a churchman.  To society this would have been a proper match for Eliza and it is unthinkable that she should refuse it.<br /><br />But Austen opts to sell a true fairytale and in doing so established a modus operandi for much modern fiction.  Eliza and Darcy begin by getting off on the wrong foot.  The remainder of the novel is an Anabasis from the confused territory of mistaken assumptions and impressions to an epiphany of understanding and mutual respect.<br /><br />On either side of this love story are the very proper courtship of Jane and Bingley on one hand, and the dreadful elopement of a younger sister with a complete cad on the other.<br /><br />The prize at the end is not just Darcy, but his wonderful estate of Pemberly, thoroughly described in the novel.  The reward for the characters is access to this estate (invitations to balls, summers holidays etc) and the virtuous are awarded open access while those who behaved badly are excluded and sent to parts of England furthest from Pemberly.<br /><br />The beauty of this story lies in the wit of conversation and letter.  The cutting comments, the razor sharp assesments of character.  The constant referral to income, house size, education and marriage prospects.  It is here that Austen really excels, and to appreciate just how funny the novel is requires the attention of the reader to what is being said.  Careful attention to the language carries a huge reward and I frequenly found myself collapsing in laughter while reading this book.<br /><br />I am not a fan of romance or of regency fiction, but I am a fan of this book.

B00005BL2A|5.0|From the initial release of \\"Speak & Spell\\" I have been a devoted fan of the Mode. Without going on too much, just know that I have everything they have ever released domestically on vinyl, CD and video. As a former club DJ in the 80's, I wore them out! As an avid music fan they have never disappointed. Even so, I don't dish out 5-stars very freely.    The strength of Depeche is their ability to communicate musically something new and fresh with each release, while maintaining a theme. Each album offers up a new concept with continuity from track to track. They reinvent themselves without losing that personalized thread of creativity that makes them so darn cool. Very few artists are able to pull this off.     Nonetheless, I know Depeche has wielded their way into the hearts of America by consistently delivering the quintessential head-bobbing-pop-fare in their indisputably unique style. However, what Depeche delivers on \\"Exciter\\" is exciting in a different way. They offer up a more mature, relaxed sound. This recording is opulent and emotional. I don't believe that true Depeche fans are the ones expressing disappointed about this, because these factors are exactly what separates this group from the rest of the electronic-keyboard-based bands. The negativity is from those immature psuedo-fans who thrive on the tunes that have allowed D.M. their commercial success. Though \\"Freelove\\" is as awesome of an offering to appease the monsters as, \\"People Are People\\"... This is not an album recorded to persue commercial-pop success.     The alternative, as I see it... They could have maintained Vince Clark and continued to sound just as they did on on their first release, \\"Speak & Spell\\", which was consistently high-energy and fun, but augh! Mr. Clark found an outlet for that as \\"Erasure\\", and aren't we all a little tired of middle-aged men churning out nothing but synthesized high-energy disco? I am. Martin Gore on the other hand is a song writing genius who does not rely onformula and that's in part why...  \\"Exciter\\" is my absolute favorite D.M. release to date.     I won't review the songs because who wants to trudge through me describing how awesome each and every track is? My only disappointment is with \\"Comatose\\", which is comparatively weak. Growing up with Depeche Mode is one of life's special treasured little pleasures. Please,let them grow up as well. This  release of smooth, mature, emotionally-charged tranquility is,...exciting.
0788815490|5.0|Watching The Wings of the Dove on dvd after years of not seeing it, I felt as though I were watching a completely new movie - the ravishing cinematography of Eduardo Serra makes this a completely new experience from its video transfer that I first saw.  The rain-strewn canals of Venice seem to have never looked so vivid, romantic, and - cineastes beware - symmetrical.  This becomes so eye-catching because despite amazing Merchant-Ivory productions, the turn-of-the-century class-romance conflict has never been made like it is here.  That's because beneath its struggle between desire and social mores is two fully vivid women whose characterizations embody the full depths and aspirations of humanity (not to a mention a deliciously misanthropic turn by Charlotte Rampling as icy Aunt Maude).  Alison Elliot never quite got the credit she deserved for matching Milly's rapaciousness towards life with her rapaciousness towards Martin - and Kate.  And Helena Bonham Carter gives equal parts sizzle and sympathy to the almost totally sympathy-less Kate, who, at her center, is a fairly vile manipulator.  The fact that the movie could have such romantic force despite our very human reservations towards what's going on onscreen is a testament to the full gradations of life Iain Sotley and Hossein Amini bring to Henry James's novel - and it makes this thick British drama a pulsating force.

B000002IMG|5.0|\\"The New Order\\" has always been my favorite Testament album which came out in 1988 which was one year later after they released their 1987 debut \\"The Legacy\\" which was a classic as well, but this album however is much better, and it's also Testament's best album as well as I might add. It is simply an absolute classic and it's definitely one of the best Thrash Metal albums of the 80's as well. Words just can't even describe how amazing this album is. It just rips and shreds like a beast, it is really amazing. Musically, \\"The New Order\\" is a bit more melodic, complex, and very technical, and the songwriting is also better than on the first album as well. The production which is handled by Alex Perialas is also great too, while not being too polished, but not under produced whatsoever. Chuck Billy is a very talented and skilled vocalist whose style ranges from wicked high piercing screams to gruff, aggressive low growls that will make your bones quiver. The guitar work here is just fantastic as rhythm guitarist Eric Peterson anchors and drives the songs here with heavy, fast, brutal, violent riffs, while lead axeman Alex Skolnick steals the show throughout with his share of excellent riffing and let's not forget about his amazing, wailing, amp-shredding solos as well. He is truly one of Thrash Metal's best lead shredders in my opinion, no questions asked. Greg Christian's bass notes are good and audible on occasion, and Louie Clemente's drumming is just rock solid throughout.<br /><br />\\"The New Order\\" is just chock full of classic Testament songs. Every song on here is a winner in my book. Track one \\"Eerie Inhabitants\\" begins with some eerie, spacey acoustic notes followed by some awesome melodic lead guitar work until the song propells into an angry, thrashing foot stomping beat and blistering riffage, and there's also a lenghty, killer, melodic yet winding, wailing solo from Alex. \\"The New Order\\" is another stomping thrasher, as well as my favorite song on here which opens with some furious lead guitar shredding backed up by some heavy intro riffs, and then segues into another pounding, stomping thrash onslaught which also includes another killer, wailing solo by Alex. The chorus in this song is also awesome as well. \\"Trial By Fire\\" is another one of my favorite Testament songs that starts off with some more awesome melodic soloing and then shifts into a barrage of grinding, thrashing riff and stomping drums, and we're treated yet again with another awesome, wailing, shredding Alex solo. Next up, we have \\"Into the Pit\\" which is another one of Testament's best known songs, and an all out blistering, bruising, and blazing thrasher highlighted by an array of angry, aggressive vocals, blistering riffs, blazing soloing, pounding beats, and a mosh pit-worthy chorus. \\"Hypnosis\\" is a cool 2 minute instrumental interlude which features a nice blend of dark, eerie acoustic plucking and haunting lead guitar work, meanwhile \\"Disciples of the Watch\\" is yet another classic Testament song as well as a wicked speedy bruiser highlighted by ripping, blistering riffs, thumping, pounding beats, and another awesome solo by Alex. Next, we have yet another classic highlight \\"The Preacher\\" which is another one of my favorite Testament songs that is highlighted by amazing vocal work from Chuck including some wicked high piercing screams, and then we have a fantastic cover of Aerosmith's \\"Nobody's Fault\\" which is followed by \\"A Day of Reckoning\\", and the 4 minute closing instrumental piece \\"Musical Death (A Dirge)\\" which features some terrific and beautiful acoustic picking as well as a beautiful melodic solo.<br /><br />So in conclusion, \\"The New Order\\" is definitely an essential listen for any serious Thrash Metal fan or Metal in general. I highly recommend this album along with \\"The Legacy\\" and \\"Practice What You Preach\\" especially if you're new to Testament. Believe me, this is one of the absolute best Thrash Metal albums ever, no questions asked...Buy it now!!!<br /><br />HORNS UP!!!..Buy it now!!!<br /><br />HORNS UP!!!
B000068OSK|4.0|The White Stripes are a band that I listen to in amazement every time I put one of their albums in my CD player. I also hardly ever sing along to their music because I want to listen so intensely to everything that's going on in each song. The drums and guitar are the principal instruments of the Stripes' music and represent a back-to-basics approach to how rock music *was* made 30 years ago and, supposedly, how it should *still* be being made. Their self-titled 1999 debut album was released without much fanfare and passed by without selling anything. When the band broke through to international attention with 2001's \\"White Blood Cells,\\" this debut album was re-issued, re-packaged, and re-released and sold thousands.<br /><br />As far as raw and rough rock music goes, this debut album has it in abundance. This is probably the heaviest album from The White Stripes, but it never seems like a chore to get through it because of the heavy melodies and the wonderful arrangements. Jack White is in the early development stages of realising his true potential, and Meg White is the perfect counterpart. It's hard to believe this album was recorded in 1999, because it sounds so much older! This isn't a bad thing, though, it's quite refreshing and amazing in today's music scene.<br /><br />The album opens with the stunning \\"Jimmy The Exploder.\\" With a heavy guitar and clunking drum pieces, this song will have you jumping around from the moment it starts! Jack's vocals are on fire and you just feel like shaking your head to his \\"Woo! Woo! Woo!\\"-ing! \\"Stop Breaking Down\\" is a brilliant cover version. The beat is heavy, vocals are strong and the guitar is crazy. \\"The Big Three Killed My Baby\\" has a sharp, stabbing noise to begin with, followed by some crazy drum beats. Meg pounds on that kit like no tomorrow! Jack is literally screaming his lyrics here, but it's so irresistible. \\"Suzy Lee\\" is a softer, more gentler song but builds up in the choruses. \\"Sugar Never Tasted So Good\\" is a welcome change from the incredible, but repetitive, heavy guitars and drums. It's quite a lovely song which is followed by the crazy \\"Wasting My Time.\\" The vocals on this song are very good and I like the way the guitars breaks things up nicely into softer and harder sections. \\"Cannon\\" is more hard rock with lots of whooping and undulating drum loops. \\"Astro\\" is definitely one of the best songs on the whole album with guitar licks that will dance around in your head for days on end. The drum kit keeps constant in the background as the guitar climbs, stalls and continues with it. \\"Broken Bricks\\" is so heavy you'd mistake it for a crate of bricks falling onto your head! Short and swift, it starts and ends before you know it, but leaves one Hell of an impression.<br /><br />\\"When I Hear My Name\\" has lots of \\"whoa-oah-whoa-oaa!\\"-ing going on in it. The guitar rips this song apart and the drum kit is always there in the background. \\"Do\\" is a softer song about being hated by people for no apparent reason, and knowing there's nothing you can do about it! \\"Screwdriver\\" has a very intense vocal delivery from Jack, and the guitars seem to have come straight outta Hell. \\"One More Cup Of Coffee\\" is a brilliant cover version of the Bob Dylan original with some great harmonious instruments in the background. This is different to much of the rest of the album. \\"Little People\\" has a strange noise in the background that keeps your attention. It sounds like a whale under the sea to me. A lot of people dislike this song, but I think it's great - it builds up tension! \\"Slicker Drips\\" runs for just 90 seconds and isn't really a favourite of mine. \\"St. James Infirmary Rules\\" is pure old-school blues right here, and we're talking 1930's here, not even Sixties! There's something very silent-movie about this song and the piano is a wonderful addition: a sign of things to come. The album closes with \\"I Fought Piranhas.\\" This song takes the slide guitar of Suzy Lee which adds a very Western, deserted sound to the song.<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 8/10<br /><br />This album is far from being the best one from The White Stripes. In fact I'd probably say it's my least favourite of all five of their albums, but it was their debut and was simply a platform from which they could ascend to higher levels of brilliance. Okay, so this album didn't change the world, but their later stuff bloody did. This album is slightly one-dimensional and after a while the drums and electric guitars can get slightly tedious. This makes the album seem a lot longer than it's actual 43 minutes. If you're just getting into this incredible band, I'd begin with their more recent stuff such as \\"Elephant\\" and \\"Get Behind Me Satan.\\" Then I'd move onto their older material to see how they progressed over time.song.    OVERALL GRADE: 8/10    This album is far from being the best one from The White Stripes. In fact I'd probably say it's my least favourite of all five of their albums, but it was their debut and was simply a platform from which they could ascend to higher levels of brilliance. Okay, so this album didn't change the world, but their later stuff bloody did. This album is slightly one-dimensional and after a while the drums and electric guitars can get slightly tedious. This makes the album seem a lot longer than it's actual 43 minutes. If you're just getting into this incredible band, I'd begin with their more recent stuff such as \\"Elephant\\" and \\"Get Behind Me Satan.\\" Then I'd move onto their older material to see how they progressed over time.

B000002MTR|5.0|The Red Hot Chili Peppers, a band that means so much to me. I've only been listening to their music as a fan for the past two and a half years, since I bought \\"By The Way\\" in January 2003, but in that time they have easily become my all-time favourite band. There's something about the music they make, coupled with Anthony Kiedis' voice that sends me to a special place. I know this might sound stupid, but I used to listen to their albums when I played Grand Theft Auto on my PlayStation 2, and I think something about that combination of music with something visual brought out the true beauty of the music. Yeah, it sounds strange, that a video game would make me realise this.<br /><br />Four years had passed from 1991's breakthrough classic \\"Blood Sugar Sex Magik\\" and 1995's \\"One Hot Minute.\\" The popularity of the band had waned somewhat, but the expectation for new material was still very high. John Frusciante had departed the band in between the release of both these albums, and Jane's Addiction guitarist Dave Navarro stepped up to fill his shoes. Fans were a bit disappointed, which has resulted in this album receiving harsh reviews. I personally really like this album. It's different to their other albums, which is not always a bad thing: variety is what keeps a band fresh. Navarro left the band in 1997 after \\"creative differences,\\" and I'll be the first to admit it was better when John came back for 1999's \\"Californication.\\"<br /><br />The album opens with the heavy rock anthem \\"Warped.\\" This song begins as though it is miles away with a drum beat travelling faster and faster to your ears. Kiedis' vocals are warped to give a distorted effect before the guitars and drums storm in after 46 seconds. The beat in this track is so heavy and travels like a tidal wave through the entire length of the song. The chorus is powerful and makes for a great driving anthem! \\"Aeroplane\\" is the album's lead single and one of the best songs that they have ever done! The tranquil intro soon turns into a VERY funky piece of rock. The guitar in this song is amazing and although the lyrics are rather meaningless, Kiedis' vocal delivery is beautiful. \\"Deep Kick\\" is the longest song on the album, and begins with a very long spoken intro. It's a poem really, and I think it works quite well. I'm just not too fond of the actual song once the music kicks in. \\"My Friends\\" is a beautiful ballad. Anthony serves up a very nice vocal delivery here, with the band harmonising to great effect. The song is quite sad and emotional as Kiedis' sings about how much his friends mean to him.<br /><br />\\"Coffee Shop\\" is quite a short song that a lot of people hate. However, I adore it, I can't get enough! Yes, it's a bit outrageous and crazy, but that's what makes it so wonderful. Kiedis' vocals are just hilarious on this track, and the way they change at the end of each line has me in giggles every time I hear it! \\"Pea\\" is Flea's solo song that I think is quite underrated! Okay, this song is pretty bad, but the message is great. I love the way Flea takes down a big, tough, macho homophobe in just a few lines! \\"One Big Mob\\" is a song that I'm only rather partial to. It's not great, but then it's not that bad either. It begins very heavily with lots of manly chanting! I think this sounds great, then for the song to slow down and become really peaceful, only to fire up again towards the end makes for a wonderfully arranged piece, quite different to the other songs on the album. \\"Walkabout\\" begins with some great guitar work, before slowing down and transforming into a really nice ballad. The guitars and drums are still present in the background, but Kiedis' vocals make for a very cool chillout track. \\"Tearjerker\\" is one of the best songs on the album. It's quite a nice ballad with some great guitar work that creates a relaxing atmosphere. The lyrics in this song make love seem so simple and get down to the basics of how Kiedis is feeling. He bares his soul here, and the chorus is a revelation.<br /><br />The album title track, \\"One Hot Minute,\\" is a bit overblown in my opinion. It starts off quite well, but I think the guitars and vocals don't quite work well together in this song. Still not a bad effort though. \\"Falling Into Grace\\" opens with some weird, guttural noises and is quite funky in its approach. I like the chorus with Kiedis' vocals in an almost falsetto style. He's also backed up beautifully by the female backing vocals of Kristen Vigard, who helps to harmonise the melody of the vocal arrangement. \\"Shallow Be Thy Game\\" begins with drums that get louder and louder as the seconds progress. Suddenly, it's easy to see where the intro to \\"Can't Stop\\" may have come from! \\"Transcending\\" closes the album out after 13 songs, and is a tribute from the band to the late River Phoenix. The bass and guitar line work in perfect synchronicity in this gorgeous song, before it speeds up and gets louder to play out a great ending to sixty red hot minutes.<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 9/10<br /><br />This album isn't perfect, but then not many are. A lot of people who are supposedly long-time Chili Peppers fans don't like their new sound, as expressed on \\"By The Way.\\" This is the album that got me into the band though, so I can hardly say I dislike it. By starting from their more recent material, I've worked back in time with their albums, listening to their older material and ultimately finding it more difficult to get into. This is because of the evolution in their style. Albums like \\"Californication,\\" \\"Blood Sugar Sex Magik\\" and \\"Mother's Milk\\" are incredible pieces of rock art. \\"One Hot Minute\\" is a level down from this, but it's still a great rock album and I admire the band's willingness to experiment and evolve over time.The album title track, \\"One Hot Minute,\\" is a bit overblown in my opinion. It starts off quite well, but I think the guitars and vocals don't quite work well together in this song. Still not a bad effort though. \\"Falling Into Grace\\" opens with some weird, guttural noises and is quite funky in its approach. I like the chorus with Kiedis' vocals in an almost falsetto style. He's also backed up beautifully by the female backing vocals of Kristen Vigard, who helps to harmonise the melody of the vocal arrangement. \\"Shallow Be Thy Game\\" begins with drums that get louder and louder as the seconds progress. Suddenly, it's easy to see where the intro to \\"Can't Stop\\" may have come from! \\"Transcending\\" closes the album out after 13 songs, and is a tribute from the band to the late River Phoenix. The bass and guitar line work in perfect synchronicity in this gorgeous song, before it speeds up and gets louder to play out a great ending to sixty red hot minutes.    OVERALL GRADE: 9/10    This album isn't perfect, but then not many are. A lot of people who are supposedly long-time Chili Peppers fans don't like their new sound, as expressed on \\"By The Way.\\" This is the album that got me into the band though, so I can hardly say I dislike it. By starting from their more recent material, I've worked back in time with their albums, listening to their older material and ultimately finding it more difficult to get into. This is because of the evolution in their style. Albums like \\"Californication,\\" \\"Blood Sugar Sex Magik\\" and \\"Mother's Milk\\" are incredible pieces of rock art. \\"One Hot Minute\\" is a level down from this, but it's still a great rock album and I admire the band's willingness to experiment and evolve over time.

6301973410|4.0|\\"Mildred Pierce\\" a 109 minute black and white film was nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Actress, Michael Curtiz's 1945 noir classic.  This film features a great, Oscar-winning come back by its star, Joan Crawford, who was fired by MGM and voted box-office poison before filming began. <br /> <br />The film begins with the murder of Monte Beragon (Zachary Scott) in the beach house he lives in with his wife, Mildred Pierce Beragon (Joan Crawford). Four bullets are fired into him at close range and he dies while calling out Mildred's name. Mildred walks in the rain on a pier and appears to be the one who killed him. She certainly had a reason to kill her good-for-nothing husband.  <br /> <br />The film is told in flashback from the murder scene, as the suspects are brought into the police station to be interrogated.  The suspects include former husband Bert (Bennett), whom Mildred married at 17; business associate and close friend, Ida (Eve Arden); a former real estate partner of her husband's, Wally Fay (Jack Carson); and, the torn downed Mildred.  <br /> <br />As Mildred's interrogation starts the film starts its flashback to her first marriage to Bert and how he loses his real-estate partnership with Wally and starts seeing a mistress.  Mildred leaves Bert saying that she can make it on her own and becomes a waitress to support herself and her gentle daughter Kay and her money hungry 16 year old daughter, Veda (Ann Blyth).  With the help of Wally's keen business skills she secures an ideal place to open a restaurant. She purchases the land from wealthy society loafer Monte Beragon. The place is an overnight success and Mildred is now living in a mansion, and providing Veda with all the love that money could buy. But this kid is so rotten that it's impossible to believe that her mother could still love her so much.  <br /> <br />Monte turns out to be a snaky guy, playing off both mother and daughter for his love. When he has cash problems Mildred helps him out despite how he looks down upon her as a working women, just like her daughter does as someone with greasy hands from working in the kitchen.  After Mildred divorces Bert, she is lured in by the handsome Monte's charms. She marries him, despite not loving him, because she wants Veda to return home. <br /> <br />All these melodramatics were heavy-handed and Mildred's possessive desires were hard to explain, except she's someone who encouraged others to take advantage of her because she never found satisfaction in either marriage or with herself. It was hard to feel sorry for her, since she brought this tragedy onto herself. The film is very reflective of 1940s attitudes about independent women who desert the idea of a nuclear family, and how dangerous it could be for them to do that.  <br />

1573223026|5.0|I enjoyed Hornby's inventive approach to this seemingly dark topic, suicide.  I expected a somber read, but found myself laughing out loud several times.  He doesn't take the questions of Life and Death too lightly, nor does he take them too seriously.  He finds the perfect mix of melancholia, humor, depression, and excitement.<br /><br />Hornby writes the book in first person, but the point of view is passed around between the four main characters.  My main concern when I discovered this format was that I was going to be re-living events through the four characters eyes, constantly back-tracking in time to get all points of view.  Fortunately, Hornby avoids this pitfall by never having the story fold back on itself.  This preserves the forward motion of the story.  The reader is left with the impression that four very different people have written their personal memoirs and an editor deftly pieced them together to create a moving story.  We've all read books where a young girl is speaking and you just can't get it out of your head that a middle-aged man is writing how he imagines a young girl would speak.  Hornby doesn't have that problem. He writes from the point of view of different ages, sexes, and nationalities.  You don't feel the heavy hand of the author weighing down their words.  So in the end, Hornby's fiction feels like non-fiction.<br /><br />While Hornby creates and develops his convincing characters, he includes insightful commentary on current London (and global) culture, such as the \\"Starbuck-ing\\" of the world, tabloid culture, and our obsession with celebrity.  He doesn't necessarily condemn these things, he just starts conversations about them, or rather his characters do.  Hornby takes some highly unlikeable people and fleshes them out so the reader cares what they think, and most importantly cares if they live or die.<br /><br />I didn't really enjoy Hornby's last book, \\"How to be Good.\\"  I agree with several Amazon reviewers of HTBG who wrote something like, \\"That was an interesting premise and a fun ride, but what was the point?\\"  I felt like I had wasted a few days of reading.  \\"A Long Way Down\\" begins in a manner similar to \\"How to be Good,\\"  an intriguing but highly implausible exposition that shows great promise.  While reading I was saying to myself, \\"Don't burn me again Hornby!  Don't take me on this wild journey for no apparent reason!\\"  Fortunately, \\"A Long Way Down\\" has a point.  Not one I can sum up in a few sentences, but a point nonetheless.<br /><br />There's no way to discuss the plot without ruining the book for you.  Just order the book and enjoy a brilliant summer read.an interesting premise and a fun ride, but what was the point?\\"  I felt like I had wasted a few days of reading.  \\"A Long Way Down\\" begins in a manner similar to \\"How to be Good,\\"  an intriguing but highly implausible exposition that shows great promise.  While reading I was saying to myself, \\"Don't burn me again Hornby!  Don't take me on this wild journey for no apparent reason!\\"  Fortunately, \\"A Long Way Down\\" has a point.  Not one I can sum up in a few sentences, but a point nonetheless.      There's no way to discuss the plot without ruining the book for you.  Just order the book and enjoy a brilliant summer read.

B000001DU5|4.0|Tears For Fears is my favorite group, so it is very hard for me to be critical of any effort that they release.  As someone who is a deep Tears For Fears fans, the greatest hits compilation \\"Tears Roll Down\\" might be overkill for me.   With the exception of a new track, this compilation provides a sampling of what are widely considered the \\"hits\\" for the band over the first three albums.   If you look at this collection as a primer for a new fan of Tears For Fears, this collection is going to do the job.   If you are a deeper fan like myself, you may be disappointed.  However, I'm going to write this review from the perspective of a new Tears For Fears fan. <br /> <br />Tears For Fears was a band formed by Bath England's Curt Smith and Roland Orzabal.  Curt and Roland would leave Graduate in 1981.  Much of the reason why they left Graduate was that they didn't want to be confined to a band.    When they would form Tears For Fears - they would operate in a \\"project\\" mode.  This would mean that Curt and Roland would form the nucleus and bring in surrounding musicians to help them complete the picture.  Tears For Fears would release three albums with Curt and Roland as the core nucleus:  \\"The Hurting\\" (1982); \\"Songs From the Big Chair\\" (1985), and \\"The Seeds of Love\\" (1989).   The collection \\"Tears Roll Down\\" consists of 11 songs from these three albums, plus one new song.   For the first two albums, the lineup would also consist of Keyboardist Ian Stanley and Drummer Manny Elias.   On the third album, R&B/Gospel singer Oleta Adams would also be a part of the project.  There are also many other various and talented musicians that would work with Tears For Fears - including Nicky Holland, who emerge as a key songwriter on \\"The Seeds of Love\\".  Unfortunately, after \\"The Seeds of Love\\", Curt and Roland would go separate ways.  Roland would continue to record and perform under the Tears For Fears name.   It wasn't until 2004's \\"Everybody Loves a Happy Ending\\", where Curt and Roland would reunite as Tears For Fears once again. <br /> <br />Many people associate Tears For Fears as a 1980s \\"Pop\\" band.   This is partially true.  In a lot of ways, their music reflects the 1980s Pop music scene.  As many are aware, the early 1980s sound started out as a Synth-Pop song, but by the late 1980s transformed to a more \\"natural\\" guitar-laden sound. When Tears For Fears would release \\"The Hurting\\", you could generalize it as Synth-Pop, but it really was an album that put a dark and haunting spin on New Wave.  As the title indicated, many of the songs dealt with hurt and pain.    By the time \\"Songs From the Big Chair\\" was released, it could be argued that the band moved more toward a Pop sound.   But the sound would incorporate elements of jazz, and even harder-rock.   By the time \\"The Seeds of Love\\" was released, they would have completely transformed themselves to a natural, guitar-laden sound - some would even term this this sound as \\"Beatlesque\\". Overall - innovation is not a problem with Tears For Fears. <br /> <br />As mentioned, this album focuses on the \\"hits\\".   The distribution of \\"hits\\" is as follows:  \\"The Hurting\\" (\\"Mad World\\", Pale Shelter\\", \\"Change\\"); \\"Songs From the Big Chair\\" (\\"Everybody Wants to Rule the World\\", \\"Shout\\", \\"Head Over Heels\\", \\"I Believe\\", \\"Mothers Talk\\"); \\"The Seeds of Love\\" (\\"Sowing the Seeds of Love\\", \\"Woman in Chains\\", \\"Advice for the Young at Heart\\").  This also contains the new song \\"Laid So Low (Tears Roll Down\\").  It is worth noting that this song would be later released on the \\"Saturnine, Martial and Lunatic\\"  CD- a CD devoted to rare and B side songs by Tears For Fears.    <br /> <br />Unfortunately \\"Tears Roll Down\\" doesn't have its tracks in chronological order.  I usually prefer my greatest hits compilations to be in chronological order.  This allows me to see how the band has evolved over time.   With the case of Tears For Fears, this would have been a most positive thing - because this band not only evolved - but they underwent a transformation during the 1980s. <br /> <br />\\"Tears Roll Down\\" was the first of several greatest hits compilations by the band.   Here are some of the others: <br /> <br />\\"Shout: The Very Best of Tears For Fears\\": This is a more comprehensive collection than \\"Tears Roll Down\\".  All of the original songs on \\"Tears Roll Down\\" are on \\"Shout\\".  This collection also contains some \\"B\\" side songs as well as two songs from \\"Elemental\\" (the first post Curt Smith Tears For Fears collection).  For the most part, this collection also goes in a chronological order. <br /> <br />\\"20th Century Masters - The Millennium Collection: The Best of Tears for Fears\\":  This is a less comprehensive collection than \\"Tears Roll Down\\".  Only one song from \\"Shout\\" is included\\" (\\"Change\\").  It also includes one song from \\"Elemental\\" and one B-side song.  This collection is not in chronological order. <br /> <br />\\"Ultimate Collection\\": This is a three CD import set - and is the most comprehensive set.  It includes 37 songs in chronological order.  It includes songs through 1995's \\"Raoul and the Kings of Spain\\" (the second post Curt Smith album).  One of the CDs is devoted to remixes and also contains a rare Curt Smith solo track.   If you are looking to go deep, this would be the collection to get. <br /> <br />Overall, I wouldn't put \\"Tears Roll Down\\" as the strongest compilation out there.   It still is a terrific way for the new fan to get on-board with Tears For Fears.  While I would give \\"Shout\\" and \\"Ultimate Collection\\" 5 stars, this one falls a notch below because it is less complete.  But the quality of what is contained on this collection is top-notch.  There isn't a bad song on this collection - and that's ultimately what matters.   This is still recommended, but mostly for the newbie fan.
B000002L3P|4.0|Okay everyone before you go slamming someone for making changes in their style and sound I suggest that you strap on a guitar yourself and try playing the same thing over and over and over again and try to remain enthusiastic about it.. <br />I'll admit that this recording is quite a departure from Kens previous stylings.. Some songs sound to me a bit like Lenny Kravitz, some almost sound to me a bit like Cry of Love meets Brother Cane ... But they're only comparisons.. These songs are still Kenny Wayne and I am humbled by his ability and facility with his instrument.(Makes me almost want to put mine down and not pick it up again...) <br />                         Jimi Hendrix lamented the same feelings back in the 60's when he wanted to move on stylistically but everyone was still screaming for him to play Hey Joe or whatever.  <br />                   Just like eating waffles everyday for breakfast....It can get old.. We ALL need change once in a while.Why should our modern day minstrels be any different.. I'd say don't give up on Ken just yet.. <br />                                       I remember giving Living Colour (remember them?) two second chances because I dug their first disc so much. But Vernon Reid's stylistic change just lost me..Too avant garde I guess.. <br />                             Ken I give you credit for singing on your own songs. You can pull it off.. There are others who,in my opinion,absolutely should NOT be singing on their songs but shall remain nameless because this is just my opinion..  <br />          I suppose this isn't so much a review of Kens music as it is me going to bat for him ( not that he needs me to or would even want me to)and anyone else that has the courage to try change...Just wanted to throw in my $.02 worth I guess. The good thing about keeping the same kind of sound is that you will insure that you keep your dieheart fans and not taking the risk of losing them. B0006L16N8|4.0|Three calendar years is a long time to wait for a studio album. I'm sure it feels even longer when you end up re-recording the album three times over. And with all of the systematic ways in which world-wide touring and promotion and the release of singles to radio and the production of music videos is done, it's no wonder it now takes upwards of several years in-between major releases by big name bands. It all makes the workload that a band like The Beatles was able to achieve in a single year look downright impossible in this day and age. <br /> <br />As I'm sure most of us already know, the copy of \\"X&Y\\" which we have now in our possession is the third version of the album, recorded earlier this year after the band's spur of newfound enthusiasm and creativity. But as many of you know, this isn't the first time that the band scraped entire albums of material. The final version of \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\" was, if I recall correctly, the second recording session after the initial sessions were completely shelved. Funny enough, most of those shelved songs, which then became b-sides to \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\" singles, ended up becoming some of my favorites: \\"One I Love,\\" \\"Crests Of Waves,\\" \\"1.36,\\" \\"I Ran Away,\\" and \\"Murder.\\" Just an example in variation of taste between fan and band, I suppose. But, after all, a good call on the band's behalf, because \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head\\" ended up being their commercial break-through, reaching the same masses that swarmed music stores on June 7 to pick up \\"X&Y.\\" <br /> <br />Putting all of Coldplay's music side-by-side and judging it on completeness, \\"Parachutes\\" is still my hands-down favorite. In my opinion, that album truly takes the name \\"masterpiece\\" and does it justice. Not to discredit \\"A Rush Of Blood To The Head;\\" it is full of terrific songs, featuring one of the all-time best front-ends of a CD with \\"Politik,\\" \\"In My Place,\\" \\"God Put A Smile Upon Your Face,\\" and \\"The Scientist,\\" but as a whole, as an album experience, that's where it falls short. However, that's where \\"X&Y\\" excels, is in Coldplay's return to a more complete listening from start to finish. \\"X&Y\\" reflects the Coldplay of \\"Parachutes\\" in the way in which you can put this latest release on at the start and listen through to the end, no skipping around track-to-track necessary. <br /> <br />I really despise track-by-track breakdowns, so I'll spare you the same suffering. What I will say about the music is that it is distinctly Coldplay: it's probably clich as hell to say, but they've managed to keep their style, but not sound the same. After all, it's hard to be one of the biggest bands in the world and now have a burden on your shoulders that keeps whispering in your ear, \\"It's gotta be big...bigger than the last.\\" Instead of just being able to make music, the band is now worried about living up to expectations and record sales. It's the danger that comes from living up to hype rather than living up to ability. Whether it's in the world of film and it's \\"Star Wars: Episode I\\" or in the world of music and it's the follow-up to \\"Jagged Little Pill\\" or \\"Yourself Or Someone Like You,\\" there's a real expectation by the masses, and it can cause an artist to either flourish or flounder. <br /> <br />Thankfully, from what I've seen in interviews with the guys of Coldplay, they have a strong bond, which makes them a much better band. Things they've said and done have really impressed me. It was on their \\"Live 2003\\" DVD in the documentary that showed how grateful they were to be playing music for a living. Whereas most show-boat musicians would gawk at a morning radio show performance after a late show the previous night, Coldplay did it, and they even commented on how it would have been all-too-easy to complain and not do it. They went through with it, the show went on. And in a recent interview, the guys said they took 18 months to record \\"X&Y\\" because they needed some time to get away from the fictitious world of touring and promotion and the life of rock stars. They said they had to so that they didn't end up writing an album full of songs about touring and the ever-so-hard life of a musician. That made me so happy to hear that. How many bad albums have you bought that wind up that way, full of complaints about groupies and no green M&Ms? I know I've heard my share. <br /> <br />Honestly, there was a point in 2003 when I worried that Coldplay's next album would end up being nothing but ballads to Gwyneth and baby Apple. That isn't the case come 2005. Fortunately, we've ended up with a high quality assortment of tunes, which are well crafted and will be killer to hear live. What impresses me most is the maturity of their sound, which stems from the evolution of their songs. Take \\"Talk,\\" for example: comparing the \\"X&Y\\" version to the demo version, in addition to including Kraftwerk, now includes portions of the 2003 road-tested track \\"Ladder To The Sun,\\" ends up being one of the strongest songs, if not the best, on the album. <br /> <br />With \\"X&Y,\\" I truly believe that there is something for everyone. Whether you're into the album experience or just like standout tracks. Whether you loved their uber-hit \\"Clocks\\" or you're like me and prefer their deeper cuts, \\"X&Y\\" does not disappoint.
B0006L16N8|3.0|While I wouldn't call them the next Radiohead, there is something about Coldplay and their ability to write songs. And also like Radiohead, their main frontman usually gets top billing over the other members. We may love Johnny Greenwood's riffs or Ed O Brien's playing yet we can't seem to name them for some reason. Same with these guys too. Whereas Radiohead gave us a surprise double hook with Kid A and Amnesiac, Coldplay just keeps giving the same punch, hoping after awhile they'll make a dent, instead we get used to it easily. <br /> <br />Square One: Don't Panic had a likability despite its short length while Politik had all the bombast a opener can have. This is more subdued. Opens with ambience that could easily fit on a Pink Floyd or Mogwai record before Chris starts singing, and the rest come in. It's a good opener but I find Politik better. 8/10 <br /> <br />What If: Starts with Chris and the piano singing about the possible upsets in life with strings added to give it more atmosphere. Then song then gets better as the rest of the band joins in and Chris does nice falsettos in the chorus. After several listens, it's likable. 8/10 <br /> <br />White Shadows: It reminds me U2 back in their War/Unforgettable Fire days which is no surprise since it has Edge-like guitar lines. It's a good track and a good song overall. Chorus bugs me slightly. Also it's a bit long. 8/10 <br /> <br />Fix You: Part of me wants to hate this song. It's literally the Scientist Part II with piano/keyboards starting the verses, then guitar being added after the first chorus, Chris's great falsetto singing and the big emotional climax. But it's such a damn good song that you just give up and like the thing. Those magnificent bast*rds. 9/10 <br /> <br />Talk: Lifting, sorry, \\"borrowing\\" the melody line from Computer Love by Kraftwerk, it's another song that could be a good single. I don't know if it's just me but it doesn't really sound clean in terms of production, almost sounds \\"too much\\" during the chorus. 7.5/10 <br /> <br />Speed of Sound: Since we had the Scientist Part II why not have the Clocks sequel too? And it's over 5 minutes, oy! 6/10 <br /> <br />The Hardest Part: Beautiful guitar arpeggios and piano chords caught my ear but the rest didn't. Like many songs on the last half, it could've been put in the oven and worked on more. 7/10 <br /> <br />Swallowed in the Sea: Not the greatest lyrics and a bit convincing vocal delivery. The chorus catches me somewhat, maybe after repeated listens I'll like it more. Nice and short ditty that you'll probably like if you give it time. 8/10 <br /> <br />Twisted Logic: Weird organ and Chris's singing start it off before the guitar comes in(which sounds like a slower Everybody Hurts). One complaint: remember that Radiohead intro I said? Well the lyrics to the chorus here: you'll go backwards again, you'll go forwards again..., kinda similar to Radiohead's \\"I'll go forwards, you'll go backwards\\" chorus from Electioneering no? 8/10 <br /> <br />Til Kingdom Come: Originally written for Johnny Cash but the Man in Black passed before he could record it. Chris has a nice lower voice in a largely acoustic song strummed in a kind-of folkish 1970's way. Why this was a secret song I have no idea. Probably didn't fit with the big production stuff of the album. My favorite song after Fix You. 9/10 <br /> <br />The songs run together a bit too easily, some rather bad lyrics(\\"my song is love\\", \\"puzzles keep puzzling me?\\"), U2-inspired guitar. For some reason we tolerate Iron Maiden, Slayer and AC/DC writing the same record 10 times over yet we hate when Coldplay, Radiohead, REM, U2 and Smashing Pumpkins repeat themselves. While this isn't a bad record, the long incubation time on this record should suggest a really super punch in the face record, only it's more like a punch in the arm.
B000001EAQ|5.0|This is the most exciting U2 album ever: The album takes countless schizophrenic twists. This complex, intense swarm of guitars is held aloft by a solid, inventive rhythm section and an impressive array of electronica and keyboard textures. <br /> <br />Listening to the record, you wouldn't initially realize that there are so many computerized noises weaving through the songs, but a closer listen reveals a dense, texturally-rich presentation that relies equally on both musical approaches. The disorienting delights of the music and the intense messages presented on the lyrics make you feel an unique experience. <br /> <br />The sense of alienation is palpable. If the unstable, quick-slow existence of pop stardom offers Bono both the free time and the necessary stress and disorientation to think in terms as Mofo, maybe half of us though our sense of inertia and unspecified angst have an idea of what he's talking about.  <br /> <br />When the vocals dissolve into a distant storm of rabid, distorted screams, it's not the snortings and foot-stampings of a petulant ingrate, rather a snippet of that same rage that drives us into lousy self-mollification or else off the hinge. A very modern terror, an unreachable itch. <br /> <br />You've got one of the few rock masterpieces of the '90s. This masterpiece won't be surpassed...and you can forget about \\"easy listening\\" right now.

B0009I7NNA|2.0|First off, Waking The Fallen was an excellent CD and Avenged puts on a sick live show.  That said, this album is a disappointment.  For those who believe that M. Shadows doesnt scream because of throat surgery, watch this band on the Warped Tour this summer.  Unless they play ALL new material, anything off of Waking The Fallen will require screaming.  If he screams for that, than he has the ability to scream but is choosing not to use it on this CD.   <br /> <br />The real problem here is the song writing.  This band has fallen into such a formula.  Waking The Fallen's 6-7 minute songs featuring solos and a blend of screaming and singing worked great.  The beauty of that album was the balance between the heavy and the melodic, both musically and vocally.  However, an entire album of singing (especially Shadows' new style of whiny singing) over this band's type of music doesnt quite fit.  Now the songs seem boring and dragged out, sometimes it feels like the band is adding in guitar parts just to compensate for the lack of vocal punch.  Why not take a chance and write a two minute blast of power? No, they choose to add 45 extra seconds of extra guitar riffing just because thats what already worked for them once.  Theyre getting rid of screaming to go in a new direction? How about trying something new musically instead?  We all know that the musicians in this band are extremely talented, but why not try something new instead of trying to impress us with what we have already heard that you can do?
B0002858YS|4.0|Back in an old review, I lamented that a lot of the new big releases I bought were from veterans: bands that have been around for years releasing their 3rd or even their 5th record(like Weezer). I never really cared for Killers first single Somebody Told Me but I decided to give them a chance. Good thing I did. <br /> <br />Jenny Was a Friend of Mine: The lost Cure track? Has the best guitar/bass interplay I've heard recently. Guitar provides the chord changes while bass does the main melody primarily with vocalist Brandon Flowers doing his best Robert Smith voice. Excellent opener. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Mr. Brightside: I avoided the big radio overplay so I'm not sick of it yet. Repeats itself a bit too much but it's one of the great rock songs in recent memory. Very high fretted guitar notes and good use of drones and one incredibly catchy guitar line in the chorus, plus the chorus is a hook on its own. Awesome. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Smile Like You Mean It: I love the guitar intro and the synth underneath and its odd synth hook during the chorus but the chorus just smacks of laziness(singing the title and that's it, bah). Musically it's good but everything is ok. 8/10 <br /> <br />Somebody Told Me: One of the few rock songs you can probably dance too. The chorus has an odd novelty value about an androgynous boyfriend of a former lover. Great pop ditty that could be a good single, unless they stopped already. But personally go with Jenny first then this. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />Believe Me Natalie: Now this is probably my favorite guitar riff on the entire album even though it's incredibly simple, it just has this kind of ethereal quality to it. Some find it boring, me, I love it. Could've had a minute shaved off though. 9/10 <br /> <br />Midnight Show: Fast-paced verses with ska chords and Unforgettable Fire-like guitar but oh my do I hate that chorus. Like Smile, musically I like it but everything turns me off. 7.5/10 <br /> <br />Everything Will Be Alright: Floating around on the net is a song called Indie Rock and Roll which could've been a good closer. This however sounds like a sonic experiment without the interesting part. Brandon almost sounds like Freddie Mercury at times. Robert Smith, now Freddie Mercury. Huh. 6/10 <br /> <br />Unlike other albums by bands where ideas seem half-baked, here they sound fully cooked but they just not tasty(how's that for an effective analogy?) Still, here's hoping they don't go into sophomore slump land for the next one.
B000002UJQ|5.0|\\"... Oxfordshire 1996, and Radiohead finally begin to record the follow-up to 'The Bends'. Thom Yorke's brain is accelerating. The aforementioned view amplified by the conditions in which he's working. Recording at night, he goes to bed at dawn and wakes at ten to continue the lyrics.  <br /> <br />His state of mind is sleepless and fractured. When 'OK Computer' is finished, Yorke describes the 12 completed songs as \\"Polaroids in my head\\", a succession of snapshots that form a larger whole. Away from distractions and shrouded in secrecy, Radiohead have created an album motivated and unified by one overriding theme: three years away from the millennium, Yorke wants to leave the planet and escape from the routine and clutter of life.  <br />Not that Radiohead have chosen to follow a 1.5 million-selling record with a concept album; at least, not consciously. It's just that virtually every track on 'OK Computer' is driven by a feeling of impotence with the world around it. And it's that realisation which makes 'OK Computer' both age-defining and one of the most startling albums ever made.  <br /> <br />Here are 12 tracks crammed with towering lyrical ambition and musical exploration; that refuse to retread the successful formulas of before and instead opt for innovation and surprise; and that vividly articulate both the dreams and anxieties of one man without ever considering sacrifice or surrender. What makes it so important is its context. After all, 'The Bends' elevated Radiohead into the sphere of stadiums.  <br /> <br />While Thom was dreaming daily of planetary escape, the rest of the group were fashioning alien sounds from earthly instruments. In much the same way as Spiritualized's Jason Pierce became obsessed with new sound when recording 'Ladies And Gentlemen We Are Floating In Space', so it seems did Radiohead. Of course, the first single - 'Paranoid Android' - was designed to prepare you for that: six minutes of disconcerting sound and lyrical distress, halfof which is dominated by freakish guitar spasms and jolting time changes, half by neo-classical choirs and calming acoustics.  <br /> <br />And certainly one of the most bizarre songs ever to find its way into the British Top Five. Still, as far as Radiohead are concerned, that's just the beginning...  <br />The album itself opens with the slashed riffs and sucking electronics of 'Airbag', a song that at once sets the scene for all that's to follow. Yorke's ambivalence towards modern technology (that's also present in the album title) and supernatural insistence that he's \\"back to save the universe\\" are both made immediately apparent. Any hope that such a feat might actually be possible, however, is quickly extinguished by the realities of the rest of side one.  <br /> <br />Not that the album immediately descends into hopelessness and morbid introspection because, while avenues of earthly escape are explored and ultimately rejected, there remains throughout a tangible sense of purpose and uplifting sentiment. Once you've negotiated the real dissatisfaction of 'Paranoid Android' (a possible hymn to the vagaries of music journalism: \\"When I am king you will be first against the wall/With your opinions which are of no consequence at all\\"), what unfolds is a curiously positive experience.  <br /> <br />The lyrics of 'Subterranean Homesick Alien' might crave abduction from this planet and a chance to see the world from outer space (\\"Take me on board.../Show me the world as I'd love to see it\\") and 'Let Down' might recount the feeling of being \\"crushed like a beetle\\" under \\"motorways and tramlines\\", but at no point does this feel dispiriting or self-pitying. As the world speeds by ever faster, Radiohead have attempted to retreat to calmer climes to voice their concern. 'Subterranean Homesick Alien', 'Exit Music' and 'Let Down' are all apparently peaceful: guitars materialise then fade, blissful hidden melodies drift by unnoticed, and previously still songs are suddenlygiven momentum by a change of wind or a movement of the tide.  <br /> <br />Listen closer, however, and you will just about be able to distinguish the sounds of daily existence: of playground babbling and overloaded electrics, of surface noise and indistinguishable drones.  <br />After the fading noise of 'Karma Police', side two opens with a spate of ill-natured cacophony and dehumanised cynicism. 'Fitter Happier' sees Yorke wiring himself up to a synthesized voice machine and delivering a series of increasingly curious lifestyle slogans, while 'Electioneering' buries his rage at the power of multinationals under an avalanche of uncomfortable guitar noise. It's the last (and perhaps only) moment of fight, and it's from here that 'OK Computer' soars towards its climax.  <br /> <br />The claustrophobia of 'Climbing Up The Walls' is rapidly replaced by a trio of songs that equal - if not surpass - 'Street Spirit (Fade Out)''s beatific conclusion to 'The Bends'. Here the band truly dazzle. 'No Surprises' (billed as the band's attempt to rewrite 'What A Wonderful World') marries the resignation of Yorke's lyrics (\\"A job that slowly kills you/Bruises that won't heal... I'll take a quiet life\\") to a spacious wall of melancholy and bright xylophone chimes, while 'Lucky' - previously released on the 'War Child' compilation - brings the conclusion nearer with a continuous surge of Pink Floyd-esque slow-motion guitars.  <br />The album ends with the sound of Thom Yorke's brain decelerating. Buried within 'The Tourist''s monastic chanting and stately guitars, you can just about make out his voice (as grief-ridden and emotive as ever) trying to make sense of what's happening to him: \\"Where the hell am I going?/At 1,000ft per second/Hey man slow down/Idiot slow down\\".  <br /> <br />It's the final, futile attempt to alter the progress of his - or indeed anyone else's - life and it's a perfect finale. Such stoicism renders 'OK Computer' a spectacular success: a true articulation of the anxiety of late-20th century man backed with music not only of extraordinary grace and melody, but also of experimental clarity and vision. Truly, this is one of the greatest albums of living memory - and the one that distances Radiohead from their peers by an interstellar mile.(10/10)\\" <br />

B00003CXCT|1.0|If the mighty Sith Lord Lucash would openly and honestly state that the DVD box set version is in fact different from both the original (theatrical) and even the special edition (also theatrical) versions then at least he would be spared all the venom and vitriol that has been and is being thrown at him.
