B0009A1AS2|2.0|First. The Review. After that, the scam revealed.<br /><br />I have given Octavarium 4 full listens. It's hard to explain this album. It's not awful, it's not great, it's not \\"Six Degrees of Inner Slop.\\" It just `is'. I can't put my finger on it. It's like a mix between Images and Words and Falling into Infinity but without the magic of the former and the `umph' of the latter. There is not a single jaw-dropping moment on the album - though I'm not sure that's a bad thing in general. In other words, not once did I get goosebumps from a part that just made me go \\"holy crap!!\\" Yet it's a fairly pleasant listen. There are some decent, catchy tunes on it. It's kind of like Floyd. Nothing in Floyd's catalog is jaw dropping and yet their albums are stellar (not that this album is stellar! Not even close.). But because there are none of these jaw dropping moments on Octavarium, which DT needs in order to remain interesting, I'm afraid this album will probably become a boring listen rather quickly and not revisit the CD player after a few more listens. The mix on the album is ok. It's good to not hear that Kevin Shirley garbage that has plagued them for the last 5 albums. But the drums are buried and the mix overall is a little muddy for my tastes. The guitars are WAY understated, though there is a great Journey sounding solo on one of the earlier tunes, and the keys have finally been brought forward again after being non-existent for 4 albums. Labrie sounds good as usual but again, nothing extraordinary. And Portnoy may finally NOT win the Modern Drummer reader's poll after winning 9 straight years because he doesn't flex a whole lot. Yes, there are certainly those `Portnoy moments', but generally he just plays for the song. Normally, that's great! But with DT, we've come to expect a certain level of virtuosity that is just not on this album. With Train of Thought and other DT albums, I knew those albums would grow on me because there was so much to digest. And they did grow on me as I really love those prior albums (except for SDOIT). But after one listen of Octavarium, I didn't find myself saying, \\"Wow, so much to digest.\\" It was easily swallowed, digested, and passed through my bowels.<br /><br />...Now onto the scam...<br /><br />I am of the mind that DT is truly spreading themselves too thin with all the side projects and too many of their good ideas are being filtered through 15 different bands. If they would just stick with DT and put ALL their effort there, I think each new album would be a masterpiece. But why is that not happening? It's simple. Dream Theater purely exists now so the band can make money on the DT name (thanks to 'fans' like us who keep buying their records) and earn a living, while playing and writing the music they TRULY want to play and write with other musicians in other projects. It's really that simple. A DT album comes out, it sells a million copies worldwide, they make a decent chunk of change on sales, merchandise, tours, and clinics, and then they go and play with other guys because that's where their hearts lie now.<br /><br />Like it or not, this could very well be the last DT album (or maybe we'll see one more) because I think fans are starting to catch on to this shameless scam.<br /><br />Shame on you Dream Theater for bilking your fans. Shame on us for falling for it album after album.<br /><br />Feel free to email me :)row on me as I really love those prior albums (except for SDOIT). I'd like to see them continue down this path, and even become more experimental with their sound. I think Oasis still has more songs left to leave their mark.

1400032717|5.0|It has all been said below and I write only to add that, in my opinion, the plot is almost irrelevant to the book.  While there is briefly a mystery as to who killed the dog in the night, it is resolved at the midpoint of the story without any denoument and without any cleverness.  Nor does the narrator really \\"solve\\" this mystery although his actions do lead to us discovering the solution, a solution so mundane as to be in itself boring if there was no more to be said.  For those looking for a summer mystery to read, they will have to look elsewhere. <br /> <br />No, what matters in this book is how the narrator responds to the events he observes.  Getting to hear how a teenage autistic boy views the events of his world was one of the most fascinating experiences I've ever had in literature.  Christopher's experiences are both hilarious and also profoundly sad and for this reason what happens makes an interesting read, one I could not put down.  But even more, I learned more in this short book than I have from any other source as to why at least some of the autistic children I've known act the way they do.  My only concern had been whether Haddon was correct in his understanding of autism so it is gratifying to know from the autistic writer below that he is in fact accurate. <br /> <br />Even if Haddon had not gotten it right, Christopher's observations force us to look at our own world in a different light.  It is a profound observation to realize how much of our world we ignore and in fact as Christopher demonstrates, the world is a very difficult place to live unless we can ignore much of what happens around us.   <br /> <br />To me, great literature teaches about deeper reality than we see on our own and does so while being entertaining enough to hold our interest.  Haddon has done this with Curious Incident and I recommend it highly.
B0009A1AS2|5.0|Although many are divided about the previous album, Train of Thought, they may have come to a consensus about Octavarium.  The band has thankfully used more variety and has done an amazing job of giving each member a fairly equal share in the music.  It's true that Rudess has a much bigger role in this album than Train of Thought, but he definitely does not \\"dominate\\" the album.  I think many listeners feel there was too much keyboard because there was almost none on the previous album and are not used to having keyboards having importance.  I felt that Portnoy and Petrucci took a slight step back in Octavarium because they had almost total control over TOT, which doesn't mean that there weren't nasty drum fills and classic Petrucci shredding.  In terms of the singing, Octavarium brings out the best of Labrie, even though many fans criticize his abilities.  The musicianship is excellent as usual and touches upon many different styles of playing.  There are two heavier tracks on the album: The Root of All Evil and Panic Attack, both two of my favorite pieces.  The third track, These Walls, blew me away.  The song is in 6/8 (typical DT progression) and is reminiscent of the band's older stuff (Images and Words) and Scenes From a Memory.  The last song, the 24 minute epic, Octavarium, is very unusual, but a good listen, for at the 15 minute mark, the band transitions into a sick instrumental section that is very similar to Dance of Eternity.  With all this said, I honestly did not appreciate these aspects of the new DT masterpiece until about the third time listening to the CD.  My advice is to not speculate the quality of the music too quickly, but rather listen to the songs a few times over until you have fully grasped the new DT direction of 2005.
0393317552|4.0|Jared Diamond's astounding thesis on the developement of human civilizations is one that is thought provoking at the least.  The book provides sound and abundant evidence to a geographical explanation of why certain societies come to be superior over others.      Diamond is able to provide a plethora of historical and climatical evidence far above the realms of mere coincidence, striking down the age-old assumption of race superiority as a practical means for explaning modern dominance.  Do not heed over-zealous rebuttals and objections all too commonly given to this work - after all, one must establish a personal perception before making the yea/neh decision.  Criticism, after all, is the number one method for killing un-popular opinion, as one might notice through the example of Zora-Neale Hurston caught in the rush tide of the Harlem Rennaisance.    The work is not for the adventure seeker either, its romantic sounding title should not give any allusions to action or controversy.  It is based in the interest of science, not popular entertainment.    Two minor flaws persist throughout the book: an inevitable brevity in describing the culture of some societies, and a rather discouraging bias counter-productive to the book's task at hand.  Diamond occasionally flies off the handle to allude a matter-of-fact superiority of the societies whose short-falls he sets out to explain.  He provides excellent evidence to support equality of race which is often marred by over-reactionist commentary.  The reader gets the sense that Diamond would rather envoke a racial flamewar than appeal to the silent objectionalist.    Bias aside, the book is an excellent read and provides a roadmap to understanding human societies through causation and historical truth rather than the high-flung insecurities of modern supremists.
0440217563|4.0|I agree with other readers that there is SOO much to like about Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series. The Scottish phrasing was wonderful, the time travel and historical context incredibly believeable and the warmth and passion between Jamie and Claire so genuine I felt as though I were living it.  However, I also agree that parts were disturbing, especially the physical brutality in both heterosexual and homosexual contexts.   <br /> <br />I've asked myself whether any of the wonder of these books would have been diminished if those scenes had not been portrayed in such detail.  I admit I'm squeamish and perhaps overly sensitive to violence (I didn't see Mel Gibson's The Passion specifically for that reason). Once I knew what was in store, I found myself skipping pages here and there to get beyond those passages and I don't believe I lost a lot in doing so. I had the general sense of how brutal life in that time period was (and war in any timeframe) and feel I was still able to comprehend how deeply their lives, their souls and their passions were intertwined, which is really what makes these stories so amazing.

Professor Graham elegantly lays out the distinction between an investor and a speculator and makes the convincing case why you should discipline yourself to be a value investor and resist the temptation of speculation.  This book is far superior to Professor Fisher's Common Stocks and Uncommon Profits (also a favorite of Mr. Buffet's). <br /> <br />Much has been made about Jason Zweig's annotations and commentaries in these reviews.  I must admit that reading them made me hesistant to purchase this edition, but in the end my wallet won out and I bought this cheaper copy.  To put it mildly I never thought I could gain so much by spending less money.   Even having gone to law school, I found some of Professor Graham's language hard to follow, but luckily at just the right times Mr. Zweig would clarify a difficult to understand term or obscure historical reference with a footnote.  In his end of chapter commentary Mr. Zweig does a masterful job of relating Professor Graham's comments to present day (especially the internet stock speculation of the late 1990's).  Further, Mr. Zweig does a fantastic job of pulling out the most valuable gems of knowledge from each chapter and expounding upon them with real life examples.  I found Mr. Zweig's annotations to the book to be a priceless addition to this work and therefore I highly recommend this edition to anyone looking to purchase \\"The Intelligent Investor.\\"

B000089RVR|5.0|It's a grey day in (usually sunny) Florida as the outer bands of tropical storm, Arlene are starting to dump a ton of rain outside. For melancholy weather such as this, I put the perfect musical soundtrack into the CD player... Dido's \\"Life for Rent\\". To be perfectly honest, I picked this CD up at my used CD shop for the two very worst reasons anybody could ever buy a CD. One, a really pretty girl at a party told me she loved it and two, I liked the cover. Pretty bad...huh? Well, once I started playing the CD, I couldn't get that voice and the songs out of my brain! Dido has this almost haunting voice, that just stays with you. It soars over the trip-hoppy/trance like beat of the music. When she sings a song, boy do you believe it! The only way I can put it is that she really knows how to get across the emotions, that are are behind the tunes. That voice just seems to cut you to the bone and goes right through you. Earlier I had mentioned a storm reminding me of this CD and that seems to be the perfect metaphor for \\"Life for Rent\\". It's the storm that follows having your heart broken. The whole album seems to be about having love in your life and losing it. Thats my take on it. I don't know a whole lot about Dido Armstrong or her personal life. But this women must have been through one heck of a nasty romantic break-up to unleash the lyrics and emotions behind some of these tunes. Probably one of the most bitter is \\"See You When You're 40\\". She sings...\\"you think you are complicated, deep mystery to all/well it's taken me a while to see, you're not so special/all energy no meaning with a lot of words/so paper thin that one real feeling could knock you down.\\" Boy, would I hate to be on the recieving end of those lyrics! All the songs on this album are just so memorable. \\"White Flag\\" (one my favorites on the CD) at first glance is a fist pumping anthem about love. But if you really take a close look at the lyrics, the singer seems to be both obsessive and destructive about her failed relationship declaring \\"I will go down with this ship and I won't put my hands up and surrender.\\" Even gaining love shows signs of bitterness. On \\"Mary's Gone to India\\" the singer is pretty much telling the character, Mary off. Apparently Mary left for India, dumping her boyfriend, Danny. The singer is pretty meanly telling her, well you might have treated him like sh_t, but he's mine now and I'm going to treat him right! Other great songs on this album include the title song \\"Life for Rent\\" and the delightful post-vaction, \\"Sand in My Shoes\\". At least \\"Life for Rent\\" ends on a happy note with the post break-up, get out of bed tune, \\"See the Sun\\". On that song, Dido sings \\"And you probably don't want to hear tommorow's another day/but I promise you, you'll see the sun again/and you're asking me why the pain's the only way to happiness/and I promise you, you'll see the sun again.\\" That's a good thing to know. For those who hate Coldplay with a passion, the cd will probably cement those feelings even more so take away 2 stars. B00003OSTN|4.0|Joan Crawford plays \\"Mildred Pierce\\" in this sad tale of a loving mother, her willingness to do nearly anything to provide a better life for her family, and her ultimate failure to do so.  Mildred (Joan Crawford) is married to Albert `Bert'  Pierce (Bruce Bennet).   He has trouble keeping a job or providing enough money to give their 2 daughters the finer things in life.  Kay Pierce (Jo Ann Marlowe) and Veda Pierce (Ann Blythe) are Mildred's reason for living and she lavishes them with everything a child could want.  This doting behavior causes strife between Bert and Mildred due to the fact that the lifestyle Mildred wants to provide for the daughters is a financial impossibility.  Mildred sells baked goods and caters local parties from her home in an attempt to raise money for her daughters.  This furthers the rip in the family fabric, as Bert sees this as an insult to his ability to be the breadwinner.  It becomes obvious at this point that Bert and Mildred have differences that cannot be resolved.  Bert and Mildred decide to separate.  We also are introduced to Veda's horrifically flawed character as she complains that a dress her mother buys for her is nothing more than a rag, and is not good enough to be seen in public. The split between Bert and Mildred spurs her into action and she is resolved to do whatever it takes to provide the best for her Veda.  She decides that she can make money in the restaurant business since she's been making a profit selling food from home and catering parties.  Mildred is ultimately introduced to Monty Beragon (Zachary Scott) by Wally Fay (Jack Carson), her husband's ex-business partner.  Wally is a fast talking realtor, who tries to angle on Mildred at every opportunity, but goes nowhere romantically with her.  Monty Beragon comes from a wealthy family, but is apparently having financial problems, and agrees to let Mildred take possession of some of his property without paying him up front.  She agrees to pay him back in full within a year.  This property takes shape and her restaurant business launches.  She and Monty start to spend time together and eventually become romantic.  The business continues to flourish while her relationship and control with Veda starts to decline.  Veda wants more and more from her mother, and will say and do anything to get what she wants.  Veda even goes so far as to fake a pregnancy to extort $10,000 from the supposed father.  Mildred tears the check up and tells Veda to leave.  At this point Mildred and Monty start to have financial difficulties as he and Veda continue to use Mildred and spend all her hard earned money, and show absolutely no gratitude for it.  Veda eventually goes to work as a showgirl since being removed from her mother's money supply.  Mildred, in the meantime, takes a vacation and returns resolved to make amends with Veda.  She decides to buy a fancy new home and marry Monty Beragon, even though she has no respect for him and is not in love.  She does this solely to appease Veda again and try to gain her love.  Veda does come home and she and Monty once again drain Mildred financially to the point of bankruptcy.  Veda is ashamed of her mother and repays her love with the ultimate slap in the face as we see Veda's current love interest and the catalyst for violence.  The end result of all of Mildred's hard work to be a good mother backfires with horrible consequences for everyone involved.  She has poured everything into pleasing Veda and providing anything she could want, but in the end Veda still wants more.  This time however there is nothing more Mildred can do for her reprehensible daughter, and Veda finally gets what she deserves.  I would rate this film at 4 stars.  It has as much validity today as  it did in 1945 when first released.  It runs 109 min and is presented in black and white.

Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy soon realize that they have a lot of freedom due to the lack of supervision and decide to play a game of hide and seek in the house. All throughout the house there are unused rooms and passages that take them to places they had not known about. While playing this game, Lucy comes across an old wardrobe. She goes in thinking nothing of it, and finds something beyond her imagination. \\"A moment later she found that she was standing in the middle of a wood at night-time with snow under her feet and snowflakes falling though the air\\" (p 113.) B000023VR6|5.0|Dr. Dre returned to the forefront of rap with this 1999 release of 2001(Dre's always ahead of his time).  After leaving Death Row Records where he produced some of the most classic records in rap history he launched his own Aftermath Records but aside from the disappointing DR. DRE PRESENTS...THE AFTERMATH and some production work on THE FIRM laid relatively low for a period of time from late '96 until '99 when he discovered and launched the career of an unknown white rapper named Eminem.  One could say that Eminem was as responsible for bringing the already legendary Dr. Dre back as Dre was for making Eminem the megastar he became.  On the heels of the multiplatinum THE SLIM SHADY LP it was time for Dre to release his first official solo album in 7 years.  While no album by any artist may ever top THE CHRONIC, 2001 did not disappoint.  Dre proved he still had what it takes behind the boards with classic beat after classic beat updating the style he perfected on THE CHRONIC with a freshness that was still classic Dre.  On the other side of the glass, with help from Eminem and others penning lyrics, he proved himself still worthy of holding the mic.  His delivery might have rusted slighty since the last time we heard him, but Dre's not known near as much for his MC skills as being able to piece together a classic album.  And with Eminem spitting the most memorable lines, Nate Dogg returning for the sequal and introducing Xzibit to the mainstream there are plenty of lyrical highlights on this CD.  Snoop Dogg might not flow quite as fast or as smooth as he did on earlier Dr. Dre produced Death Row releases, but his voice will always be welcome over a Dr. Dre beat.  This album cemented Dr. Dre's place as a legend in rap.
B00006AW2M|4.0|A brave album, but not the best in the boys' inventory, that's for sure. 2,000 Light Years, with its haunting mellotron intro by Brian Jones was one of the best songs of the entire Psychedelic era and easily the standout song here, although the superb She's A Rainbow and The Lantern are two other great songs. <br /> <br />The Stones put out a superb single called We Love You in this general time period, and it always seemed like it should have been on Majesties, to me. <br /> <br />As for influences, if you ever read background bios on the Stones and the Beatles or even catch some of the many interviews that Paul McCartney and Mick Jagger have done over the years, you realize that the bands of the time all influenced each other, and that the Stones and The Beatles were actually friends, who hung out together. <br /> <br />Apart from the fact that many bands owed a tremendous debt to the early Blues artists, they all borrowed ideas and innovations from each other; so The Byrds, The Beach Boys, The Rolling Stones and The Beatles couldn't fail to have an effect on each other's work - but it was all amicable, with respect being the watchword. <br /> <br />Definitely worth having in your collection, but not a representative Stones album by any means. Beggar's Banquet or Let It Bleed would be a better entry point if you wanted to try out some classic Stones, although with this band, you pretty well can't go wrong by picking an album at random. <br /> <br /> <br />
0393035158|4.0|Having read a review of this book in the New York Times Book Review (written by, if I remember correctly, Susan Jacoby) I got the feeling this book would be a balm to my heathen soul, so to speak.  Considering that Harris had me at the title, there was no way I wouldn't read this book.  Indeed, right from the first chapter, he had me shouting secular humanist \\"hallelujahs\\" 'til I was hoarse (and embarrassed, considering on was on a train).  There are many passages here that should be on t-shirts, mugs, billboards, etc.  This is of course a bad idea, because that's exactly the sort of thing \\"People of Faith\\" do that annoys the hell out of me (that, and trying to change the law to conform to their personal fairy tales, but I digress).  Actually, annoying \\"People of Faith\\" is probably the sort of thing that Mr. Harris would revel in.<br /><br />One of the main themes in \\"The End of Faith\\" is that extremists are only part of the problem.  The more pernicious threat, as he sees it, comes instead from religious moderates.  By providing a support system for the extremist's core beliefs, moderates only increase the possibility that something, well, something really BAD will happen (as in rogue-nuclear-device bad).  A moderate cannot calm an extremist, because at the core, they're cut from the same cloth.  This gave me some problems at first, since after all we can't expect the Bible Belt to fall into mass apostasy, and moderates are of course, not bombing anything, so at least there's a small opening for the start of a somewhat reasonable discussion.  Harris isn't having any of it, though.  The book's title is as much a statement of purpose as a provocation.<br /><br />Along the way, we are treated to lengthy smackdowns of the Old Testament and the Koran (included are literally pages worth of Koranic verses exhorting the virtues of violence against unbelievers), and brief swipes at the religious right (yay!) and even Noam Chomsky (an unreasoned wolf in academic clothing).  There is a chapter about the neurological underpinnings of belief (Harris is completing his doctorate in neuroscience) that I had to read twice to understand, and a chapter about the philosophy of ethics and morality that totally went over my head, but then I still have trouble spelling Nietsh...uh, Nietzs...oh you know, that crazy German guy.<br /><br />The last chapter is where a lot of hard-line atheists will be disappointed.  In it, Harris prescribes a kind of logical, non-supernatural approach to Buddhist meditation as an antidote to prayer or \\"spirtitual experience.\\"  He asserts that people seem to need some sort of transcendence, so why not look Eastward, where at least the religious atmosphere is a bit less scary and violent?  A review in the secular humanist magazine Free Inquiry dismissed the idea, and indeed it left a bad taste in the reviewer's mouth.  I think he misread the chapter, but I concede where Harris leaves the matter open to misinterpretation.  I nonetheless find it an interesting avenue of investigation.<br /><br />Not long after finishing the book, I visited the author's website (samharris.org) where I found video clips of his television appearances.  I was rather unnerved to discover that he seemed to appear only on programs that would be the least hospitable to his point of view.  In one, a rude cable news screaming head dismisses him and asks if Harris is an atheist.  To my horror, Harris seems to dodge the question, and is promptly cut off.  Why couldn't he say something like \\"of course I'm an atheist, you shrieking idiot, but it goes a bit deeper than that\\"?  In clip after clip, as Harris practically quotes his book verbatim, one is left with the uncomfortable conclusion that, in the end, he's just another author desperately trying to plug his book.  Mind you, the hurricane force of this particular book is a galvanic experience that needs to be sold to at least 90% of Americans, but I think a reasoned approach to Buddhist meditation might be necessary to get rid of that unfortunate bad taste...editation might be necessary to get rid of that unfortunate bad taste...

B000929AJQ|4.0|Imagine a dance album soaked in battery acid, with its lush melodies and sledgehammer drumming slowly seeping through your ears like an unavoidable aural plague. It rushes ferocious electronic beats at you, along with an underlining sense of self-discovery and a hint of political bashing. This wave of sound and enlightenment is With Teeth. From the hushed opening beats of \\"All The Love In The World\\" to the anti-bang whimper of \\"Right Where It Belongs,\\" Nine Inch Nails' new album, With Teeth, is a more to the point, song-oriented effort than any of Trent Reznor's prior works. It's not as angry or intense as Pretty Hate Machine (1989) and The Downward Spiral (1994), so it slightly closer resembles The Fragile (1999), minus the elaborate instrumentals. The title track \\"With Teeth\\" contains an incredibly quiet piano interlude in the middle, surrounded by aggressive vocals. As to the album's first single, \\"The Hand That Feeds,\\" NIN fans either love it or hate it because of its so-called \\"accessible\\" sound. It also sounds like a call to arms signaled by Reznor to stand up against President Bush's war in Iraq, \\"What if this whole crusade's/A charade/And behind it all there's a price to be paid.\\" With Teeth is an explosive album from NIN, period; it delivers on what has been anticipated over these past six years. However, if you listen to it and do not agree, then just hit the eject button to save yourself from the auditory plague that is With Teeth.

B000002JSP|5.0|For Led Zeppelin fans, nobody expected that 1979's \\"In Through the Out Door\\" would be the last CD for the legendary quartet. This was because of the untimely death of their legendary drummer, John Bonham.   Many long-time Led Zeppelin fans were disappointed by this 8th studio album by the legendary band. Led Zeppelin had thrilled fans throughout the 1970s by its unique and innovative mix of Blues and Hard Rock.    This album would mark a change by Led Zeppelin as for the first time, the heavy use of Synthesizers were introduced.   But Led Zeppelin has always been a band that has never been short when it comes to innovation.   Despite the criticism of many, Led Zeppelin's \\"In Through the Out Door\\" shows that the innovation is alive - and I think results in one of the band's best releases. <br /> <br />Since the inception of the modern Rock and Roll era in the late 1950s, the popular music landscape has frequently undergone changes.   In the late 1970s, there were several music influences penetrating the music landscape - namely, Disco and Punk Rock.   Many traditional Rock artists were accused of selling out when incorporating new styles into their music (i.e. The Rolling Stones, Rod Stewart).   This is an unfair rap because I think it is good when Rock artists innovate.   As mentioned above, Led Zeppelin has always been a band willing to innovate.   While Led Zeppelin doesn't incorporate Disco or Punk Rock into their music, they do make use of an instrument that is widely used in those genres - the Synthesizer.     John Paul Jones was beginning to do a lot of experimentation with the Synthesizer and worked with the band to incorporate the use of it into the music.   The use of this instrument was one that seemed to disappoint the long-time fans.    However, if you listen to \\"In Through the Out Door\\", you will hear how Led Zeppelin adds a new dimension to their sound - while still maintaining their Blues and Hard Rock edge.    If you listen to artists such as MichaelJackson, you can hear how the Synthesizer sounds very synthetic - at the expense of traditional instruments.   On \\"In Through the Out Door\\", Led Zeppelin uses the Synthesizer to augment the traditional instruments. <br /> <br />Perhaps the only thing that disappoints me on this collection from a musical standpoint is that there are only 7 songs.   Here is a synopsis of each of them: <br /> <br />\\"In the Evening\\": At the beginning you will hear the use of the synthesizers with a slight middle-eastern effect.   The song then progresses into a classic Led Zeppelin Blues/Rock sound. One thing that I always liked about Led Zeppelin is that you can always single out all of the instrumentation- whether its Robert Plant's Vocals, Jimmy Page's Guitar, John Paul Jones' Bass and Keyboards, or John Bonham's drums.  In particular I think Page's guitar chords are right on the money here. <br /> <br />\\"South Bound Suarez\\":  This track also shows that Led Zeppelin hasn't abandoned their Blues roots.   This song has much more of a Honky-Tonk/50s Blues Sound.   John Paul Jones' Keyboards are really going to stand out on this track.   Plant is right on the money with his vocals. <br /> <br />\\"Fool in the Rain\\": While many have accused this song of Led Zeppelin going mainstream, I tend to disagree - this is some of their top innovation.     This song has a slight Caribbean feel to it.  However it also shows the band showcasing what they do best - jamming.    There is a jam that begins about 2 1/2 minutes into the song.   This song seems to come together perfectly.   While everyone really shines on this song, no question it's John Bonham's drumming that is your \\"MVP\\" performance on this album.  His drumming combined with the Latin/Calypso feel is incredible stuff.     <br /> <br />\\"Hot Dog\\":  Another Bluesy song.  This one also has a Honky Tonk Blues feel - but clearly sounds like a \\"Dixie\\" like song.  Once again, Robert Plant is right on the money with his vocals. <br /> <br />\\"Carouselambra\\":  This might imply another Latin sounding song, but this one serves as another Jam session for the band.   Here is where John Paul Jones shows how the synthesizers can enhance the sound of the band.  As always, the band is rock-solid with the delivery of the song. <br /> <br />\\"All My Love\\": This song was a tribute to Robert Plant's son, who had died a few years earlier.   This is another song that appeals to the mainstream fans.   Once again the synthesizers provide some terrific augmentation to the guitar and drum work.  In addition, there is one of Led Zeppelin's all-time great instrumental pieces midway through the song.   Not only is this song solid instrumentally, it is lyrically one of the band's strongest. <br /> <br />\\"I'm Gonna Crawl\\": I admit, this song took me a while to get into.  Once I did, I really liked it.   It seems like there is use of a Steel Guitar in this song. <br /> <br />The only other disappointment of this collection are the liner notes.    There is virtually nothing in the way of liner notes.   The inside of the notes do feature a list of the seven tracks, their length, and the songwriting credits.   I'm really disappointed that the lyrics are not included on this collection.   While most people who buy this album are going to be aware of who the four band members are, it still would have been nice to see a listing of the band members.   However, the liner notes are only a small part of the package here.   The bottom line is that from a musical standpoint, this album has it all.    While some core fans may not care for it, I still think that many will.  This album might have shown us what might have been in-store for 1980s Led Zeppelin - I think they would have even gotten more popular than they were in the 70s.  This is also a great album if you are more of a mainstream fan.   Overall - highly recommended.

B000002GVO|5.0|The Eagles reached the 80.000.000 mark in 2002. Eighty million records sold - not just of \\"Hotel California\\", of course, but of their entire catalogue. <br />Still, this album is rightly considered their artistic peak as well as their commercial one. Everybody who knows music knows \\"Hotel California\\", one of the ten best-selling LPs of all time (even if you include compilations). Or at least they know the title track, that one tremendously evocative piece of \\"west coast rock\\" which threatens to overshadow everything else on the album. <br /> <br />If you think \\"Hotel California\\" is a bad song, you're a fool. Yeah, sorry about that, but it's the truth. This might not be your kind of music, but you have to recognize how tremendously well-wrought that song is, both musically and lyrically. It's not my favorite song, excactly, I'm mostly into blues music, but I still think it's an amazing piece of work, right up there with \\"Stairway To Heaven\\" and \\"Hey Jude\\". The partiture reads a classical chamber piece...at one point eight electric and acoustic guitars are playing at the same time! <br /> <br />Everybody has heard \\"Hotel California\\" so many times that they forget what an incredible musical achievement it actually is - but just listen to Don Felder's 16-bar solo immediately after the last verse. That has to be one of the greatest rock guitar solos ever committed to tape. <br />And while none of the other seven songs are as well known, the rest of the album is uniformly excellent as well. The other two singles were Glenn Frey's easy country-rock shuffle \\"New Kid In Town\\" and the hard rock stomper \\"Life In The Fast Lane\\", and while nothing matches \\"Hotel California\\", those songs would be the two shining highlights on any other album. <br /> <br />This album is less country and more mainstream rock than anything the Eagles had done previously, mainly because Bernie Leadon had been replaced with hard rock veteran Joe Walsh (who provides the main riff to \\"Life In The Fast Lane\\", and plays a number of sizzling solos), and the three-guitar onslaught of Frey, Felder and Walsh have arena-rock heft. The sound is big and vibrant, and while \\"HC\\" could have used one or two up-tempo songs to \\"make up\\" for the numerous slow tunes, you really can't say anything bad about these eight selections. <br />\\"Wasted Time\\" is a beautiful ballad, \\"The Last Resort\\" is a scathing political statement for which the Eagles also remembered to write good music. And Joe Walsh's mellow \\"Pretty Maids All In A Row\\" is a minor song only because it sits next to the mighty \\"Hotel California\\". <br />Randy Meisner's last Eagles song, \\"Try And Love Again\\" is a lovely mid-tempo rocker with a melodic country feel and some great ringing lead guitar by Glenn Frey, and the tough stop-and-go rocker \\"Victim Of Love\\" is equally excellent. <br />This wonderful album finds the Eagles at their peak. It belongs in any serious collection of popular music.

B00005OM5L|4.0|Eric Clapton was touring behind the excellent \\"From The Cradle\\" album when this concert was recorded, and the set list includes a lot more genuine blues numbers than most latter-day live Clapton.    He is backed by an excellent combo which includes Andy Fairweather-Low and Muddy Waters' harpist Jerry Portnoy, and Clapton's own playing is delightfully gritty. He plays sizzling slide guitar on a terrific \\"It Hurts Me Too\\", and lets loose with a series of raw blues solos during Freddy King's \\"I'm Tore Down\\" and Eddie Boyd's \\"Five Long Years\\", and even pulls off a better-than-average \\"Hoochie Coochie Man\\".  Eric Clapton's vocals are as good as I've ever heard him, and fans of his bluesier side should definitely pick up this fine concert video. DVD. Whatever.  This recording should have been released on CD...it is much, much better than the recent \\"One More Car, One More Rider\\".

B0009A1AS2|3.0|What is the soul of a musical group? What is their identity, even as members and styles change over time? What is their worldview? I have asked this question about Dream Theater, a group I have been investigating for several months after being somewhat impressed with the Liquid Tension releases.<br /><br />The instrumentalists are virtuosos in their genre. (I doubt that any of them could play jazz, however, except possibly Mr. Rudess.) At their best, they can create driving, dramatic, intense, yet sophisticated music. That is what is appealing about Dream Theater. Their instrumentals shine. However, there is a heavy darkness in much their music, especially resident the lyrics--especially lyrics by Mr. Portnoy, who seems to use the music as a confessional of sorts. \\"Honor Thy Father\\" from \\"Train of Thought\\" is punishing, heart-breaking, and brutal. I nearly cry sometimes when I hear it. Mr. Portnoy may be speaking from desperate experience, but I do not know. The obscenity and the rage is painful. Mr. Portnoy also repeatedly writes of his problems with addiction. One may feel for him, even pray for him, but the effect is overly self-focused and depressing.<br /><br />Now on to this effort. Instead of making detailed comments on particular pieces, a few general remarks are in order. First, Mr. Petrucci is a world-class heavy metal/progressive rock guitarist. He plays with both speed and feeling. He is not a shredding machine. Therefore, he should have had more of a presence here, since he supercharges the music when he is let loose. Amazingly, several songs lack guitar solos entirely, even the more blistering ones where he would shine. Second, the lyrics alternate from sorry cliches (\\"The Answer is Within\\") to more dark protestations (\\"Panic Attack\\") and raging (\\"Never Enough\\") to tepid social commentary about September 11 several years late (\\"Sacrificed Sons\\"), to more desperate dark ramblings (\\"Octavarium,\\" which, once again [for some reason], brings up mental illness, as did \\"Six Degrees of Inner Turbulence\\"). \\"Octavarium\\" has particularly disturbing sections where words are nonsensically thrown together. Insanity strikes once again. Why write like this? What purpose is served by it? Does one of the band members suffer over the insanity of a loved one? None of the pieces rise to the lyrical level of \\"Endless Sacrifice\\" (from \\"Train of Thought\\") with its sense of lament mixed with appreciation for someone willing to stick with a challenging, long-distance relationship.<br /><br />Musically, the recording alternates between harder, driving pieces and more pop/schlock sounding tunes. (Unlike other reviewers, I cannot compare the styles to other heavy metal groups, since I don't know of any to which they are often compared.) The ballads are rather insipid and prosaic if not embarrassing. Mr. LaBrie sounds better in the studio than live, but, nevertheless, he just gets in the way of the music too often. (And his screaming, heavy breathing, and hissing I could live without.) If the lyrics were thoughtful or searching or poetic, it would be another story. But they are not. Instead, they wildly alternate between the nihilistic and the utopian. Which is it? If \\"the answer lies within\\" why are is there a \\"panic attack\\" and lunacy at large once again? And why all the high-profile rage if \\"the answer is within\\"? Maybe it isn't within. Maybe it is somewhere else, somewhere higher.<br /><br />Nevertheless...there are a few good chops displayed in the better moments when the group speeds through their multi-layered intensities. Just don't attend this theater for a well-integrated worldview.ss, as did \\"Six Degrees of Inner Turbulence\\"). \\"Octavarium\\" has particularly disturbing sections where words are nonsensically thrown together. Insanity strikes once again. Why write like this? What purpose is served by it? Does one of the band members suffer over the insanity of a loved one? None of the pieces rise to the lyrical level of \\"Endless Sacrifice\\" (from \\"Train of Thought\\") with its sense of lament mixed with appreciation for someone willing to stick with a challenging, long-distance relationship.<br /><br />Musically, the recording alternates between harder, driving pieces and more pop/schlock sounding tunes. (Unlike other reviewers, I cannot compare the styles to other heavy metal groups, since I don't know of any to which they are often compared.) The ballads are rather insipid and prosaic if not embarrassing. Mr. LaBrie sounds better in the studio than live, but, nevertheless, he just gets in the way of the music too often. (And his screaming, heavy breathing, and hissing I could live without.) If the lyrics were thoughtful or searching or poetic, it would be another story. But they are not. Just don't attend this theater for a well-integrated worldview.

B000022TSH|5.0|\\"Chinatown\\", staring Jack Nicholson, is the quinessential Los Angeles detective story.  Over the years some more recent films, such as LA Confidential and Mulholland Falls, sought to redevelop the same themes.  Both, in my view, failed to live up to the high standards established in Chinatown.  Chinatown begins with an interesting plot :  the woman who had arrived in his private detective office turned out to be someone other than the person he thought.  The original woman had wanted to spy on her husband to see if he was cheating.  The actual woman had never met the character played by Jack Nicholson.  From this twist early in the movie, all other events follow:  Nicholson uncovers a plot by the Department of Water and Power to divert water stream flows to an area in the  Valley, whose developer is intending to reap extra profits from purchasing the land, quite cheaply, and being able to sell at a profit once knowledge of the irrigation supply that will be provided to the Valley will be made public.
0670033375|2.0|There was obviously someone awake in the sales department when coming up with the title of this book but it really was not as scintillating as I had hoped.  Collapse starts out kind of slow, with some rambling on about Diamond's experiences in Montana, before it gets interesting.  The middle section is decent, concerning societies that have collapsed and the various reasons why and then the end gets kind of preachy, about what we can do to save-the-spotted-owl and that sort of thing.  For those who have read \\"Guns, Germs, and Steel\\", Diamond's exhausive (and exhausting) statistic-laden writing style will be familiar but, if you have not read his earlier work, don't pick up \\"Collapse\\" expecting a white-knuckle thriller.  It is really more of an academic tome than popular reader.  In all, I think many people will be duped into expecting more excitement from \\"Collapse\\" than it delivers.

B000000W5L|5.0|Ah, the Stones at their best is, arguably, Mick Taylor at his best.  This may be the finest and the worst hour for this band (it has certainly been argued both ways) but no doubt about the power of \\"Ventilator Blues\\", the ONLY Stones song to which Taylor was given a writng co-credit.  It's certainly his lick and it's as hot,sweaty,Delta Blues swampy as the Stones would ever get in their career.  Taylor was one of the hottest and most technically proficient lead guitarists of the time-Jagger and Richards have admitted as much in recent interviews-and songs like \\"On Down the Line\\" let him stretch out a bit with his searing slide guitar attack. He added a dimension of fluidity in his guitar style that the band lacked prior to his arrival in '69 and never had again after his departure in '75.  Sadly, his solo career has been spotty but has shown brilliance in the few offerings he has made.  I realize this is all a bit narrow in focus, but so much has been said already of this album and the songs which folks are all too familiar with that,well, I just wanted to see the guy get some credit for what is clearly the sound most of the public readily identifies as the Stones and to what a tremendous degree Mick Taylor contributed to it.

B00005NKKZ|5.0|This album was the most successful in the career of Simon and Garfunkel, deservedly so. They had recorded plenty of great music before this but the overall strength of this album puts it ahead of their other albums. Curiously, the title track was the only UK hit from the album although it made number one. In America, the album yielded four hits, these being the title track, The boxer, Cecilia and El condor pasa (If I could).<br /><br />I've heard various stories about the origin of the title track. One story is that a bridge in Tiverton (Devon, England) inspired the song. Another story is that the song is not really a love song at all but is actually about drugs. I've listened very carefully to the song and I eventually realized that this is possible (the drugs, rather than a lover, being the bridge) but I, like nearly everybody else on this planet, will continue to regard it as a love song. It is, of course, one of the finest love songs in popular music history.<br /><br />With such an impressive title track, you might expect it to overshadow the rest of the album but this is not so. Quite apart from the three other American hits, the album also includes Keep the customer satisfied and Baby driver, both of which must surely have been considered for release as singles, as well as a live version of Bye bye love (acknowledging one of their main influences, the Everly brothers) and some other interesting but less famous songs - So long Frank Lloyd Wright, The only living boy in New York and Song for the asking.<br /><br />This classic album deserved all the success that came its way. Many of these tracks have appeared on compilations down the years, but the original album (now re-mastered with improved sound quality and bonus tracks) stands on its own merits.

B000777J2S|4.0|I love this album.       Antony rolls his vocals with a lovely, dramatic execution.   (It sounds like he's swallowing his voice while alternating his notes/octaves.) These lyrics are ripe with contemporary pain and overcoming.        This is one of the few albums I can listen to every day and still be moved by the songs.         Rufus Wainwright joins Antony in a very short track on this seemingly incomplete album. Other guests include Boy George and Lou Reed.      These songs-- they are strangely original and powerfully emotive. Track one (\\"Hope there's Someone\\") is especially beautiful; it's one of the most heartwrenching songs I've heard in years. It's like that beautiful kind of aching that some songs make you feel, as though you've been cut by a familiar blade. My Lady Story is the best overall song.     If you listen to \\"Hope There's Someone\\" with good headphones, alone in the dark, you might even be moved enough to shed a few tears.     I value this album at 4.5 stars. If it boasted a few more songs, then the talent of this band could easily earn 5 stars album after album. This music fills a gap in today's music, and it does it quite well.     This type of music is not well-suited to all, (like Coldplay and Modest Mouse seem to be). But those who do love this won't care about ubiquitous radioplay, because they will be reeling from the intense aethestic grandeur of this album, of Antony's tremulous, soulful vocals.     I'm tempted to say that their self-titled debut album is better, but it really isn't superior. They are different, but equally majestic.

0060005696|4.0|This book aims to explain that Americans literally get too many options for their own good and it accomplishes that goal admirably well.  The book is at its best, however, when it relates how the human mind operates before, during, and after making a decision. <br /> <br />Schwartz spends about half the book laying out the ways in which each of us conciously or subconsciously compare ourselves to others, get accustomed to new levels of fortune or misfortune, and constantly seek to improve our lot even when it no longer behooves us to do so.  The ideas he lays out are excellent for improving your own approach to life or to help you understand what drives other people. <br /> <br />Highly recommended for people who enjoy social-sciences and the often irrational workings of the human mind.

Christopher, on top of being a teen, and not having a mother, has autism, a spectrum disorder.  When Wellington, a neighbor's dog is murdered with a garden fork, Christopher is determined to catch the dog's killer.  The chapters are numbered using only prime numbers, because it is told by Christopher, and Christopher likes prime numbers. 1400032717|5.0|Meet Christopher Boone - an autistic teenager.  His favorite colo r is red and he despises anything yellow or brown.  He lives with his father.  And he's just decided to solve the mystery of Who Killed His Neighbor's Dog.   <br /> <br />The story is much more than just a simple whodunit, however, and the mystery really takes a back seat to the many uncomfortable and complicated truths that Christopher finds as he investigates the crime.   <br /> <br />More than just a mystery, the story is a coming-of-age tale of a teenager in England.  Christopher has a father, who he lives with.  His father is obviously very dedicated but is only human and has a whole bunch of issues to deal with himself - not the least of which is raising an autistic child with no mother around to help.     <br /> <br />Were this story not told in first-person POV, we might feel sorry for Christopher.  But his rational decision making ability, combined with his very real (though sometimes unrealistic) dreams and aspirations make him understandable and complex.   <br /> <br />I won't reveal any of the plot points that deal with the mystery because the investigation is a real joy to read.  It is also very funny at times.  It's also sad in parts, too, usually when the reader understand more about the situation than Christopher does.   <br /> <br />I recently re-read this book and was delighted with the way Mark Haddon has created such a wonderful and totally believeable story.  This is a great read and one that will not disappoint.
B00003CXD5|5.0|I watched \\"The Wages of Fear\\" last night which was largely about vagabond Europeans in a South American country.  It  reminded me of \\"The Treasure of the Sierra Madre\\" in many ways; the vagabond \\"whites\\" in the Third World, several men who are down on their luck take a chance on making some big money, the riches gained were lost due to their inability to cope with what they had gotten.  Both movies were excellent but my deference still leans to \\"The Treasure of the Sierra Madre\\" for a number of reasons. <br /> <br />The direction is excellent in both movies but my nod goes to Huston for doing what a director ought to do best; make the most of each scene to tell the story.  There was so much meaning in each step of the movie that we were able come to know the characters without having it all spelled out.  Clouzot (in \\"The Wages of Fear\\") did well but needed 30 minutes more to accomplish the same results. <br /> <br />The acting was also terrific in both movies but the trio of Holt, Huston and Bogart was in a class by themselves.  Tim Holt essentially played the straight man to Walter Huston and Humphrey Bogart.  Walter Huston won the Best Supporting Actor Oscar that year and deservedly so.  However, the star of the show is Fred C. Dobbs played so well by Humphrey Bogart.  To witness his gradual descent into the cesspool of greed was certainly deserving of an Oscar as well (no offense to Laurence Olivier but who watches his \\"Hamlet\\" these days)?   <br /> <br />Finally, there's the script.  Both directors got involved with their movie's script but Huston had a better act to start with.  It was through the book by the same name that I got acquainted with the author B. Traven.  His was and remains a brilliant perspective on the corruption of man by the influence of an expanding society (in other words, he's an anarchist).  The focus was on greed in \\"Treasure\\" and it culminated in a closing scene that put everything in its' proper perspective.  \\"Fear\\" tried to do the samebut stumbled somewhat in the process. <br /> <br />Both movies are worth seeing but \\"The Treasure of the Sierra Madre\\" is a movie I stick with each and everytime I come across it while channel surfing.  It is a classic of American Cinema.
B00005JKJA|4.0|It has been established beyond a reasonable doubt that David Lynch is a pretentious boor, and aside from artsy effects and fancy camera angles, most of his films lack Significance.  Muholland Drive is the exception.  Unfortunately, it is also his most misunderstood work.  It starts with an attempted assassination foiled by a freak accident, then cuts to a surreal vingette, then proceeds as a classic \\"film noir\\" thriller for the next hour or so, before suddenly spinning out of control in a whirlwind of confusion.  I began to think that this was some more artsy silliness, but then the unthinkable occured -- it all came together and began to make perfect sense!  This film is about the choices people make, and how each choice can potentially create a new reality.  Classic Quantum physics (which I believe to be deeply flawed) postulates that literally hundreds of alternate realities are co-existing side by side (BS), and this film shows us about a half-dozen such realities -- and what happens when the barriers between them are partially lifted.  Added to the mix are a number of demi-god type entities masquerading as humans in order to physically interact with those they seek to influence.  Most of Lynch's films are notable only for a handful of good scenes -- this one was good nearly all the way through.  Impressive!

B0006IIPIK|2.0|As a rapidly aging fanboy, it pains me to write this, but I wasn't crazy about this movie like I wanted to be.<br /><br />Now that the dust has settled, it's clear that Sky Captain has not taken the world by storm. In fact, it can be looked upon as not just a disappointment but a box office failure. The critics didn't go as gaa-gaa over it either. I had to wonder why. It sure seemed like it would hit it out of the park but after finally seeing on Sunday, I've got some idea what happened.<br /><br />1. The script. Yeah, 'fraid so.  Writer/director Kerry Conran may be a visionary, but a wordsmith, he ain't. (Sound familiar, Mr. Lucas?) The characters were mostly flat, the dialogue didn't crackle (this is not a quotable movie) and the jokes fell flat, the worst of which being the stupid and inappropriate line \\"Cold air makes nipples hard.\\" Yuck. Sure there were lots of ideas bandied about in the story but there was no real focus . It doesn't build. It just kind of...happens.<br /><br />2. Film references. Sure they're fun when they are few and far between, but it seemed like almost every scene needed an asterisk for the footnote below. Tarantino almost did in Kill Bill the same way. Maybe it's my problem. I get all of the references and I find it distracting. It's really time to give The Wizard of Oz a rest.<br /><br />3. The lack of a decent villain. The Olivier stuff was so underdone, it comes off as just a conceit, like Fred Astaire dancing with a vacuum cleaner.<br /><br />4. Jude Law. He looks great, just like the movie itself, but he's too soft-spoken and, as a result, doesn't come off that heroic to me. And I may be killed for saying this (oh, what's one more thing...) but why was Sky Captain a Brit? I really think this character should have been an All American guy, unless it all took place in England or London instead of New York. And what is it with this guy anyway? Chris Rock was right on the money. For awhile, he was in a movie a week. Sky Captain I Heart Huckabees, Alfie, Closer...I hear he's a porter on The Polar Express too. Who does he think he is... Ben Stiller? Don't get me wrong. I like Jude Law, certainly a lot better than I do Colin Farrell, but he didn't pull this character off for me. He seemed more like Leslie Howard. I didn't want Ashley Wilkes saving the world. I wanted Rhett Butler in a pilot's uniform. And while we're at it, less Gwyneth Paltrow and more Angelina Jolie...<br /><br />5. The CGI. It is wonderful. Whatever works in this film is due to the brilliance of the effects. However...(okay don't spit on your screens)...I think it's overkill. Too much, too soon in the early stages left me almost yawning by the end. It seemed to be less of a movie and more of a demo reel. In fact, I think it would have made a great short subject. Stretched out to a full-length feature, the seams started to show.<br /><br />Okay, I've dumped all over this movie and I feel rotten about it. I really do. There's nothing I would have liked better than to have embraced it and championed its cause, to chide those who make cah-rap like National Treasure popular, but ignore the fine work of an emerging new talent. But I can't. Chalk this up as a noble failure. Not awful, but not great either. It falls into that middle ground somewhere and that's kind of like Purgatory. I do think Kerry Conran should be given another shot to strut his stuff, but for God's sakes...give him a collaborator next time. He needs guidance. Otherwise, he'll end up in the Where Are They Now? column next to the director of Tron..I hear he's a porter on The Polar Express too. Who does he think he is... Ben Stiller? Don't get me wrong. I like Jude Law, certainly a lot better than I do Colin Farrell, but he didn't pull this character off for me. He seemed more like Leslie Howard. I didn't want Ashley Wilkes saving the world. I wanted Rhett Butler in a pilot's uniform. And while we're at it, less Gwyneth Paltrow and more Angelina Jolie... <br />5. The CGI. It is wonderful. Whatever works in this film is due to the brilliance of the effects. However...(okay don't spit on your screens)...I think it's overkill. Too much, too soon in the early stages left me almost yawning by the end. It seemed to be less of a movie and more of a demo reel. In fact, I think it would have made a great short subject. Stretched out to a full-length feature, the seams started to show. <br />Okay, I've dumped all over this movie and I feel rotten about it. I really do. B0000CABBW|5.0|When you go to the video store looking for films with positive role models for kids (and adults!), with an inspirational message that you can accomplish something if you put your mind to it, you typically will find almost nothing.  Worse, even movies with a fraction of a positive message will be so silly or idiotic that watching them as an adult is torture.  With \\"Whale Rider\\" you get a movie that adults and teens (and many pre-teens) can both watch and enjoy.<br /><br />As Roger Ebert pointed out in his review of \\"Whale Rider,\\" something is horribly wrong with a ratings system that gives a movie like this a PG-13 rating.  Just watch this next to a movie like \\"Dodgeball\\" with its objectification of women, toilet humor and sexual innuendo.  Both movies have the same rating!  Don't be fooled.  The average 12 year old _should_ be watching \\"Whale Rider\\" while \\"Dodgeball\\" shouldn't be viewed even by 14 year olds.  All of this has me wondering about about the sanity and intelligence of the ratings board.<br /><br />As many have pointed out, Keisha Castle-Hughes puts in a superb performance.  Ditto for the rest of the cast.<br /><br />Perhaps even better than the performances are the positive roles played by most characters.  The kids are intelligent, confident and curious.  The adults are generally supportive and wise.  While the males in the movie have obvious faults, this movie is about them as it is about \\"girl power.\\"  There's a scene where Keisha's character is riding a bike with her grandfather and a loving glance passes between them.  How rare it is to see such imagery - a father figure bonding with a child - in movies or TV!  \\"Whale Rider\\" isn't just about celebrating a girl's empowerment.  It's also about showing the love between male parental figures and their own personal growth as their children mature.<br /><br />One caveat: \\"Whale Rider\\" is not typical Hollywood popcorn fare.  Viewers with short attention spans or those who hate all foreign film style filmswill likely not like this movie.  Still, \\"Whale Rider\\" is an excellent start to open the eyes of a youth (or an adult) to ideas outside of what the studies usually throw at us.<br /><br />Bottom line: We'd all be better off if we had more movies like this.

B00008AWOG|5.0|Still Life sees Opeth hitting a style of death metal that is so original, odd and perfect that it can only be called a work of genius. They manage to orchestrate every part of every song to sound practically folkloric, with the super heavy guitars combined with Mikael's vocals sounding as much like a folk song as the slower parts. I'm not sure how they do it, but something about how great his death vocals are, and how well the instruments are played/produced just gives it this eary medieval feel. Something orchestral death metal bands like Dimmu Borgir have tried to do, but Opeth do it without even having the orchestra. <br /> <br />Compared to their other albums,  Still Life is slowed down a bit, as well as having more accoustic parts(and they either go full out death metal, or completely quiet accoustic, none of the clean vocals over heavy guitars like on  My Arms, Your Hearse). Truly a masterfully put together and performed album, I highly suggest any fan of metal, or even music in general check this out.(Even if you don't like metal... Opeth were the first badn with cookie monster vocals I ever liked)
B0009A1AS2|4.0|If there is one band on the planet that has defined there sound on changing their forumula evertime they go into the studio, this is the band. This time around its no exception. <br /> <br />With their previous release TOT, the first listen was extremely alientating because of the massive change made to the bands sound, this album is no exception. The first listen turned me off, I was very shocked by the extreme they decided to experiment with; but as with TOT (train of thought) the second listen really reveals the genious of this album. <br /> <br />This is probably one of the most stunning DT releases in years. It is both heavy, but can be extremely light. With the intro \\"The Root Of All Evil,\\" which is the third track in the AA (alcoholics anonyimus) series, it opens on a very solid Alice in Chains influenced rocker. The one thing that may turn fans off from this track is the lack of a seven string guitar which has been the center piece of the rythm section for this continuing story, but none the less its a great opener. <br /> <br />The four tracks to note on this album are \\"I walk besided you\\" which is a masterful Coldplay influenced love song, that rates up their with awakes \\"Lifting Shadows Off A Dream.\\" The song is probably the most accessible on the album and might be the first real attempt at DT attempting a mainstream song. Expect to hear this one on commerical radio.  <br /> <br />The second track is \\"Panic Attack\\" a buzz saw shreder, where petrucci and portnoy show off the metal roots once again, in an almost new-metal fashion. This song is both heavy and edgy, sporting some of the best written lyrics Petrucci has done in a very long time.  <br /> <br />Next is \\"Sacrificed Sons\\" which is a nice moderate 6/8 piece which displays some of the best progressive elements this band has put together in years. Lyrically it's in the same continum as TOT's \\"In the Name of God\\" and is just as well accomplished. From it's Iron Maiden harmonies, to its more edgy keyboard arrangements this is a definately a track you'll find yourself listening to over and over again.  <br /> <br />Lastly and certainly not least is the title track \\"Octavarium,\\" a 24 minuet epic in the vein of \\"A Change of Seasons.\\" This song is incredible, with seemless transistions and plays on many of the greatest progressive rock bands of the 70's, but even with these older influcnces this piece is simply timeless. From the emotionally impacting lyrics, to the insane arragements of the instruments this simply one of the best tracks DT has done EVER!  <br />  <br />With this album, the main things to note, is Rudess taking the forefront of the lead section, and displaying some of the best written keyboards this band has seen in a long time. With Petrucci standing back a little bit and not being so shred heavy, Rudess has the room he deserves to show his great contribution to the band.  <br /> <br />Also is James LeBrie's singing, which definately blends and sours in some of the best DT songs that have been released in years. His emotion impacts every track with an absolutely stunning fashion, whether it be his strong balading in \\"The Answers Lie Within\\" or screaming frenzy that would make Danny Filth jealous at the end of the title track \\"Octavarium\\" he defintatly adds to the artistic value of this incredible set list.  <br /> <br />As stated before this Cd will take multiple listens before you are comfortable with the arrangements and can see the masterful performances that have been put together on this album; but once you have you will find that a stripped down DT with tight arrangments works just as well as the more complex arrangements that have comprised their previous works.

B00005JMFQ|4.0|What's most enjoyable about Love Actually, besides the terrific scoring (inventive use of pop songs to bridge from one story to the next) is the inspired casting.  Along with wonderful comic bits from Bill Nighy and the actor playing Colin (those two alone were worth the price of admission), several gifted actors do themselves proud. Case in point: Sarah, hopelessly in love with a co-worker and emotionally strangled by caring for her brain-damaged brother, could have been a bathetic mess in the hands of anyone less talented than Laura Linney.  I was also impressed with Alan Rickman and Emma Thompson, totally believable as a married-with-children couple who deal with each other comfortably on an everyday basis, but who are thrown for an emotional loop over an office romance.  And Colin Firth (okay, I do have a teeny crush on this guy and am not totally reliable as a critic!) is the only actor I know who could convincingly sell the writer-loves-housemaid story.   <br /> <br />What's less satisfying is the director's overreliance on his stock-in-trade story resolutions.  Curtis always has to include a mad dash for the airport to get two characters together -- in this movie, there are TWO mad dashes -- and Prince Charming must always rescue Cinderella from a drab life with a dramatic flourish (in this case, two Princes, Colin Firth and Hugh Grant).  Curtis uses his gimmicks with charm and skill, but they still feel gimmicky and one longs for more surprises.   <br /> <br />Two other minor carps: (1) I am willing to suspend disbelief long enough to pretend that an 11 year old boy can learn to play the drums expertly in two weeks, but I refuse to accept that on the very night of the big show,  he's still in his room learning the basics.  (2) If Hugh Grant is cast as a P.M. in his late 40's or early 50's, for heaven's sake put a little gray at his temples or something.  Grant looks 25 here, negating the intended older man/younger woman aspect of his relationship with Natalie and rendering Emma Thompson's greeting of her \\"big brother\\" late in the movie a little silly. <br /> <br />One final comment, not on the movie itself but about some of the reactions to it:  I'm bemused by the postings that claim  Curtis' casual use of interracial couplings represents some sort of P.C. gone amok. This demonstrates a complete ignorance of the British sensibility on race.  Class differences are everything in British culture, NOT the black-white divide as is the case in America.  <br /> <br />Those who see a \\"left-wing agenda\\" in a totally unpolitical movie like Love Actually could vastly benefit from learning something of other cultures and mores, as well as checking their own biases in the mirror.

B0009A40ES|4.0|Mary Harron's American Psycho (based on the infamous Bret Easton Ellis novel) is really quite a brilliant movie. I recall seeing it five years ago when it first came out, but never really appreciated it much until I saw it again recently. I remember liking it when I first saw it, but found it rather disturbing. Watching it again, I realized what a brilliant comedy it actually is. It's not a thriller at all, it's completely a dark comedy. A very dark comedy. It brilliantly satirizes the \\"yuppie\\" lifestyle by portraying young businessmen as hollow, soulless robots whose only concerns are: A) having an expensive apartment, B) Having a nice, stylish business card and C) Getting reservations to the nicest, most expensive restaurants in town. Director Harron portrays these people almost as inhuman, and in the case of Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale), unfeeling and homicidal. Christian Bale gives an amazing performance as Bateman the yuppie psycho. Bale alone makes the film worth watching. His character is cold, arrogant and able to murder an innocent person without batting an eyelash. There's a very memorable scene where Bateman slaughters a coworker with an axe while discussing the music of Huey Lewis and the News. Christian Bale is always believable as the meticulous, obsessive psycho.    I feel that as a whole, American Psycho doesn't completely work. Towards the end, it feels a little bit aloof and ends rather abruptly. There's really not much of a conventional story, so that detracts from it a little bit. However, the movie is so well directed and acted and so on-target with its satire, that I can easily overlook its flaws. Don't watch it expecting a horror movie or a suspense thriller. Many people are bound to misunderstand it, but American Psycho is really an intelligent, razor-sharp dark comedy. If you like dark humor and hate shallow, materialistic people then by all means check out American Psycho immediately.
B0002NRRAG|2.0|Her cover of Leonard Cohen's \\"Dance Me To The End Of Love\\" rivals the original.  But the rest of the album is pretty bland.  She has a very good voice that's almost just like Billie Holliday but not quite.  Her backing band is very good but just not good enough.  Although many people hate her, Norah Jones had found her own voice and that's why her first album was so great.  Madeleine Peyroux has yet to find her own voice, both literally and figuratively speaking.  If she does, she'll become a much more accomplished artist.  But until then, save yourself the money and just download the Cohen cover.

B000003CMB|5.0|I have many regrets in my life. At the top of this rather long list, along with never stepping foot on another planet, is missing the Allman Brothers' Fillmore East concert in 1971. Why, you ask? Buy this landmark recording and you will understand.    The Allman Bros, in the days of Duane Allman (who, in my opinion, is probably the best slide guitarist to ever pick up a bottleneck) were the best live band, and this recording illustrates this fact beautifully. Through the seven recordings pieced together here, the band keeps you on the edge of your seat, and sometimes knocks you off.     THe whole band starts out white-hot with a scathing rendition of \\"Statesboro Blues.\\" Dickey Betts is a little stiff on the first couple tunes, but he soon is pushed to the title of blues master by Duane. Then comes a reworking of Elmore James' \\"Done Somebody Wrong,\\" Which is probably my least favorite on the album, but nevertheless, a great song. The band cruises through five more, some reaching marathon lengths, like \\"Whipping Post,\\" which is worth every second.    The true highlight of the album, though, is the brilliant cover of T-Bone Walker's \\"Stormy Monday.\\" The musicianship is superb,and Gregg's vocals (and organ, I might add) are top-notch. The amazingly terrific solos are played atop one of the best-sounding rhythm sections in the biz, which is the recipe for blues perfection.     As far as the improvisation goes, Allman and Betts are on the same level as the best of the best. In fact I think it may be truthful to say that they are the best. Allman's slide is like quicksilver rolling over his strings, and through every song e doesn't repeat a lick. He has become my idol, and I have tried in vain to become the replacement Duane Allman since I first heard this album. The crowd eggs him on maniacally, and he is quick to hush and satisfy them with his relaxed and thoughtful way of playing, sometimes (like at the 11-minute mark of \\"In memory of Elizabeth Reed, and throughout mostof \\"Whipping Post\\") working the band into a frenzy. Barry Oakley matches him and Dickey perfectly, while Butch Trucks and triple-J belt out tight thunder.     Everything on the album is blues and rock perfection, with incredibly quick responses from the rhythm section. I dream of traveling back in time and seeing that legendary concert, but since I know that is impossible, I settle for this recording, which is as close as it gets to taking you to the making of the greatest live album of all time.

It's hard to deny the 80's influence on this album- and it will no doubt be huge.  The songwriting is a bit weak this time around- but overall a pretty solid record.

B00008S2VG|5.0|I can say to all of you right now that I am not just another diehard Madonna fan who automatically loves every album she puts out simply because of the name behind it.  American Life is the first Madonna album I ever heard, and it is what inspired me to look into her more and buy her other albums.  I feel like this album crashed and burned mostly because of the fact that she chose to release the song where she raps as her first single.  Yes, rap artists tend to be black, male, and Ebonics-ridden.  Yes, rap music tends to be about \\"street\\" themes.  That doesn't mean that a white girl who actually SOUNDS white when she raps and raps about something other than being \\"gangsta\\" or having sex is a bad rapper.  If anything, Madonna does what Lauryn Hill and The Fugees did:  shows listeners that rapping began with people seeing how many bars they could rhyme together to a beat.  \\"Bling-bling\\" and \\"hoes\\" and all that came later when rappers found out that they could use those topics to sell albums. <br /> <br />Now that I'm done ranting, onto the album's analysis.  I feel that this album is very musically well-crafted (which is to be expected from Madonna, it seems).  The lyrics are more simple than what we grew accustomed to with her previous two albums, but I don't think this is because she has suddenly lost her songwriting ability.  Clearly, Madonna is a very intelligent woman, and she could have chosen more elaborate words if she wanted to.  However, I think she felt that the messages on this album needed to be driven home hard, and the best way to deliver an important message is short and to the point.  She didn't want any unnecessary decoration in her lyrics, choosing, instead, to make them more colloquial.  This album beautifully represents an intelligent, artistic, brave woman at her most recent and mature point of her recording career.  I hope that the reviews and sales of this album don't prevent her from making more because we cannot afford to lose any more true artists when pop culture is in the state it's in today.
