When Roth was their lead singer,the songs were fun and juvenile,and when Hagar was with the group,even though Van Halen had some juvenile songs with Hagar on vocals,for the most part,once Hagar was with the group,the songs became more mature and good but not as fun and rocking as the Van Halen era with David Lee Roth was. With the exceptions of \\"Poundcake\\" and \\"Spanked\\",this album showed that Van Halen was really starting to mature;however,this album still rocks. The producer of this album,Andy Johns,had also produced some Led Zeppelin albums,so if you put every Zeppelin album in a blender with \\"Diver Down\\"(their fourth album which featured DLR on lead vocals),\\"0U812\\"(their eighth album out of all of their albums and the second album they had with Sammy Hagar on lead vocals),and every song from the 80's/90's hair metal group Slaughter(hence,the song \\"Up All Night\\"(Sleep All Day)that is reminiscient of Zeppelin(FLY TO THE ANGELS,DO YA KNOW,BREAKDOWN 'N CRY,HEAVEN IT CRIES,and HEADIN' FOR A DREAM)then this album would be the result. The opening song,\\"Poundcake\\",is fun,juvenile,raunchy and a cross between Warrant's \\"Cherry Pie\\" song and Def Leppard's classic \\"Pour Some Sugar On Me\\". The other highlights here are \\"Runaround\\",\\"In 'n Out\\",\\"Right Now\\",the beautiful instrumental \\"316\\"(which Eddie Van Halen wrote for his son Wolfgang that he had with Valerie Bertinelli)and the closing song,\\"Top Of The World\\",which is a really nice and cool song. Bottom Line:All die hard David Lee Roth fans need to stay far away from this record as possible,but all Van Halen fans who are loyal VH fans with either David Lee Roth or Sammy Hagar need to give this album a listen.
B0006A9FKA|5.0|Its impossible not to love this movie.It has Zombies, romance, scares and even a tear or two. Its without a doubt the best movie to come out of the UK in the last five years. <br /> <br />Simon Pegg is wonderful as Shaun, the ultimate everyman with his sidekick Nick Frost as Ed. The rest of the cast are wonderful and a veritable whos who of British comedy, with Lucy Davis from the smash hit \\"The Office\\" and utterly fabulous Dylan Moran who is perhaps one of the greatest Irish standup comics ever. <br /> <br />The film was not what I was expecting at all. I was expecting a kind of typical spoof on all levels, with lots of \\"in jokes\\" for people who love Zombie movies. But that isnt what I got at all. It actually had a plot. A good one at that. You feel for these characters, especially Shaun who has to see more than a few of his loved ones fall prey to the flesh eating followers. I was choked up at the scenes with his mother and the goodbye to Ed in the cellar. There is genuine tension created with the character David, proving Dylan Morans wonderful range as a dramatic actor.  As a result this film has just as much credibilty, if not more, than the recent remake of Dawn of the Dead.  <br /> <br />On the extras front, this is a perfect example of how to produce a real dvd. The wealth of commentaries (on the uk release) is wonderful. B000001FQQ|4.0|KISS' \\"Hot In The Shade\\" album,which was released in October of 1989 and was their last album that was released in the 80's,is a pretty good album.I'll sum it up this way:it is a good album,but it is really different from \\"Lick It Up\\",\\"Animalize\\",\\"Asylum\\",and \\"Crazy Nights\\". The opening track is \\"Rise To It\\",which is an intersting song. The lyrics are sung from the point of view of a guy who wants payback towards his \\"snobby\\" ex-wife/girlfriend-what's so interesting about the lyrics of this song is that the video for this song showed Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley putting on their make-up backstage at a KISS concert and talking about the future of the band-so when Paul Stanley wrote this track with Bob Halligan,I wonder what he and Gene Simmons had on their minds(I remember reading once that there was supposed to be a KISS reunion tour in 1989 that would feature Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Ace Frehley,and Eric Carr and that Simmons,Stanley,Frehley,and Carr were going to put back on their makeup and costumes). I wonder what happened. <br /> <br />The rest of this album,while it is not outstanding,is pretty good. It spawned the hit power ballad \\"Forever\\",which was written by BOTH Paul Stanley AND Michael Bolton,and this album also has the original KISS song from their 80's era that Eric Carr(RIP)sang(note that KISS re-recorded \\"Beth\\" with Carr on lead vocals for their \\"Smashes,Thrashes,and Hits\\" greatest hits package that was released in Nvember of 1988). That song(the song on this album)is \\"Little Caesar\\",which is a really cool tune-it kind of reminds me of the things I've heard about Carr's unreleased cartoon show,\\"The Rockheads\\".Everything else here,while it is not earth shattering,is really good and really different-\\"Hide Your Heart\\" is about fights over love between teenagers(it may seem hard to understand after You've listened to the lyrics of the song,but if You've seen the video for that song on KISS' \\"Extreme Closeup\\" video than You'll understand the concept ofthe song).\\"Betrayed\\" is about being betrayed and following \\"the law of the jungle\\" when You're out on your own,and I won't give away everything,but \\"Somewhere Between Heaven and Hell\\"is sung from the point of view from a guy(believe it or not,this is a Gene Simmons song)who has his heart broken because his girlfriend will not have sex with him. Very interesting. <br /> <br />Overall,while this is not a great album,it is pretty good,and it is just really different. It was the last KISS album that Eric Carr would perform on(Carr died of heart cancer in November 1991)and out of all of the KISS albums of the 80's following \\"Lick It Up\\",this was where everyone in the band kind of gave it a 100 percent-Gene Simmons had been acting in movies and was not available to complete half of \\"Animalize\\" and \\"Asylum\\",and he co-wrote more tracks on this then he did on \\"Crazy Nights\\". So,considering all of those facts,it is really interesting to see how this album turned out,especially since this was the last album that Vini Poncia(the producer of Dynasty,Unmasked,Peter Criss' self-titled 1978 solo album,among some of Criss' other solo albums)co-wrote some songs on this record,although he did not produce it. <br /> <br />An interesting album-especially for a KISS record.

B00005B58Y|5.0|Milestones is a transitional recording . Sandwiched betweeen Round ABout Midnight and Kind Of Blue, it features Miles with Coltrane and Cannonball just before Miles' move to a pure modal approach on Kind Of Blue. For me the title tune is a stunner and it has become something of a jazz anthem for good reason. The contrast between Adderly's melodic playing, Coltrane's harsher approach and the perfectly understated trumpet of Miles Davis is one of those moments in musical history that make you shake your head in wonder. The treatment given Monk's Straight No Chaser is fantastic. This is right up there as one of my favorite Miles recordings.

B0007MVXQG|5.0|Judas Priest's comeback album finds them picking up about where they left off in the `80's. \\"Angel of Retribution\\" has as much energy and integrity that Priest had when Rob Halford left in 1990. Thus, when I listen to this C.D., I sometimes forget what year it is- and that Rob is 54 years old! He is the third oldest man who is still playing heavy metal (Lemmy Kilmister of Motorhead is the first oldest, and Ozzy's second.)  <br />  <br />Some people (some very ignorant people) say that some of Priest's new songs sound too similar to \\"British Steel\\" and \\"Screaming for Vengeance.\\" Let me defend this statement. First of all, if you like the sound, what are you complaining about? Next, the original singer rejoined the group, so of course the new material is going to be similar to what it sounded like before. This is a return to form! Finally, at least Judas Priest didn't \\"modernize their sound\\" for this album. Some criticize Metallica and Slayer for doing this, but there's no way this group did. <br />  <br />At ten tracks, one might think this is a fairly short C.D., fortunately, at 52 minutes, it is not. There aren't as many high pitched yells here as there were when Rob was in his prime, but there are as many vocal hooks, Megadeth-esque guitar solos, and songs that are about devils, demons, and Hell. I guess you're never too old to hail Satan.   <br />  <br />Highlights include: <br />  <br />\\"Judas Rising\\" deserves to be the first single. The opening riff fades in and gains in volume, then things take off when the drums begin. I enjoy how the verses of this song build, then the music pauses for the very catchy choruses. The song is rounded off by two guitar solos. <br />\\"Deal with the Devil\\" features a speedy, running and chugging riff and a great guitar solo (around the 2:20 mark), which has several different parts to it. I don't mean to sound cheesy, but guitarist Glenn Tipton must have made a \\"deal with the Devil,\\" so he could sound this good. <br />Things slow down a bit during \\"Worth Fighting For\\" (which features soft singing and only and occasional riff), but they pick back up again for the very next track, \\"Demonizer.\\" It has a fast opening riff and fast-but not pummeling-double bass work by the drummer (Scott Travis). The riff then turns to a fast chug, and another wailing guitar solo (which keeps up with the pace of the song's beat) is included, as are a couple of Rob's high-pitched squeals (when he says \\"demonizer\\"). <br />\\"Wheels of Fire\\" has a slower (but still pretty fast) riff and a couple more (albeit brief) guitar solos. It is quite repetitive, both musically and lyrically, but even this song gets stuck in my head. <br />\\"Lochness\\" is 12 minutes long, but it otherwise begins as a continuation of track nine, \\"Eulogy.\\" It begins very slowly, with distant guitar noise. Then the drums kick in and the guitars come to the forefront. The next minute is a staccato riff, followed by a very brief chug and one last good guitar solo. Then things slow way down, but even at its fastest, \\"Lochness\\" is only about half the speed as most of the other songs. The C.D. ends with some wah-wah guitar noise, and a couple of crunchy riffs.  <br />  <br />The only flaw \\"Angel of Retribution\\" has is about all of its fast songs are the same speed. That's certainly not a fatal flaw, however. It's just the niche this band has created; it's part of what they're famous for. Plus, not all of the songs are fast. Tracks 4, 7 and 9 are all slow songs, almost power ballads, and (as aforementioned), track ten is half-speed as the fast songs.   <br />  <br />You might be wondering why I call this a comeback. Well, even though Priest have been making music all this time (even with Rob gone), almost no one wanted to hear any of it. So, now that Rob's back, Judas Priest-who are in top form, here-have made possibly the year's best C.D., and definitely the comeback of the year. The bottom line is this is a great album, any metalhead should pick it up, andthe bonus disc makes a great inclusion to any Priest collection. Is \\"Judas rising?\\" No, Judas has risen.
B00000I8BX|4.0|i bought this obsolete not long ago along with a couple other cds i found at cheep prices on this site. not instantly being impressed with this cd i set it aside. about a week later i found a couple songs that especially enjoyed like the first and favorite track:\\"shock\\" the heaviest on the album: \\"concreto\\" and the longest song: \\"resurrection\\". now i enjoy pretty much every song except the anoying \\"cars\\" the creepy bonus track \\"0-0 were evil dwells\\". its awesome how a lot of songs have cool intros and escelate to a shout along chorus near the end(title of review) its also pretty awesome how the flow of the music seems almost mechanical, the bass and drums are very precise, almost like a machine. but unlike other fear factory cds, this one will take some time before it finally grows on you. i would definite consider this cd to anyone interested in industrial heavy metal, AFTER BUYING ARCHYTYPE OR DEMANUFACTURE since those are better by comparison. this though is what i would consider a classic from one of the best industrial metal bands to ever walk the face of the earth!

Enjoy the Silence got me hooked and I expected another album like Violator when DM returned to the scene in 1993. Dave vocals were escpecially good.  The only thing is that the bad was having relationship and drug troubles and that might be the reason that there are some things to the ablum that doesn't work.  That being said, this album was better than most that were released in 1993.  Here are the songs: <br /> <br />1.  I Feel You (10/10) Powerful! Wow!  The video for this song was perfect and this was the best song to open the album up. <br />2.  Walking in My Shoes (10/10) One of DM's best songs.  Deep and thought provactive....this song has made many non DM fans a true addict. <br />3.  Condemnation (8/10) The only problem with this song is Dave's vocals.  There are only two songs in the entire DM cataloge where his vocals could have been better and this is one of them.  Martin's lyrics in this song are some of his best.  How many song writers of today would dare make a single of a song like this one?  DM's brialliance really comes through! <br />4.  Mery in You (9/10)  Great song! Dave's tortured voice perfectly conveys the emotions of the song.  DM at its best! <br />7.  Get Right With Me (7/10)  This is the weakest song on the album and it really doesn't fit. There isn't one keyboard used in the song but rather an entire orchestral session backed up by Martin Gore's best vocal performance by far.  I played this song to a friend of mine who hates DM and this song made him a fan.   <br />10.  Higher Love (10/10) This is my favorite track on the album because I feel this is how the album was supposed to end up.  This song is perfectly written, sund, mixed and edited.  Not to mention the fact that the lyrics are amazing!  Read the lyrics while you listen to the music and it will send you to a world of bliss.   <br /> <br />Songs of Faith and Devotion is one of DM's best albums and certainly was also one of the best albums of  the 1990's.  It was also the first alternative album to open at number 1 on both sides of the Atlantic.  Quite an accomplishment. <br /> <br />

B0000C8AVI|4.0|Dylan's career epitomizes change. He has buffeted and tossed fans around on a wild sea of change and reinvention since 1965 (when he picked up an electric guitar in defiance of the folk community's unwritten rules). The year 1979 saw his most shocking transition. One that challenged and threatened Dylan's career like no other. Dylan began espousing Christianity and throwing around the term \\"born again\\". Jerry Wexler, who produced \\"Slow Train Coming\\", told Dylan biographer Clinton Heylin that \\"I had no idea he was on this born-again Christian trip until he started to evangelize me.\\" Wexler diplomatically told Dylan to back off, but he produced the album anyway. So in the heyday of punk the performer many people associated, fairly or unfairly, with 1960s \\"radicalism\\" turned explicitly Christian. Not only that, 1978's \\"Street Legal\\" met with an extremely icy reception. For many fans Dylan's new \\"phase\\" was too much.<br /><br />Dylan's \\"Christian phase\\" (though arguably not a phase) now looks somewhat innocuous from a historical perspective. After two (some say one, some say three) more \\"Christian\\" albums, Dylan's lyrics morphed once again. Would his career have survived had he plunged permanently into Christian music? Hard to say. Many thought he was through in 1965. He may have simply found a different audience (though in the 1970s that audience would probably have been a small one). Regardless, the 1980s were probably the low point of Dylan's career from many perspectives.<br /><br />\\"Slow Train Coming\\" is a Christian album. It makes no apologies for this. Though far less preachy than its successor, \\"Saved\\", the theme of the album remains unmistakable. \\"When He Returns\\", the album's passionate closer, more than demonstrates this with lines such as \\"He's got plans of his own to set up His throne when He returns\\".<br /><br />Whether or not listeners accept this album most likely depends on their attitude towards the lyrics. Because there's nothing wrong with the music on \\"Slow Train Coming\\". \\"Gotta Serve Somebody\\" grooves in a way that Dylan had never really grooved previously. \\"Precious Angel\\" features Mark Knoplfer's distinctive guitar style and probably one of the best Dylan drawls ever recorded: \\"Ya know I just couldn't make it by myself. I'm a little too blind to seeeEEEeeeeee.\\" \\"Slow Train\\" contains an ominous groove. \\"When you Gonna Wake Up\\" lashes out at society's failings. Whether one agrees with the religious perspective or not, the criticism here seems valid and constructive. Only \\"Man Gave Names To All The Animals\\" sounds a little trite. Everything else on \\"Slow Train Coming\\" receives passion and conviction. Again, whether or not one agrees with the overall message, Dylan's performance is outstanding on this album (it even bagged him a Grammy for \\"Best Rock Vocal\\" - something his detractors, especially those who find his distinctive voice grating, must have cringed at).<br /><br />\\"Slow Train Coming\\" just adds proof to the argument that Bob Dylan remains one of the most provocative, controversial, and intruiguing artists of the 20th century. Apart from the music, he's given his fans plenty of challenges, and given future generations an almost insurmountable amount of material to ponder and debate about.\\"Gotta Serve Somebody\\" grooves in a way that Dylan had never really grooved previously. \\"Precious Angel\\" features Mark Knoplfer's distinctive guitar style and probably one of the best Dylan drawls ever recorded: \\"Ya know I just couldn't make it by myself. I'm a little too blind to seeeEEEeeeeee.\\" \\"Slow Train\\" contains an ominous groove. \\"When you Gonna Wake Up\\" lashes out at society's failings. Whether one agrees with the religious perspective or not, the criticism here seems valid and constructive. Only \\"Man Gave Names To All The Animals\\" sounds a little trite. Everything else on \\"Slow Train Coming\\" receives passion and conviction. Again, whether or not one agrees with the overall message, Dylan's performance is outstanding on this album (it even bagged him a Grammy for \\"Best Rock Vocal\\" - something his detractors, especially those who find his distinctive voice grating, must have cringed at).    \\"Slow Train Coming\\" just adds proof to the argument that Bob Dylan remains one of the most provocative, controversial, and intruiguing artists of the 20th century. Apart from the music, he's given his fans plenty of challenges, and given future generations an almost insurmountable amount of material to ponder and debate about.

I don't mean to sound cheesy, but guitarist Glenn Tipton must have made a \\"deal with the Devil,\\" so he could sound this good.<br />Things slow down a bit during \\"Worth Fighting For\\" (which features soft singing and only and occasional riff), but they pick back up again for the very next track, \\"Demonizer.\\" It has a fast opening riff and fast-but not pummeling-double bass work by the drummer (Scott Travis). The riff then turns to a fast chug, and another wailing guitar solo (which keeps up with the pace of the song's beat) is included, as are a couple of Rob's high-pitched squeals (when he says \\"demonizer\\").<br />\\"Wheels of Fire\\" has a slower (but still pretty fast) riff and a couple more (albeit brief) guitar solos. It is quite repetitive, both musically and lyrically, but even this song gets stuck in my head.<br />\\"Lochness\\" is 12 minutes long, but it otherwise begins as a continuation of track nine, \\"Eulogy.\\" It begins very slowly, with distant guitar noise. Then the drums kick in and the guitars come to the front. The next minute is a staccato riff, followed by a very brief chug and one last good guitar solo. Then things slow way down, but even at its fastest, \\"Lochness\\" is only about half the speed as most of the other songs. The C.D. ends with some wah-wah guitar noise, and a couple of crunchy riffs.<br /><br />The only flaw \\"Angel of Retribution\\" has is about all of its fast songs are the same speed. That's certainly not a fatal flaw, however. It's just the niche this band has created, it's part of what Priest are famous for. Plus, not all of the songs are fast. Tracks 4, 7 and 9 are all slow songs, almost power ballads, and (as aforementioned) track ten is half the speed as the fast songs.<br /><br />You might be wondering why I call this a comeback. Well, even though Priest have been making music all this time (even with Rob gone), almost no one wanted to hear any of it. But, now that Rob's back, Judas Priest (who are in top form here) have made possibly the year's best C.D., and definitely the comeback album of the year.<br /><br />The bottom line is this is a great album, one that is so exciting and has somuch great musicianship, it's on par with the classics \\"British Steel\\" and \\"Screaming for Vengence.\\" Any metalhead should pick \\"Angel of Retribution\\" up, and the live DVD (or the bonus C.D., if you get the Dual Disc package) would make a great inclusion to any Priest collection.<br /><br />Is \\"Judas rising?\\" No. Judas has risen.teel\\" and \\"Screaming for Vengence.\\" Any metalhead should pick \\"Angel of Retribution\\" up, and the live DVD (or the bonus C.D., if you get the Dual Disc package) would make a great inclusion to any Priest collection.     Is \\"Judas rising?\\" No. Judas has risen.

B000000W6F|4.0|Back in 91 this album represented the vanguard of alternative rock before such a thing existed.  SP were part of a group of new bands trying to push the boundaries (along with Nirvana, Alice In Chains, Sonic Youth, Jane's Addiction, Faith No More, Dinosaur Jr., Soundgarden, et al).  I had this back in 91 and was struck by how similiar I thought it sounded to Jane's Addiction.  Since I was in mourning over Jane's breakup, I ate this up (I even saw SP tour to support this album - in between Pearl Jam and Red Hot Chili Peppers in Oct 91!!).  Anyway, while this album has a lot of great songs, fans of Siamese Dream may be surprised by some of Gish's more psychadelic leanings.  It's a good album, but listening to it 15 years later, I realize that it loses steam and focus on the second half.  Nonetheless, it'll always hold a place in my heart (props to the reviewer from Ontario who nailed high school in the early 90s on the head).

B0006L16N8|4.0|I have followed Coldplay since parachutes (my favorite) through A Rush (least favorite) to X and Y (middle). One has to admit that colplay have made changes in their sound from album to album. Parachutes was a brisk record with relaxed downplayed songs that maintain a unique feeling not unlike a pleasent summer afternoon. AROBTTH was Coldplays attempt at being a stadium rock band and they achieved that with the opening chords of Politik rocking like no tommorow, though that album didn't seem to flow as well as parachutes and began to crumble toward the end.  <br />      X and Y is similar to AROBTTH at being another stadium rocker record containing some epic ballads. It also possess a new sound for coldplay with addition of organs to almost every track here. Now I have been hearing a lot of people slamming this record because they say its the same melencholic sweet guy lamenting formula, which is true, no doubt, but these are, nontheless, undeniably beautiful songs that elevate the listener.  <br />       Favorite include: Square One (can't get enough of the guitar part in chours), White Shadows (has an 80's vibe to it), Talk (the catchiest track here, awesome use of Kraftwerks riff)Swallowed in the Sea (nice melody) and Twisted Logic (uses the chord change from the beatles' 'she's so heavy') <br />       Innovation is admirable, but not for everyone and I respect that colplay have found a sound that works and sounds good. If your gonna judge a product by looking at past results than your not fairly judging the product, So just sit back, hit play and let your mind wander!  <br />  <br />By the way, Speed of Sound Kind of sucks! Why is it their first single??? Oh well, I still bought it.

B00013RC9I|5.0|My history of Air began with Moon Safari and that CD made making out 3X as fun as usual! So when I saw this new CD from France's best space pop duo I couldn't resist and bought it hoping it's magic would work just as well. I think the most accurate statement is that this new output is like Moon Safari's less fun little brother. He tries being suave and sexy, and he succeds occasionally, but he also has a cold serious side that the ladies don't like as much. He's more of an indidual and ops to speak for himself (there are no guest vocals on this record), His spacy serious side emerges in songs like the creepy 'Another Day' and the awkward futuristic 'Biological'.  <br />        <br />         But when he's on, He's on, 'Cherry Blossum Girl' is purely heaven. The flute solos sound cheesy but add a mysterious element to the song. Then there is the lennonesque 'Surfing on a Rocket,' arguably the best song here with its guitar lick which moves you (and your friend) into zero gravity. Other highlights include the sublime 'Universal Traveler' and the soothing closing track, 'Alone in Kyoto' which appears in the 'Lost in Translation' Movie. <br />        <br />      Altogether an solid effort that only increases my love for Air. If your looking for a make out CD you may need to hit the skip track a couple of times or you should check out their song from the Virgin Suicides soundtrack, 'Playground Love.' Though I defenitely appreciate their experimental side and I look forward to their future releases.  <br />        <br />

006072448X|4.0|Kevin Katchadourian is a parent's worst nightmare: a sullen child who abuses, manipulates, and controls everyone around him. His mother Eva seems to know something is terribly wrong with her son from the moment she gives birth, as he grasps for his father and turns a baleful eye towards his mother. As he gets older, Eva's maternal instincts about her dark child places him at the center of incident after incident: playgoups that are dismantled; misterious bike accidents; sexual precocity. As Kevin grows up and Eva bears a beautiful young daughter, the family dynamic becomes even more explosive as she and her husband Franklin take sides against Kevin and his malevolence presence in the family. <br /> <br />The inorexible march towards the conclusion - Kevin's violent and methodical attack on his classmates - made my stomach tie itself up in knots. Franklin pushes a Walton's-esque picture of perfection onto the family, and turns a blind eye to Kevin's failings as a son and as a human being. Eva is helpless as Kevin controls the Katchadourians and eventually destroys everyone around him. <br /> <br />Taking the form of letters written to Franklin, Eva reflects on her marriage, her children, the nature of violence and hypocrisy in America, and what it feels like to be the mother of a disturbed and dangerous child. This is not a light book, but it is a necessary one. Eva's inability to mother Kevin is perhaps an insightful look at those women who bore the real-life School Killers, and Lionel Shriver should be congratulated on her brave and difficult work.

The funeral feast is helpful because it is one of those sensitive times and comfort food always helps. <br /> <br />Hope it has been helpful.

0375703764|5.0|I first heard about this novel on the radio here in Dallas / Fort Worth.  The author's sister is the artist Poe, and she performs a song from her album \\"Haunted\\" that contains her brother reading a selection from this novel.  This got me interested. <br /> <br />This work is unconventional and truly terrifying.  It thoroughly uses footnotes and carefully structured/printed paragraphs to add another dimension (pun intended) to the House / novel. <br /> <br />The novel really gets in your head and makes you wonder whether there is any truth to the story or not.  It is written in a somewhat journalisitic style; almost as if it were a work of non-fiction.  This makes the work even more terrifying. <br /> <br />This work is very similar in style to Jorge Luis Borges (see \\"Labyrinths\\"), but is distinctly unique.  For another work that is somewhat similar in style, see Jeff Vandermeer's \\"City of Saints and Madmen\\". <br /> <br />While the footnotes can, at times, prove frustrating in that they can interrupt your progress through the novel, I can't recommend this work enough.  No other book has scared me more, and I am hard pressed to think of another book that has been more engrossing.

0767834739|2.0|John Huston once said that a good story should have \\"excitement,color, spectacle and humor, adventure, high drama, tragedy, good conversation, truth and irony\\". Unfortunately the discerning viewer won't find much of any of those qualities in \\"Resident Evil: Apocalypse\\". What they will find is a mildly entertaining spectacle of excess. There is enough tension to keep you watching, but when it finally ends and your mind recovers from its numbness, you will wish that you had not bothered.    The ending is both familiar and predictable, at least to anyone over age six. Apparently predictability is comforting to the movie genre's core fan base, in much the same way as it is for a young child watching \\"Beauty and the Beast\\" over and over again. They know the ending so the initial viewing does not scare them, and the repeated viewings give them a feeling of power and control as if they are determining the outcome each time they watch it.    The authors of the DVD expect multiple viewings as they provide three separate commentaries on the disc. A director producer/commentary, a cast commentary, and a writer/producer commentary. More terrifying than anything in the movie is the thought of listening to ALL these commentaries. Sometimes the degree of conceit and self-delusion exhibited by those close to a movie is astonishing. Do they actually believe that this unoriginal exercise in excess is worthy of even one commentary. If you can't make better stuff than this (editor and production designer excluded) you should go back to school and get your CPA.    Finally John Huston would say that it doesn't hurt to have lovable hero's in your story. Lovable heroines wouldn't hurt either or at least ones that look sexy. Milla Jovovich and Sienna Guillory are attractive women but if they chose their own costumes (?) for this movie they are also airheads.  Like many women they dress in what they think makes them look sexy. The result is a 6th Street hooker look that makes you laugh everytime they appear in the frame. Check out Milla's \\"Zoolander\\" look if you want to see what could have been; she actually looks sexier wearing old army fatigues in \\"Dummy\\" than she does in her \\"Resident Evil-Apocalypse\\" outfits.    Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

0060512806|5.0|Cryptonomicon is a delightful outburst of creative and intellectual energy.  It's a novel that interweaves the stories of a modern-day cryptographer and his grandfather's adventures in World War II.  The plotting is complicated but enjoyable, but the best of the book is all that happens along the way.  There are many very interesting excursions into mathematics that require some patience but reward it.  There are fascinating windows into the world of high technology and its potentials.  There are things to learn about espionage, nature, music, language, breakfast cereal, and a hundred other topics.      I don't consider Cryptonomicon any great success as a novel in the traditional sense.  Many of the characters are flat.  And it's certainly too long.  The author is in love with his own powers and can't restrain them.  But if you approach the basic story as an excuse for the ingenious digressions, explorations, and the like that constantly appear, it's a very enjoyable ride.

0805066691|5.0|America is legitimately a beacon of freedom to a weary and war-torn world. Really. What America has wrought serves as a shining example to all peoples for all time.<br /><br />But when the Chinese, for example, chide us for our criticism of their treatment of the peoples of Tibet and Xinjiang by saying that we ought to get off our high horse, thay make a painful point.<br /><br />Somehow, just after America finished spilling the blood of a million of its own people to preserve the Union and free the Negro slaves, the same people (Sherman, Sheridan, Custer, et al were heroes of the Civil War) took it upon themselves, as the instrument of a whole nation, to exterminate the Indians.<br /><br />Why would a country emancipate and enfranchise its Negro slaves at such a staggering cost and almost simultaneously deny freedom, franchise and life itself to the Indians?<br /><br />This book makes it pretty plain that the vast majority of the Plains Indians were no threat to anyone. For the most part they were pitiful and starving, and completley overwhelmed by the advance of our forebears. Most of the attacks by the US Army on Indian encampments caught the occupants completely by surprise and resulted in the deaths primarily of women and children.<br /><br />But we already knew this, didn't we? What this book lays out is just how outmatched the Indians were and just how predatory the White Man was. No punches are pulled, but this is no polemic.<br /><br />So what was the difference, in the late 1800s, between the Negro and the Indian? Why were they treated so completely differently? The only conclusion can be that the Negro didn't own anything of value at the time, whereas the Indian had the great misfortune to be living on land that a much stronger people wanted to occupy.<br /><br />America can still serve as a beacon of freedom and rectitude to the world. But we did not come by this without some shameful behavior.

B0006GAOBI|5.0|Granted, it's a thought provoking movie, which is a bit of an oxymoron, if you think about it. I mean, movies are Entertainment, and the minute you have to think about what is supposed to entertain you, it stops being entertainment, and becomes work, which is what we go to movies to escape from! <br />Okay, I'm not saying this because I don't 'get it.' I'm the weirdo in my social circle. Tape deck: Pink Floyd, Radiohead, Coldplay, conscious hip-hop - the stuff that requires thinking. <br />Favorite movies: Fight Club, Vanilla Sky, Memento - the stuff that the average dude has to see 3-4 times to 'get.' <br />I respect your attempts at philosophy, Sunshine - no doubt you're a college man. But for God's Sakes, this isn't a teen movie made to challenge religion. The Matrix has more religious undertones than Donnie Darko! DD is an acid trip, in the most poignant sense of the word. <br />Bear in mind, I rated this movie five-stars, so I'm not belittling it. Still, so many of my friends have the tendency to overhype things. If it's just okay, it's good. If it's good, it's great. If it's great, it's a classic piece of art that dwarfs all things in its presences. You get the picture. <br />About the movie: Donnie Darko, like the last review said, is a challenging movie, with a scenario that's hard to explain to someone who hasn't seen. Even after all is said and done, it's still difficult to tell whether Donnie Darko has imagined the whole thing, or if he has somehow been able to turn back the hands of time. <br />Donnie's an iconoclast; he (forgive the tired cliche) marches to the beat of a different drum. He's a little darker than those his age (duh), but he's also a lot smarter, dabbling in obscure sciences, and often wrapped up in an obsession with the study of time travel.  <br />This would make him a respectable fellow, if not for forte for theories about the apocalypse, as well as the fact that he sees a life-sized talking rabbit (we've all seen that in the trailer).<br />All of the performances, both from the veteran actors, of which there are a few, and the newcomers, of which there are also quite a few, are very well-delivered and believable. It's really surprising to me that this wasn't a big movie, propelling Jake to stardom (sure, he's popular, and he got to go out with Kirsten Dunst, but he's no A-Lister). <br />It's very surprising that this was the writer/director's first film, as every piece of dialogue, and every camera angle seems like it came from the hands of a pro.  <br />In the end, I highly recommend this movie. It is a great film, a thing that young aspiring directors may look to in the future for inspiration. So, in conclusion, people, watch it, enjoy it, but please don't take it too seriously!

B000002I7R|4.0|As some reviewers put here - Pictures At Eleven IS arguably Plant's best album.  Somewhat forgotten after more than 20 years, the production still sounds crisp and the band is tight.  Many of the songs were co-written with Robbie Blunt, who turned out to be an excellent and distinctive guitarist in his own right - with a sound pleasing to Zep and Page fans.<br /><br />What did Plant do right here?  Well, he went for a solo sound that didn't try too hard to break new musical ground (\\"pretentious\\" as one reviewer puts it here).  He put out a mature somewhat progressive AOR album, where different styles and arrangements come into play with each track.<br /><br />\\"Like I've Never Been Gone\\" and \\"Moonlight In Samosa\\" are classic Plant tracks and highlight his ballad skills.  I've always felt that \\"Like I've Never Been Gone\\" was the successor to \\"Since I've Been Loving You\\" - listen to it and you'll know what I mean.<br /><br />\\"Slow Dancer\\" sees Plant recalling Kashmir and hammering it home while \\"Worse Than Detroit\\" is classic blues rock with some Zep nuances.  Both of these could have easily been Zeppelin tracks from another time and place, giving them some special resonance.<br /><br />\\"Pledge Pin\\" is another interesting Plant track which features a great sax solo.  Driving this album is its excellent rhythm section, which never lets up.<br /><br />Worth getting if you're curious about Plant's solo work, like Zep, and want to hear what might've been - had Plant kept the path of the blues.  This is the closest tangent from Zep that exists, besides The Firm's \\"Mean Business\\" album with Jimmy Page.  In subsequent albums, Plant would move further away from his rock and blues roots into synth territory.<br /><br />In all, Pictures at Eleven makes you nostalgic for the Plant that had just left Led Zeppelin and was finding a new future.  Although he's continually evolved as an artist, Pictures at Eleven was a debut album that amazingly still sounds good after all this time.<br /><br />**Postscript: Strangely, none of the tracks were selected for his Sixty Six to Timbuktu album.  The extra tracks on the reissue are nice to have but not indispensable.  The sound mixing is a little better but as others point out - it's not a quantum leap.  Go Percy!were selected for his Sixty Six to Timbuktu album.  The extra tracks on the reissue are nice to have but not indispensable.   The sound mixing is a little better but as others point out - it's not a quantum leap.  Go Percy!

B00082IJ08|4.0|When the Gorillaz first broke back in early 2001, I was not very impressed. \\"Clint Eastwood\\" was overplayed trash in my opinion, and I quickly grew to hate them. Four years has passed and the band are back now with their second album \\"Demon Days.\\" I rolled my eyes upon hearing about this return, but something happened over the past month or so which has lead to me buying the album in question, and to be honest, I'm quite surprised. I always thought of Damon Albarn as this really fit guy out of Blur, and whilst Blur's material from the Nineties is embedded in the public conscious, I've never been really impressed with their more recent stuff.<br /><br />I don't own the debut album by the Gorillaz because, like I said before, I was too busy hating them, so I can't really compared Demon Days to it in terms of style, content and appeal. I half-expected this album to be full of hip-hop drizzle and dull rap style, but this is very much not the case. Whilst a few songs bestow these features, most of the songs here are highly elaborate, well crafted and beat-heavy. There's elements of funk, pop, rock, indie, hip-hop, R'n'B and a lot more. The addition of strings towards the end of many songs is also quite a revelation.<br /><br />The album opens with \\"Intro,\\" which I feel is a rather pointless way to begin the album. This is followed by \\"Last Living Souls.\\" I loved this song from the minute I heard it, because it's just so fun. The beat is almost computerized and bounces all over the place. The synths are a wondrous addition, making for a very polished track. A possible single. \\"Kids With Guns\\" has a heavy and clunky beat that plods along. The lyrics are quite powerful yet almost tongue-in-cheek. The vocals drag in that intended way that makes the Gorillaz such a cool band, whilst the female backing vocals add depth and texture to the song. \\"O Green World\\" is very much the opposite of what you'd expect it to be, because this world is obviously not green anymore, but basically a polluted landfill! This would be a great theme for a Green Peace campaign. I like the chanting in the background to this song, and especially the way it flows with the beat. \\"Dirty Harry\\" is an amazing song and one of the best on the album. It almost feels like the past four songs have been a build-up to this. The vocals are very ambiguous, and the addition of a choir works incredibly well. A synth pop beat sparkles and dazzles in the background in time with a clap section that adds rhythm to the song. This is a very primal and quite animalistic song.<br /><br />\\"Feel Good Inc.\\" is the album's first single and features De La Soul. It has this really funny laughing all the way through it that becomes really raucous towards the end! The beat on this song is very bouncy and funky, while the vocals are almost muted. The chorus is really strange psychedelic, and is the highlight of the song. The video is also very good, check it out if you can. \\"El Manana\\" has a quite siren going off in the background as some strange, pulsating beats dance over the bass. A guitar is quite prominent on this song, making for a great holiday anthem that sounds quite dry and desert like. \\"Every Planet We Reach Is Dead\\" is another album highlight. The beat is more immediate on this track than probably any other on the album. I think this song is pretty special because the beat is very dirty and gritty, and it completely stops once someone starts singing. The humming background vocals are also very good. \\"November Has Come\\" is one of the more hip-hop style songs on the album which I'm not very fond of. \\"All Alone\\" is another song I don't really like, because it's very repetitive and gets on my nerves. The beat is also a bit sharp and will annoy you if you're trying to listen to this song while doing work.<br /><br />\\"White Light\\" is a short song at just over two minutes long. This song is very heavy and the beat goes down a storm. Then it all fades as what sounds like a masked choir is trying to break its way through. The beat then comes back to finish the song off. \\"Dare\\" hit me right from the second it began. I wasn't expecting much, but this is a really fantastic song and another album highlight. This is quite a club banger and, DARE I say it, rather camp! It's almost like the band has got their sparkly disco gear on and gone down a club to boogie the night away! I hope this song is released as a single because it would be a huge hit in Europe. \\"Fire Coming Out Of A Monkey's Head\\" is a spoken song for the most of it's three minutes. It's the Gorillaz explanation of human beings, I think. It's quite good but not one of my favourites, but I do like the way the music is in sync with the story being told. \\"Don't Get Lost In Heaven\\" is another really good song and has quite a soft piano playing a very melodic tune in the background. The addition of a choir adds an ethereal, angelic quality to the song. The album closes with the title track \\"Demon Days.\\" This is another great song and a good way to round out the album. It begins as the previous track closes, so they blend into each other. There's some very catchy \\"Woo-woo\\"-ing on this song, followed by some crazy falsetto vocals. It sounds like the perfect round out to a very good album.<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 9/10<br /><br />All in all I'd say that this is an album worthy of a place in your collection. There's some great songs on this album. It begins very strong, taking a bit of a downfall in the middle section, before picking up for a very strong final few songs. Gorillaz have proved with this album that they are so much more than just a cartoon band. Damon Albarn is behind them, so what else would you expect? The man is very talented, and the Gorillaz are simply an outlet for him to express his other musical style without damaging the legacy he has preserved with Blur. This album almost breaks boundaries, because there's styles of music here with other styles that you'd think would not work at all, but they do. Highly recommended.ir is trying to break its way through. The beat then comes back to finish the song off. \\"Dare\\" hit me right from the second it began. I wasn't expecting much, but this is a really fantastic song and another album highlight. This is quite a club banger and, DARE I say it, rather camp! It's almost like the band has got their sparkly disco gear on and gone down a club to boogie the night away! I hope this song is released as a single because it would be a huge hit in Europe. \\"Fire Coming Out Of A Monkey's Head\\" is a spoken song for the most of it's three minutes. It's the Gorillaz explanation of human beings, I think. It's quite good but not one of my favourites, but I do like the way the music is in sync with the story being told. \\"Don't Get Lost In Heaven\\" is another really good song and has quite a soft piano playing a very melodic tune in the background. This album almost breaks boundaries, because there's styles of music here with other styles that you'd think would not work at all, but they do. Highly recommended.

B00003CWL6|5.0|The movie begins in an ominous way  with the video taping of girl who is asks  a friend to kill her father. Not meaning to be a spoiler but we are being set up by this scene.    The next scene we see, the actual beginning of the movie, is an aerial shot of a tree lined street as Kevin Spacey begins to narrate the story. He tells us  that  he is  42  and \\"in less than a year he will be dead\\"  The introductory narration is  done in somewhat of a funny sarcastic deadpan.      Lester Burnham (played by Spacey) lives in a nice neighborhood   and is  married to his  wife Carolyn (Annette Bening) who trys to keep a picture perfect house that would make Martha Stewart proud.     Lester bemoans  his joyless life but as   Lester says in his narration before the story begins it is never too late to make a change.   We  learn Lester is stuck at a job he hates and we see him spending his days on the phone dealing with clients.   His wife  is a driven woman who puts on a false front.  Lester and Carolyn are obviously following two different paths although both are going through a middle age crisis. Most of the adults in this movie are portrayed as living lives that are lies.    They have a teenage daughter, Jane, going through her own painful transition in her life.    Camera work, music and editing come together to humorously highlight the absurdity of the  life style Carolyn has made for her family and with which Lester until recently has gone along.     New neighbors move in next door to the Burnhams who will play an important role in their lives. The new family is run by a tyrannical military man.    But  as the story proceeds three   new characters come into their lives: for Annette Bening it is \\"The Real Estate King\\", for their daughter it is the boy who moves in next door and for Lester it is his daughter's best friend.    Three  events precipitate what comes to follow: the arrival of the new neighbors, a cheerleading performance at a basket ball game and a party for realestate agents.    The Burnhams travel to the basket ball game to see their daughter perform and their Lester becomes smitten with  his daughter's best friend and so he begins an obsession with this Lolita.    At a party for real estate agents Carolyn puts does he best  to be the picture of confidence (Bening is quite  brilliant as her performance of the confident real estate agent which borders on the surreal and absurd) and does her best to schmooze and  to cozy up to \\"The Real Estate King\\". Lester who is bored out of his wits at the party meets Ricky Fitz, the boy next door. Ricky's  is a waiter at the party but the job is really just a cover for his very profitable business as a marijuana dealer. Lester and Ricky step out back where   Lester is reintroduced to pot.  Later we find   Ricky has a fascination with the Burnham's daughter something she learns when she discovers him surreptitiously filming her.     Other than Lester, Ricky is the most pivotal character in the story. He is constantly beaten by his father, did a stint in military school and after   nearly beating a fellow  student to death spends time in a mental hospital. Through it all the suffering he has gone though  he find himself on a  spiritual journey seeing the world as being overwhelmingly beautiful and is now wise beyond his years.  His hobby is video taping everything he sees especially the beauty of the world. Included in the beautiful things that fascinate him are the  eyes of a homeless man who had just died. To paraphrase Ricky says he  could see  God  looking back at him through the eyes of the dead man. There is a beautiful sequence where   Ricky shows  Jane one of his favorite tapes - a bag  dancing in the wind. Despite his criminal profession Ricky can be seen as a young holy man. Also   he seems to symbolize the movie's creators themselves as his fascination with the lens and Ricky's can be seen as being one and the same.    Things progress quickly. Carolyn   continues with her questfor the good life and ends up having and affair with the \\"Real Estate King\\" whereas Lester quits his job and blackmails his boss into giving him a large severance package and  starts working at a fast food restaurant. There is definite a clash of paths, of values and cultures between Lester and his wife.    Lester buys himself the car of his boyhood dreams, listens to the music of his youth, smokes pot and lifts weights. He also continues  his obsession with his daughters' friend until finally the two of them come together. (during this important sequence we are treated to Neil Young's poignant \\"Don't Let it Bring You Down\\"  sung softly in the background).   She offers herself to him willingly  but  Lester  refuses and in that instant things seem to come together for Lester both realizing  his responsibility as an adult and his love for his family. It is a type of epiphany for Lester.     Immediately there after Lester has his brains blown out. To tell you the name of the assailant would take away the surprise.    But the fact that  the lovable Spacey character is now dead is portrayed as a joyous thing and his narration that concludes the movie which sums up his life in a very moving, joyous and hopeful. And in the end everyone seems to experience a type of salvation.     Some of the movie is  social satire  but the overwhelming  message of the movie is the holiness and mystical nature of life and the idea that life and death are on a continuum -  very much in tune with poets such as William Blake, Walt Whitman and Allen Ginsberg.     A wonderful choice of music accentuates the mystical feeling of the movie including the main score which is made up of percussion instruments and that has a somewhat oriental feel to it.     So what does the title refer to? Does it refer to the roses Carolyn tends  or the  Lolita  Lester pursues? I think it is neither. America Beauty for this reviewer seems to refer to  American life. Although is may be materialistic and filled withdisappointments has a holiness to it.    Highly recommended

B00003CXUM|4.0|This movie, filmed in Thailand in order to recreate the atmosphere of Hong Kong in the 1960s, manages to marry the claustrophobic mood of illicit, romantic longing to the sense of epic proportion that only memory can bring. Director Kar Wai Wang was first brought to the attention of many American viewers through Quentin Tarantino's enthusiasm for Chunking Express, a 1994 movie that harbingers some of the techniques employed in Mood For Love but registers nothing near the impact of this melodrama set mostly in the cramped confines of tenement houses and business offices.  <br /> <br />Chief among these techniques are the slow motion shots and the discreet ruptures of time and sequence to emphasize the confusion inherent to the predicament of the two major characters. Where slow motion sequences in Wai's previous work were often halting, and combined with out of focus camera shots, in Mood they are languorous and intensely erotic as they follow swaying hips and swinging arms of characters simply moving from one room to another. These shots are usually close-ups at torso-level (front or back) and encourage in the viewer the kind of obsessive observations made by lovers in close quarters.  <br /> <br />The action begins in 1962 as Chow Mo-Wan (Tony Leung) and Su Li-zhen (Maggie Cheung) move in to adjacent rooms with their respective spouses. Since the heart of the story follows their co-discovery and reactions to the adultery committed by these spouses, there is an element of surprise that evokes sympathy for the Chow and Su as they fumble their way through a web of tangled emotions within their private lives and struggle out from under the oppression of a society that places more burdens on them than on their sneakier spouses, whose faces are never seen and their voices never heard. No wonder that love soon blooms between them as well. On the pretense of writing a martial arts serial together they begin meeting more frequently, and their growing friendship is characterized in the movie by their unification within single frames, where they had hitherto been more often separated by individual shots. Their intimacy increases even as they remain faithful to their already broken marriages, and the poignancy of their choice is most evident in their efforts to keep their relationship secret.  <br /> <br />The importance of secrecy is apparent when Chow shares with a co-worker a fable about confession rather than the details of his life. According to the story, in the old days, if someone had a secret they didn't want to share, they went up a mountain, found a tree, carved a hole in it, and whispered the secret into the hole. Then they covered it with mud, and left the secret there forever. <br /> <br />Perhaps a three fourths of the way through the film moves forward: first to 1966, then to, and finally to Cambodia in 1966 following De Gaulle's visit to Phnom Penh. The era is vividly evoked by a soundtrack that includes Nat King Cole and other standards of the decade. Other staples of the mid-60's aesthetic are the bee hive hair doos and cheongsam dresses worn by Su. <br /> <br />Compared, say, to Adrian Lyne's `Unfaithful', or for that matter, Liv Ullman and Ingmar Bergman's `Faithless,' Wai's film seems both staid and daring in its treatment of adultery. It isn't that morality is sacrificed, but rather the full dimension of moral responsibility is explored in such a way that something more than titillation and lacerating guilt is brought to the drama. To pursue the story of the aggrieved partners is an interesting choice, if not totally unheard of. What makes it works so well is Wang's restraint, which is translated on film as the self-control of Chow and Su. This decision brings its own pain, as when he helps rehearse her for the eventual confrontation and revelation. As viewers we never see this confrontation: we are left to imagine it just as they imagine it. Of course we don't want to, any more than they do, and soon we are returned to the private life shared by them. <br /> <br />The final sequence observes Chow's pilgrimage to Angkor Wat, perhaps as a search for love and reconciliation on a religious plane. He's seen whispering into the hollow space of pillar, confessing his secrets in secret. Though we can't hear, we understand the significance of those whispers, and of such a mysterious ending to such a mysterious movie we are privileged observers indeed.
B00080ZG10|5.0|I had never heard about the life of Howard Hughes before, so \\"The Aviator\\" provided me with an eyeopening exposure to one of the most excentric millionaires of the past century, who ironically enough also happened to be responsible for many of the greatest advancements in commercial aviation during his lifetime.<br /><br />Very well acted, and packed with great talent, the movie touches it all: his titanic contributions to aviation and moviemaking; his flirting with the world's greatest divas of the first half of the 20th century; his David vs. Goliath struggle against PanAm, the world's greatest airline at the time; and his public appearance in front of Congress to redeem himself. All of it happens in the midst of Hughes' torment in dealing with his biggest enemy: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD).<br /><br />We certainly got to thank Scorcese for (yet another) great movie, but as you see the extra fetures, it becomes apparent that DiCaprio is to be thanked just as much if not more. The actor took it upon himself to dig deep into the life of the character, and brought to the screen a fantastically close depiction of his traits, fears and overall personality.<br /><br />After sitting through it, my only complaint (though minor, when compared with the epic proportions of the undertaking) is that it was too long. That aside, this is going to be a movie for the ages, and one that will hopefully create even more awareness about this psychiatric condition known as OCD.

B000002X2B|3.0|Blows sounds essentially like an old JA album and a pretty good one at that. It's highly emotive and an obviously sincere and genuine work compared to today's era of disposable nonsense lyrics and non-melodic electronic/machine rhythms. The unfortunate thing is that for such a haughty concept as universal truth and worth the writing, both lyrically and musically, could have been something they put a little more work into. That's not to say I don't like or appreciate the concept because I like it a lot but as a package the lyrics don't flow particularly well and too many of the melodies sound forced (ie. Mau Mau the opening track).     I've always liked JA and Kantner both but this album has some fabulous bright spots and really did deserve some serious reworking and polishing before putting it out.
